
►<field>pub.n="incomplete"</field><?phoenix upid="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858"?>
►<field>ch.rh="Social and Recreation"</field>Chapter 30. Social and Recreation
Scope Statement
 This chapter contains forms for use in the formation, management, and dissolution or winding up of social and recreational associations and not-for-profit corporations established for social and/or recreational purposes. Also included is a discussion of legal principles, including tax aspects, that should be considered when drafting such documents.
Treated Elsewhere

I. General Considerations
A. Introduction
30:1. In general
Research References
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I001U0D"</field><trace.deleted/><trace>West’s Key Number Digest, Associations &key;101 et seq.</trace>
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I001U0A"</field><trace.deleted/>
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I000Z4M"</field><trace.deleted/>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|1|30:1"</field>Social and recreational organizations may be formed either as unincorporated associations or clubs or as not-for-profit corporations. Both types of organizations serve primarily the same purpose and function. A not-for-profit corporation, however, is subject to greater statutory regulation.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>1►<field>fn.fnref="1"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|1|30:1"</field>See ►<field>st.ref.id="I001TZ5"</field>N-PCL &ss;§§101 et seq.<f_break>Research References<f_break>Nature of associations and clubs, generally, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I000Z5R"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &ss;§§1 et seq.<f_break>N.Y. Not-for-Profit Corp. Law, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I001TZ2"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &ss;§§9 to 13.<f_break>Definition, nature, and kinds of associations and clubs, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I000Z5U"</field>Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &ss;§§1 to 3.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|1|30:1"</field>Members' rights will be much the same whether a social or recreational organization takes the form of a corporation or an association. Membership in the club may be accorded or withheld on such terms and conditions as the organization sees fit to impose. The bylaws and regulations may provide for the requirements of eligibility as a member as well as the admission, rights, interests, and privileges of members. The power to regulate membership will exist regardless of whether the organization is formed as an unincorporated association<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>2►<field>fn.fnref="2"</field><f_break>Research References<f_break>►<field>rc.ref.id="I001TTF"</field>Rights and liabilities arising out of contract for lifetime membership in social or fraternal club or association, 10 A.L.R.3d 1357.<f_break>Regulation of membership in association, generally, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I001TTC"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, <trace.deleted/><trace>Associations and Clubs</trace> &ss;§§<trace.deleted/><trace>15 to 24</trace>.<f_break>Members of not-for-profit corporations, generally, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I000ZBK"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &ss;§§82<trace>2</trace> to 8<trace>38</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> or as a not-for-profit corporation.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>3►<field>fn.fnref="3"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|1|30:1"</field>See ►<field>st.ref.id="I001TTA"</field>N-PCL &ss;§§601 et seq.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|1|30:1"</field>Fees, dues, and assessments may be enforced and collected from the members of either type of organization in accordance with the provisions of the governing instruments.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>4►<field>fn.fnref="4"</field><f_break>Research References<f_break>Liability for dues and assessments, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I000ZBM"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, <trace.deleted/><trace>Associations and Clubs</trace> &s;§19.<f_break>Fees, dues, and assessments in not-for-profit corporations, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I003SGI"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &ss;§§<trace.deleted/><trace>828, 829</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|1|30:1"</field>On a member's acceptance of membership in a social or recreational organization, the basic laws and regulations of the organization become a binding contract between the member and the organization.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>5►<field>fn.fnref="5"</field><f_break>Research References<f_break>Constitution, bylaws, rules, and regulations of unincorporated association, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I001TT8"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, <trace.deleted/><trace>Associations and Clubs</trace> &ss;§§<trace.deleted/><trace>4 to 8</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|1|30:1"</field>This chapter deals primarily with not-for-profit associations that are organized for social and recreational purposes. However, much of the discussion applies to associations organized for other not-for-profit purposes.
B. Tax Aspects
1. General Considerations
30:2. Qualifying for tax-exempt status
Research References
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I000ZBO"</field>West's Key Number Digest, Internal Revenue &key;4045 et seq.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"</field>Nonprofit organizations are often exempt from federal and state income taxation. However, exemption is not granted merely because an organization is nonprofit. The organization must be of a type that can qualify for exemptions under federal and state law, and it must take the necessary procedural steps to establish these exemptions.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>1►<field>fn.fnref="1"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"</field>For practical information concerning the rules and procedures for organizations that seek recognition of exemption from federal income tax under ►<field>st.ref.id="I001TS2"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§501(a), see ►<field>st.ref.id="I000ZCU"</field>I.R.S. Pub. 557, &ldquo;“Tax-Exempt Status for Your Organization.&rdquo;”<f_break>Research References<f_break>For discussion of tax-exempt organizations, generally, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I001TS0"</field>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &ss;§§10:53 et seq.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I000ZCW"</field>Section 501 of the Internal Revenue Code lists the types of organizations that can qualify for exemption. The more common organizations granted exempt status include those considered altruistic in nature.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>2►<field>fn.fnref="2"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I001TRX"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§501(c)(3).<f_break>Research References<f_break>►<field>rc.ref.id="I000ZCZ"</field>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &ss;§§10:53 to 10:79.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> These include religious, educational, scientific, and literary organizations. Less altruistic, but nevertheless community-minded, are such associations as civic leagues, labor unions, chambers of commerce, business associations, credit unions, cemetery companies, veterans' associations, and social clubs.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>3►<field>fn.fnref="3"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"</field>Most of these are listed in ►<field>st.ref.id="I001TMA"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§501(c); other exempt organizations may be found in ►<field>st.ref.id="I000ZIM"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§501(d), (f) and ►<field>st.ref.id="I003SNI"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &ss;§§526 to 528. Farmers' cooperatives are covered by ►<field>st.ref.id="I006LSE"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§521(a).<f_break>Research References<f_break>►<field>rc.ref.id="I001TM7"</field>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &ss;§§10:53 to 10:79.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"</field>Each type of organization must meet its own requirements for exemption. A church, for example, cannot participate in a political campaign and no substantial part of its activities can be expended to influence legislation.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>4►<field>fn.fnref="4"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I000ZIP"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§501(c)(3).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Political activities, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I003SNL"</field>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &s;§10:9<trace>2</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> A social club cannot discriminate in membership because of race, color, or religion and must limit membership and public access.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>5►<field>fn.fnref="5"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I001TM5"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§501(i).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> Other exempt organizations must comply with their own requirements.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"</field>In general, exempt organizations must meet two sets of tests: organizational and operational. The organizations under ►<field>st.ref.id="I000ZIR"</field>Section 501(c)(3) may be used as an example. ►<field>st.ref.id="I003SNN"</field>Section 501(c)(3) includes religious, charitable, scientific, testing for public safety, literary, or educational organizations.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>6►<field>fn.fnref="6"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"</field>Anticruelty societies and certain sports organizations are also covered.<f_break>Research References<f_break>►<field>rc.ref.id="I001TM2"</field>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &s;§10:8<trace>1</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> The charter documents of these organizations must limit the organization's purpose to one or more of the purposes listed in the Code. The powers cannot extend to other activities. The charter cannot empower the organization to devote more than an insubstantial part of its activities to influencing legislation or otherwise intervening in any political campaign for a candidate to public office.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>7►<field>fn.fnref="7"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"</field>Political activities, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I000ZIU"</field>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &s;§10:9<trace>2</trace>. Organizations engaged in influencing legislation are not engaged in an exempt activity. ►<field>st.ref.id="I001TKX"</field>26 C.F.R. &s;§1.501(c)(3)-1(c)(3). They may, however, qualify as a social welfare organization under ►<field>st.ref.id="I000ZJZ"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§501(c)(4).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> The charter must provide that the earnings shall not inure to the benefit of any private person. It must also provide that on dissolution the assets be distributed for exempt or public purposes.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>8►<field>fn.fnref="8"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I003SOV"</field>26 C.F.R. &s;§501(c)(3)-1(b)(4). The charter need not contain this provision if state law requires distribution for exempt purposes.<f_break>Research References<f_break>Private benefit rules, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I001TKV"</field>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &s;§10:8<trace>8</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> If an entity is organized to carry on a trade or business, it cannot be exempt, even if all profits are payable to an exempt organization.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>9►<field>fn.fnref="9"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I001TF7"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§502(a).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Form of organization, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I000ZPP"</field>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &s;§10:54.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> To satisfy the operational test, the organization must engage primarily in activities that further its exempt purpose. Only an insubstantial portion of its activities can be devoted to activities not in furtherance of that purpose.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>10►<field>fn.fnref="10"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I003SUL"</field>26 C.F.R. &s;§1.501(c)(3)-1(c)(1).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Exempt purposes, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I001TF5"</field>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &s;§10:56.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> No part of its net earnings may inure to the benefit of private individuals, and it cannot engage in propaganda or other political activities.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>11►<field>fn.fnref="11"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"</field>An exception exists for elections by organizations (other than churches and private foundations) to make certain limited lobbying expenditures. ►<field>st.ref.id="I000ZPR"</field>26 C.F.R. &s;§1.501(h)-2(a).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Political activities, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I003SUN"</field>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &s;§10:9<trace>2</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"</field>Incorporation is not required for most exempt organizations. For example, exemptions may be obtained by civic leagues or organizations not organized for profit<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>12►<field>fn.fnref="12"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I001TF2"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§501(c)(4).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> and by insurance companies or associations.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>13►<field>fn.fnref="13"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I000ZPU"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§501(c)(15).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Exempt purposes, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I003SUQ"</field>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &s;§10:56.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> A credit union must be without capital stock.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>14►<field>fn.fnref="14"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I001TF0"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§501(c)(14)(A).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> On the other hand, exempt title holding companies must be corporations,<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>15►<field>fn.fnref="15"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I000ZPW"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§501(c)(2).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> as must be farmers' crop financing cooperatives.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>16►<field>fn.fnref="16"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I001TDU"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§501(c)(16).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Exempt purposes, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I000ZR2"</field>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &s;§10:56.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> Here again, the exact requirements for an organization must be met.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"</field>In general, the exemption extends to social and recreational clubs that are supported solely by membership fees, dues, and assessments.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>17►<field>fn.fnref="17"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I001TDS"</field>26 C.F.R. &s;§1.501(c)(7)-1(a).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Social and recreational clubs, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I001TDP"</field>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &s;§<trace.deleted/><trace>10:75</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> However, a club that engages in business, such as making its social and recreational facilities available to the general public or by selling real estate, timber, or other products, is not organized and operated exclusively for pleasure, recreation, and other nonprofitable purposes and is not exempt under the Code.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>18►<field>fn.fnref="18"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I000ZR7"</field>26 C.F.R. &s;§1.501(c)(7)-(1)(b).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"</field>The articles of association or incorporation and bylaws are of importance in determining the exempt status of an organization. They must provide the purposes and powers necessary to qualify the organization as exempt, and they may not contain any additional power or purpose that would render the organization nonexempt.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>19►<field>fn.fnref="19"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"</field>►<field>cc.ref.id="I001T82"</field>Sun-Herald Corporation v. Duggan, 73 F.2d 298 (C.C.A. 2d Cir. 1934).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Charters, bylaws, and other enabling documents, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I000ZWU"</field>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &s;§10:55.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"</field>A club organized for pleasure, recreation, and other nonprofitable purposes is not exempt from taxation for any taxable year if, at any time during such taxable year, the charter, bylaws, or other governing instrument of the organization or any written policy statement of the organization contains a provision that provides for discrimination against any person on the basis of race, color, or religion.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>20►<field>fn.fnref="20"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I003T1Q"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§501(i).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> This federal prohibition of discrimination by certain social clubs does not apply to an auxiliary of a fraternal benefit society meeting certain requirements, which limits its membership to the members of a particular religion,<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>21►<field>fn.fnref="21"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"</field>See ►<field>st.ref.id="I001T80"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§501(i)(1).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> or to a club that in good faith limits its membership to the members of a particular religion in order to further the teachings or principles of that religion and not to exclude individuals of a particular race or color.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>22►<field>fn.fnref="22"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I000ZWW"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§501(i)(2).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"</field>Although the organization must be organized and operated exclusively for nonprofitable purposes, a club otherwise entitled to exemption will not be disqualified because it raises revenue from members through the use of club facilities or in connection with club activities<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>23►<field>fn.fnref="23"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I003T1S"</field>26 C.F.R. &s;§1.501(c)(7)-1(a).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Social and recreational clubs, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I001T7X"</field>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &s;§<trace.deleted/><trace>10:75</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> or by an incidental sale of property.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>24►<field>fn.fnref="24"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I000ZWZ"</field>26 C.F.R. &s;§1.501(c)(7)-1(b).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Social and recreational clubs, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I003T1V"</field>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &s;§<trace.deleted/><trace>10:75</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"</field>On the other hand, a club that opens its social and recreational facilities to the general public on a large enough scale or that solicits public use by advertising may lose its exemption. Where there is no solicitation, the principal factor in determining exempt status is the extent of outside use. If the club earns more than the amount permitted under federal guidelines, a decision as to whether substantially all of its activities are related to its exempt purposes is based on all the facts and circumstances. In such a case, the organization is taxed as a business enterprise and entitled to all the deductions and tax benefits of such enterprise.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>25►<field>fn.fnref="25"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"</field>►<field>cc.ref.id="I001T7V"</field>U.S. v. Fort Worth Club of Fort Worth, Tex., 348 F.2d 891 (5th Cir. 1965).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Social and recreational clubs, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I001T6P"</field>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &s;§<trace.deleted/><trace>10:75</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"</field>Solicitation by advertisement or otherwise for public patronage of the club's facilities is prima facie evidence that the club is engaging in business and is not being operated exclusively for pleasure, recreation, or social purposes.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>26►<field>fn.fnref="26"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I001T6N"</field>26 C.F.R. &s;§1.501(c)(7)-1(b).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"</field>Investment income of exempt organizations not derived from controlled corporations, including all dividends, interest, payments with respect to securities loans, and annuities, royalties, and certain rents, is generally exempt from taxation.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>27►<field>fn.fnref="27"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"</field>See ►<field>st.ref.id="I000ZY9"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§512(b).<f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"</field>Such income is subject to the tax on unrelated business income if derived from controlled corporations. See ►<field>x.ref.id="I003T35"</field>&s;§30:5.<f_break>Research References<f_break>Income, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I001T0Z"</field>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &s;§10:59.<f_break>Dividends, interest, and royalties, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I00103X"</field>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &s;§10:6<trace>8</trace>.<f_break>Other investment income, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I003T8T"</field>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &s;§10:<trace.deleted/><trace>70</trace>.<f_break>Rents, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I006MDP"</field>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &s;§10:7<trace>1</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> However, certain income received by exempt organizations from or on account of debt-financed property is subject to tax on unrelated business income. Tax is imposed on the amount of such income which is the same percentage (but not in excess of 100&percnt;%) of total gross income derived during the taxable year from the property as the average acquisition indebtedness is of the average amount of the adjusted basis.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>28►<field>fn.fnref="28"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I001T0X"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§514(a)(1).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Debt-financed acquisitions, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I00103Z"</field>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &ss;§§10:7<trace>7</trace>, 10:7<trace.deleted/><trace>8</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> Also excluded are all gains on the lapse or termination of options written by the organization in connection with its investment activities to buy or sell securities, except with respect to the cutting of timber.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>29►<field>fn.fnref="29"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I003T8V"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§512(b)(5).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Income, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I001T0U"</field>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &s;§10:59.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"</field>While investment by the exempt organization of its principal and income in realty, personal property, or securities will not ordinarily deprive the organization of its exemption, the exemption may be lost if the investment activities constitute a trade or business.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>30►<field>fn.fnref="30"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"</field>►<field>cc.ref.id="I001042"</field>Randall Foundation, Inc. v. Riddell, 244 F.2d 803 (9th Cir. 1957).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Income, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I001T0S"</field>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &s;§10:59.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"</field>Certain tax-exempt organizations may pool investment funds through a tax-exempt corporation or trust to invest in real estate. The corporation or trust must, among other requirements, have no more than 35 shareholders or beneficiaries, have one class of stock or beneficial interest, and be organized for the exclusive purpose of acquiring property and holding title to, and collecting income from, such property, and remitting the entire amount of income from such property (less expenses) to shareholders or beneficiaries.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>31►<field>fn.fnref="31"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I001T0Q"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§501(c)(25)(A).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> An organization applies for an exemption by submitting a cover letter, indicating that it is applying for an exemption under ►<field>st.ref.id="I001046"</field>Internal Revenue Code Section 501(c)(25), and submitting ►<field>sst.ref.id="I001SZK"</field>Form 1024, providing all information on Schedule A (including the basis for shareholders' or beneficiaries' eligibility).
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"</field>A not-for-profit corporation is exempt from state corporation franchise taxes, except as to any unrelated business tax income of the organization,<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>32►<field>fn.fnref="32"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"</field>As to state and federal taxation of unrelated business taxable income, generally, see ►<field>x.ref.id="I00105C"</field>&s;§30:5.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> if the corporation does not have any stock or shares or other certificates of ownership interests, the corporation is operated on a not-for-profit basis, and no part of the corporation's net earnings inure to the benefit of any officer, director, or member.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>33►<field>fn.fnref="33"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I003TA8"</field>20 NYCRR &s;§<trace>1-2.11(b)(6)</trace>.<f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"</field>See ►<field>st.ref.id="I001SZI"</field>NYTL &s;§209.<f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"</field>Under New York law, not-for-profit corporations are prohibited from having stock or shares or certificates for stock or for shares, though they may issue nontransferable membership certificates or cards to evidence membership. ►<field>st.ref.id="I00105E"</field>N-PCL &s;§501.<f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"</field>Statutory assessment on gross receipts of residential health care facilities was not &ldquo;“franchise tax,&rdquo;” from which charitable organizations were exempt, and thus assessment did not violate state constitutional provision barring repeal of charitable tax exemptions; assessment was not imposed on facilities' net income, and there was no statutory prohibition on imposition of gross receipts tax. ►<field>cc.ref.id="I003TAA"</field>Charles T. Sitrin Health Care Center, Inc. v. State of New York, 195 Misc. 2d 824, 761 N.Y.S.2d 452 (Sup 2003).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> Not-for-profit corporations are also exempt from the New York City franchise tax to the extent their activities do not generate a profit.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>34►<field>fn.fnref="34"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I001STU"</field>20 NYCRR &s;§<trace>1-2.11(b)(6)</trace>; ►<field>cc.ref.id="I0010B2"</field>Pan American Athletic & Social Club, Inc. v. Commissioner of Finance of City of New York, 94 A.D.2d 606, 461 N.Y.S.2d 1017 (1st Dep't 1983).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"</field>Not-for-profit corporations that meet statutory or regulatory requirements also are specifically exempted from having to pay New York State and city sales or use taxes.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>35►<field>fn.fnref="35"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"</field>See ►<field>st.ref.id="I001STS"</field>NYTL &s;§1116(a)(4); ►<field>st.ref.id="I0010B4"</field>20 NYCRR &s;§529.7.<f_break>Research References<f_break>►<field>rc.ref.id="I003TG0"</field>Exemption of charitable or educational organization from sales or use tax, 69 A.L.R.5th 477.<f_break>►<field>rc.ref.id="I006MKW"</field>Exemption of religious organization from sales or use tax, 54 A.L.R.3d 1204.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> The corporation is also exempt from the New York City vault tax,<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>36►<field>fn.fnref="36"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I001STP"</field>New York City tax,<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>37►<field>fn.fnref="37"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I001STN"</field>New York City tax,<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>38►<field>fn.fnref="38"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I001SSI"</field>New York City tax,<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>39►<field>fn.fnref="39"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I0010CE"</field>New York City
