tax.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>42►<field>fn.fnref="42"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I0010CH"</field>NYTL &s;§1230(d).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"</field>Although tax-exempt, most organizations must file an annual information return and are subject to a penalty tax for failure to file.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>43►<field>fn.fnref="43"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I003THD"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§6652. ►<field>st.ref.id="I001SSD"</field>IRS Form 990 is used for this. If the exempt organization is a private foundation (discussed later), the form is 990<trace>-</trace>PF.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> Churches and certain other exempt entities are exempt from this requirement. All exempt organizations must file information returns on business payments of $600 or more, on tax withheld, on cash receipts of $10,000 or more, and on payments of dividends and interest.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>44►<field>fn.fnref="44"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I0010CJ"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &ss;§§6041, 6042, 6050I.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> They must also report dispositions of donated property that occur within two years after receipt of the property.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>45►<field>fn.fnref="45"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I001SMP"</field>26 C.F.R. &s;§1.6050L-1(f)(2). The form is 8282.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
30:3. Qualifying for tax-exempt status-- Obtaining exempt status; federal and state
Research References
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I0010I7"</field>West's Key Number Digest, Internal Revenue &key;4045 et seq.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"</field>As stated earlier, an organization does not generally enjoy an exemption from federal income tax merely because it is not organized and operated for profit. In order to establish its exempt status, every such organization claiming an exemption must file an application form with the <trace.deleted/><trace>appropriate</trace> office<trace> as designated by the Commissioner in guidance published in the Internal Revenue Bulletin, forms, or instructions to the applicable forms</trace>.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>1►<field>fn.fnref="1"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I001SMN"</field>26 C.F.R. &s;§1.501(a)-1<trace.deleted/>(a)(2).<f_break>Research References<f_break>►<field>rc.ref.id="I0010I9"</field>RIA Federal Tax Coordinator 2d &pp;D-4000 et seq.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> When an exempt and unincorporated association is incorporated, a new legal entity is created and a new application for exemption is necessary, even though the new corporation merely continues its previous activities. An organization seeking exemption under ►<field>st.ref.id="I001SMK"</field>Section 501(c)(3) of the Code, which covers most exempt organizations, must apply for exemption within 15 months after organization.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>2►<field>fn.fnref="2"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I001SMI"</field>26 C.F.R. &s;§1.508-1<trace.deleted/>(a)(2)(i).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Application for exempt status, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I0010IE"</field>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &s;§10:57.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"</field>To obtain exemption, a written application must be filed, even where no official forms are provided; oral requests for exemption will not be considered. Official application forms are provided as follows:<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>3►<field>fn.fnref="3"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"</field>Certain organizations do not file an official form. See ►<field>st.ref.id="I001SLC"</field>I.R.S. Pub. 557.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"</field>Form 1023: Religious, charitable, scientific, literary, educational, etc., organizations described in ►<field>st.ref.id="I0010JK"</field>Section 501(c)(3) of the Code;<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>4►<field>fn.fnref="4"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I003TOG"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§501(c)(3).<f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"</field>See also ►<field>cc.ref.id="I001SLA"</field>National Paralegal Inst. Coalition v. C.I.R., T.C. Memo. 2005-293, T.C.M. (RIA) P 2005-293 (2005), where the Service reviews procedural aspects of filing ►<field>sst.ref.id="I0010JM"</field>Form 1023.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> public safety testing; fostering certain amateur sports competition; prevention of cruelty to children or animals; educational organizations' cooperative service organizations; and cooperative hospital service organizations.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"</field>Form 1024: Used by title holding companies,<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>5►<field>fn.fnref="5"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I003TOI"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§501(c)(2).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> civic leagues, social welfare organizations, and local associations of employees;<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>6►<field>fn.fnref="6"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I001KQB"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§501(c)(4).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> labor, agricultural or horticultural organizations;<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>7►<field>fn.fnref="7"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I0018EL"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§501(c)(5).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> business leagues or chambers of commerce;<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>8►<field>fn.fnref="8"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I001KQ8"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§501(c)(6).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> social clubs;<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>9►<field>fn.fnref="9"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I0018EO"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§501(c)(7).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Social and recreational clubs, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I0041JK"</field>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &s;§<trace.deleted/><trace>10:75</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> fraternal societies, orders, or associations;<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>10►<field>fn.fnref="10"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I001KQ6"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§501(c)(8) or (10).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> voluntary employees' beneficiaries associations;<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>11►<field>fn.fnref="11"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I0041JM"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§501(c)(9).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Voluntary Employee Benefit Associations (VEBAs), ►<field>rc.ref.id="I001KQ3"</field>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &s;§10:7<trace>6</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> benevolent life insurance associations; mutual ditch or irrigation companies; mutual or cooperative telephone companies or like organizations;<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>12►<field>fn.fnref="12"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I001KOY"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§501(c)(12).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> cemetery companies;<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>13►<field>fn.fnref="13"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I001KOV"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§501(c)(13).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> mutual insurance companies or associations other than life;<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>14►<field>fn.fnref="14"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I0018G1"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§501(c)(15).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> supplemental unemployment benefit trusts;<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>15►<field>fn.fnref="15"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I001KOT"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§501(c)(17).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> and by veterans' organizations.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>16►<field>fn.fnref="16"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I0018G3"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§501(c)(19).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"</field>The official forms require detailed information peculiar to the type of organization seeking exemption. Where no official application form is provided, consult the local district director for the information to be submitted and the procedure to be followed in establishing the exemption.
Practice Tip:
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"</field>Before preparing the application, obtain ►<field>st.ref.id="I001KJ5"</field>I.R.S. Pub. 557, &ldquo;“Tax-Exempt Status for Your Organization.&rdquo;” The publication sets out the requirements for organizing and operating exempt organizations. The detailed qualifications for each type of exempt organization are discussed, as are the filing requirements.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"</field>A power of attorney must be filed if the organization applying for the exemption expects to be represented in person or by correspondence by an agent or attorney. It is now possible to file the form electronically. The power must specifically authorize the agent or attorney to represent the organization before the Internal Revenue Service. ►<field>st.ref.id="I0018LR"</field>IRS Form 2848, &ldquo;“Power of Attorney and Declaration of Representative,&rdquo;” may be used for this purpose.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>17►<field>fn.fnref="17"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I001KJ3"</field>I.R.S. Pub. 557.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"</field>Conformed copies of each of the following must accompany the application:<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>18►<field>fn.fnref="18"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I0018LT"</field>I.R.S. Pub. 557. Do not send original documents as the documents are retained in the IRS files and cannot be returned.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"</field>a. Articles or Certificate of Incorporation or trust instrument or other document setting forth the organization's authorized powers and purposes and any amendment of such document changing the name of the organization;
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"</field>b. Bylaws or other similar code of regulations;
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"</field>c. Financial statements showing receipts and expenditures for the current year and the three immediate prior years (or the years the organization was in existence, if less than four years). If the current year is less than a full year or if operations have not yet begun, a proposed budget for two full accounting periods and a current statement of assets and liabilities will be acceptable. Bank statements, ledger sheets, and profit and loss or similar operating statements that do not show all receipts and expenditures classified are not acceptable for this purpose;
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"</field>d. A statement of the proposed activities of the organization, if required by the application form; and
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"</field>e. Any additional information necessary to clarify the nature of the organization. This may consist of copies of advertising by the organization, magazines published by it, and written material used for the purpose of expressing views on proposed legislation.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"</field>All attachments to the application should show the organization's name, address, and Employer Identification Number (EIN); the date; and a heading identifying the document and that it is an attachment to the exemption application.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>19►<field>fn.fnref="19"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I001KIY"</field>I.R.S. Pub. 557.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"</field>In most cases, determination letters or rulings will be issued in advance of operation, provided the organization can describe its proposed operations in sufficient detail to convince the IRS that they will be clearly exempt under the law. A user fee must be paid for an exempt organization determination letter request. In this connection, ►<field>st.ref.id="I0018LY"</field>IRS Form 8718 must be attached to the determination letter application.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"</field>A ruling of tax exemption may be retroactively revoked where a social club misrepresents or omits material facts from its exemption application, especially where they concern the financial status of the club.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>20►<field>fn.fnref="20"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"</field>►<field>cc.ref.id="I001KHT"</field>Colombo Club, Inc. v. Commissioner of Internal Revenue, 54 T.C. 100, 1970 WL 2397 (1970), decision aff'd, 447 F.2d 1406 (9th Cir. 1971).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"</field>Once an organization has obtained its tax-exempt status at the federal level, it must also make application for such status in New York. To obtain an exemption, the corporation must file Form CT-247 and all IRS documents granting or denying an exemption with the Department of Taxation and Finance. The IRS determination is generally followed.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>21►<field>fn.fnref="21"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I001KHQ"</field>20 NYCRR &s;§<trace>1-2.11(b)(6)</trace><trace.deleted/><f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
30:4. Qualifying for tax-exempt status-- Revocation or modification of exempt status; related procedures
Research References
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I0018N6"</field>West's Key Number Digest, Internal Revenue &key;4045 et seq.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|4|30:4"</field>Federal rulings and determination letters granting exemption may be revoked or modified for such causes as a change in the law or regulations; substantial changes in the organization's character, purposes, or methods of operation;<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>1►<field>fn.fnref="1"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|4|30:4"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I001KC3"</field>26 C.F.R. &s;§1.501(a)-1<trace.deleted/>(a)(2).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> the omission or misstatement by the organization of a material fact; engaging in a prohibited transaction entered into for the purpose of diverting the organization's corpus or income from its exempt purpose; and failure to file an annual information return. Rulings and determination letters granting exemption may be revoked retroactively and deficiencies and penalties may be claimed for open years. However, the Internal Revenue Service has generally limited retroactive revocation to cases where a material fact was omitted or misstated, the organization operated in a manner materially different from that represented, or the organization engaged in a prohibited transaction.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>2►<field>fn.fnref="2"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|4|30:4"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I0018ST"</field>26 C.F.R. &s;§601.201(n)(6).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|4|30:4"</field>An organization may obtain an administrative review of the denial of its exemption application or of a proposed revocation or modification of its exemption by filing a timely protest. If the organization is unsuccessful and a deficiency is proposed, the organization may seek administrative and judicial review. An organization cannot enjoin an IRS revocation of its exemption while its status is being litigated; its proper remedy is to sue for refund of taxes.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|4|30:4"</field>The revocation will ordinarily take effect no later than the time at which the organization received written notice that its exemption ruling or determination letter might be revoked.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>3►<field>fn.fnref="3"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|4|30:4"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I001KC0"</field>26 C.F.R. &s;§601.201(n)(6)(i).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|4|30:4"</field>Formerly, if an exempt organization violated the rules prohibiting private benefit from its operations, the Service's only option as a sanction was to revoke the entity's exempt status. However, the Service now is allowed the imposition of so-called &ldquo;“intermediate&rdquo;” sanctions, pursuant to which the Service can, under Section 4958, impose monetary penalties in the form of excise taxes.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>4►<field>fn.fnref="4"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|4|30:4"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I001KBY"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§4958. See ►<field>x.ref.id="I0018SY"</field>&ss;§§31:1 et seq.<f_break>Research References<f_break>Excise taxes on excess benefit transactions, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I001KBV"</field>RIA Federal Tax Coordinator 2d &pp;D-6650 et seq.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
30:5. Taxation of unrelated business income
Research References
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I0018T1"</field>West's Key Number Digest, Internal Revenue &key;4045 et seq.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|5|30:5"</field>A tax-exempt corporation is taxed on it unrelated business income; only income from its exempt function is nontaxable.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>1►<field>fn.fnref="1"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|5|30:5"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I001KAQ"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§511(a)(1).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Taxation of unrelated business income, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I0018U6"</field>RIA Federal Tax Coordinator 2d &pp;D-6800 et seq.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> Exempt income is of two kinds. First is investment income: interest, dividends, royalties, real estate rentals.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>2►<field>fn.fnref="2"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|5|30:5"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I0041Z2"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§512. Rentals from personal property are not exempt unless they are part of a real estate rental. ►<field>st.ref.id="I001KAO"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§512(b)(3).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> Second are fees and other income from the operation of the exempt function of the organization. Taxable business income is therefore made up of income from any operations that are not the exempt business of the organization. Any business in which goods are sold or services are rendered is an unrelated business.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>3►<field>fn.fnref="3"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|5|30:5"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I0018U8"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§513(c). The share of gross income of a publicly traded partnership is also unrelated business income. ►<field>st.ref.id="I0041Z4"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§512(c).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Taxation of unrelated business income, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I001KAL"</field>RIA Federal Tax Coordinator 2d &pp;D-6800 et seq.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> However, unrelated business income is significantly different for clubs than for other exempt organizations.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>4►<field>fn.fnref="4"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|5|30:5"</field>A special definition is provided by ►<field>st.ref.id="I0018UB"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§512(a)(3)(A).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> For a club, taxable income includes all income other than income from members. Other exempt organizations are taxed on gross income from an unrelated trade or business. After making certain adjustments in the way deductions are taken, the club's income is taxed at corporate rates.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>5►<field>fn.fnref="5"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|5|30:5"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I001K4Y"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§511(a)(1).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Computing unrelated business income tax, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I0018ZY"</field>RIA Federal Tax Coordinator 2d &pp;D-6900 et seq.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|5|30:5"</field>Three kinds of businesses are exempt from taxation as unrelated business income:<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>6►<field>fn.fnref="6"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|5|30:5"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I001K4V"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§513(a).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|5|30:5"</field>1. Businesses where all the work is done by volunteers without pay;
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|5|30:5"</field>2. Businesses carried on primarily for the convenience of patients or employees; and
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|5|30:5"</field>3. Businesses that sell merchandise received as a donation.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|5|30:5"</field>In addition, certain public entertainment activities and certain convention and trade show activities do not result in taxable income.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>7►<field>fn.fnref="7"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|5|30:5"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I001K4T"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§513(d).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Qualified public entertainment activities, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I001903"</field>RIA Federal Tax Coordinator 2d &p;D-6840.<f_break>Convention and trade show exception to unrelated trade or business rules for tax exempt organizations, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I001K4Q"</field>RIA Federal Tax Coordinator 2d &p;D-6841.<f_break>Trade shows and conventions, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I001906"</field>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &s;§10:61.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|5|30:5"</field>Income earned from debt-financed property owned by an exempt organization is also unrelated business income.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>8►<field>fn.fnref="8"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|5|30:5"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I004252"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§512(b).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Debt-financed income, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I001K3L"</field>RIA Federal Tax Coordinator 2d &pp;D-7000 et seq.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> This rule applies no matter what form the income may take. The amount taxed is based on the ratio of the average acquisition debt on the property to the adjusted basis of the property.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>9►<field>fn.fnref="9"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|5|30:5"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I00191B"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§514(c)(7).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Debt/basis gross income percentage for debt-financed property, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I004267"</field>RIA Federal Tax Coordinator 2d &p;D-7002.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> This ratio is applied to the gross income from the property to calculate the amount of taxable income. The same percentage of expenses of the property is then deducted to determine net income.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>10►<field>fn.fnref="10"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|5|30:5"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I001K3J"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§514(a)(1).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> The most obvious examples of debt-financed property are the acquisition of property subject to a mortgage and property purchased on an installment basis.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>11►<field>fn.fnref="11"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|5|30:5"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I00191D"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§514(b)(1)(A).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|5|30:5"</field>Several kinds of acquisitions are exempt from the debt-financed property rule.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>12►<field>fn.fnref="12"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|5|30:5"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I004269"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§514(c).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Property excluded from debt-financed property under unrelated business income tax rules, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I001JXV"</field>RIA Federal Tax Coordinator 2d &pp;D-7012 to D-7019.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> It does not apply to property donated to the organization as a gift.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>13►<field>fn.fnref="13"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|5|30:5"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I001971"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§514(c)(2)(B).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Property excluded from debt-financed property under unrelated business income tax rules, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I001JXT"</field>RIA Federal Tax Coordinator 2d &pp;D-7012 to D-7019.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> It also does not apply to property acquired for use in the exempt function of the organization, land acquired near the organization's other property, and certain property used for research. Furthermore, acquisition indebtedness does not include liabilities incurred by an employees' pension plan or by an educational institution to acquire or improve real property.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>14►<field>fn.fnref="14"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|5|30:5"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I001JXQ"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§514(c)(9).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Property excluded from debt-financed property under unrelated business income tax rules, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I001976"</field>RIA Federal Tax Coordinator 2d &pp;D-7012 to D-7019.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> Various requirements attach in order for these exemptions to apply.
30:6. Internet activities taxable as unrelated business income
Research References
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I0042C2"</field>West's Key Number Digest, Internal Revenue &key;4045 et seq.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|6|30:6"</field>Activities that promote demand for industry products and services, like other advertising activities, generally would constitute a &ldquo;“trade or business&rdquo;” if carried on for the production of income. A narrow exception is provide as to what constitutes an &ldquo;“unrelated trade or business.&rdquo;”<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>1►<field>fn.fnref="1"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|6|30:6"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I001JXO"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§513(d).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Internet activities taxable as unrelated business income, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I001978"</field>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &s;§10:6<trace>3</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> For income received by a trade association or other nonprofit organization at its convention or trade show from renting display space may constitute unrelated business taxable income if selling by exhibitors is permitted or tolerated at the show.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|6|30:6"</field>The activities described in ►<field>st.ref.id="I001JWI"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§513(d)(3) are specifically excepted from the definition of an unrelated trade or business because they are conducted by a qualifying organization in furtherance of its exempt purposes and in connection with a convention, annual meeting, or trade show. The terms &ldquo;“convention, annual meeting, or trade show&rdquo;” refer to a specific event at which individuals representing a particular industry and members of the general public gather in person at one location during a certain period of time. Not only must the activities be conducted at a convention, annual meeting, or trade show, but the character of the exhibits and the extent of the industry products displayed at the show must be designed to stimulate interest in, and demand for, the products and services of the industry in general or to educate persons in attendance regarding new developments or products and services related to the exempt activities of the organization. It is the nature of the activities and their connection to a specific convention, annual meeting, or trade show that distinguishes qualified convention and trade show activity.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>2►<field>fn.fnref="2"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|6|30:6"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I00198E"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§513(d).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> To clarify how Internet activities fit within the exception under ►<field>st.ref.id="I0042DA"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§513(d)(3), the Service has provide guidance.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>3►<field>fn.fnref="3"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|6|30:6"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I001JWG"</field>Rev. Rul. 2004-112, 2004-51 I.R.B. 985.<f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|6|30:6"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I00198G"</field>PLR 200713024, 2007 WL 950361 where the Services examines factual circumstances with an analysis based on ►<field>st.ref.id="I0042DC"</field>Rev. Rul. 2004-112, 2004-51 I.R.B. 985.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|6|30:6"</field>In the first situation, a trade association is a &ldquo;“qualifying organization&rdquo;”<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>4►<field>fn.fnref="4"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|6|30:6"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I001JWD"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§513(d)(3)(C).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> because it is an organization described in ►<field>st.ref.id="I001JQQ"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§501(c)(3), (4), or (5) and regularly conducts as one of its substantial exempt purposes a show which stimulates interest in, and demand for, the products of a particular industry or segment of such industry or which educates persons in attendance regarding new developments or products and services related to the exempt activities of the organization. The trade association's semi-annual trade shows include conferences, seminars, and a wide variety of exhibits sponsored by members and suppliers with information useful to those in its industry and take place during a limited time, at one physical location, where its members, suppliers, and potential customers meet together in person and interact face-to-face. Thus, each of its semi-annual trade shows is a &ldquo;“show&rdquo;” within the meaning of ►<field>st.ref.id="I006VNY"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§513(d)(3).
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|6|30:6"</field>The activities conducted on the premises of each of the trade association's semi-annual trade shows and on the special supplementary section of its Internet website during the period that coincides with each semi-annual trade show are of a kind traditionally conducted at trade shows<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>5►<field>fn.fnref="5"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|6|30:6"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I009OSU"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§513(d)(3)(A).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> because the activities are designed to attract to the show persons in its industry and members of the public to view industry products, to stimulate interest in and demand for such products, and to educate persons in the industry about new products and services. Therefore, these activities are convention and trade show activity.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>6►<field>fn.fnref="6"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|6|30:6"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I001JQO"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§513(d).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|6|30:6"</field>The supplementary section is no more than ancillary to the trade show. The content of the supplementary section serves to augment and enhance each semi-annual trade show by making available in an alternative medium the same information available at the show. The supplementary section of its Internet website is available to its members and the interested public during essentially the same limited time period that each semi-annual trade show is in operation. Although the supplementary section is available for a slightly longer period than the trade show itself, the additional time is reasonably brief and serves to allow for previewing the show before attending or following up on information gathered at the show. Thus, the supplementary section is merely an extension of each semi-annual trade show.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>7►<field>fn.fnref="7"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|6|30:6"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I0019E8"</field>Rev. Rul. 2004-112, 2004-51 I.R.B. 985.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|6|30:6"</field>In the second situation, a trade association's operation of a website for a two-week period under the circumstances described is not &ldquo;“qualified convention and trade-show activity&rdquo;”<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>8►<field>fn.fnref="8"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|6|30:6"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I001JQL"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§513(d)(3)(B).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> because its Internet activities are not carried out in conjunction with any international, national, regional, state, or local convention, annual meeting, or show conducted by the trade association. The trade association's website is not itself a convention, annual meeting, or trade show within the meaning of ►<field>st.ref.id="I0019EB"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§513(d)(3) because the website is not a specific event at which its members, suppliers, and potential customers gather in person at one physical location during a certain period of time and interact face to face.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|6|30:6"</field>Moreover, its Internet activities do not coincide with, nor do they augment and enhance, any such specific event conducted by the trade association for one of the purposes described in ►<field>st.ref.id="I0042J7"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§513(d)(3)(B). Therefore, because the trade association's website is not qualified convention and trade show activity, the operation of the website, even for a relatively short period of time, is not excepted from the definition of an unrelated trade or business under ►<field>st.ref.id="I001JQJ"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§513(d)(1).<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>9►<field>fn.fnref="9"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|6|30:6"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I0019ED"</field>Rev. Rul. 2004-112, 2004-51 I.R.B. 985.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
30:7. Deductibility of club expenses
Research References
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I001JPD"</field>West's Key Number Digest, Internal Revenue &key;3314.1
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I0019FJ"</field>West's Key Number Digest, Internal Revenue &key;3331
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I001JPB"</field>West's Key Number Digest, Internal Revenue &key;3338 to 3346
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I0019FL"</field>West's Key Number Digest, Internal Revenue &key;3364
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|7|30:7"</field>Dues, fees, assessments, and similar payments made to a social club are not deductible whether the club is used for personal<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>1►<field>fn.fnref="1"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|7|30:7"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I0042KH"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§262(a).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Nondeductibility of club dues and fees, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I006VPD"</field>RIA Federal Tax Coordinator 2d &pp;L-2180 to L-2183.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> or for business purposes.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>2►<field>fn.fnref="2"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|7|30:7"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I000FUB"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§274(a)(3).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Nondeductibility of club dues and fees, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I002DAL"</field>RIA Federal Tax Coordinator 2d &pp;L-2180 to L-2183.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> The denial of deductibility covers any club organized for business, pleasure, recreation, or other social purpose.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|7|30:7"</field>Donations to a club are not deductible as charitable contributions unless the club can qualify as being devoted to an exempt purpose for which a deduction is allowed.
30:8. Tax returns
Research References
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I000FU9"</field>West's Key Number Digest, Internal Revenue &key;4045 et seq.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|8|30:8"</field>With certain exceptions,<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>1►<field>fn.fnref="1"</field><f_break>Research References<f_break>Exemptions from exempt organization annual information return filing requirements, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I002DAN"</field>RIA Federal Tax Coordinator 2d &p;S-2813.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> an exempt organization must file an annual federal information return on or before the fifteenth day of the fifth <trace.deleted/>month following the close of the period for which the return is required to be filed.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>2►<field>fn.fnref="2"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|8|30:8"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I0056FJ"</field>26 C.F.R. &s;§1.6033-2(e).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Information returns of exempt organizations, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I000FU6"</field>RIA Federal Tax Coordinator 2d &pp;S-2800 et seq.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> However, if an organization has gross receipts that are normally not more than $5,000 in each taxable year, a federal information return is not required to be filed.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>3►<field>fn.fnref="3"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|8|30:8"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I002DAQ"</field>26 C.F.R. &s;§1.6033-2(g)(1)(iii).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Exemption from requirement to file exempt organization return for organizations with not more than $5,000 of gross receipts, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I0056FM"</field>RIA Federal Tax Coordinator 2d &p;S-2820.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> There is also a discretionary exception from filing for organizations, other than private foundations, with gross receipts of not more than $50,000.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>4►<field>fn.fnref="4"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|8|30:8"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I000FU4"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§6033(a)(3)(B); ►<field>st.ref.id="I000FU2"</field>Rev. Proc. 2011-15, 2011-3 I.R.B. 322.<f_break>Research References<f_break>Exemption from requirement to file information return for exempt organizations with gross receipts of not more than $50,000, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I002DAU"</field>RIA Federal Tax Coordinator 2d &p;S-282<trace>0</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> In general, the returns require the disclosure of information concerning the income and expenditures of the organization during the taxable year, and such other information as may be required by the applicable return form.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>5►<field>fn.fnref="5"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|8|30:8"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I0056FQ"</field>26 C.F.R. &s;§1.6033-2(a)(1).<f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|8|30:8"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I000FSW"</field>IRS Form 990 is the principal federal information return of exempt organizations (except private foundations), and it must be used unless the organization is required to file a special 990 Form. See ►<field>st.ref.id="I002DC0"</field>26 C.F.R. &s;§1.6033-2(a)(2)(i).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Information return requirement for certain exempt organizations, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I0056GW"</field>RIA Federal Tax Coordinator 2d &p;S-2801.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> For example, ►<field>st.ref.id="I007ZLS"</field>IRS Form 990-T is used by otherwise exempt organizations that have $1000 or more of unrelated business gross income.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>6►<field>fn.fnref="6"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|8|30:8"</field>See ►<field>x.ref.id="I000FSU"</field>&s;§30:5.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> This, too, is really an income tax return because the unrelated business income is taxed on ►<field>st.ref.id="I002DC2"</field>IRS Form 990-T. If an organization has gross receipts that are normally not more than $5000 in each taxable year, a federal return is not required to be filed.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>7►<field>fn.fnref="7"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|8|30:8"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I0056GY"</field>26 C.F.R. &s;§1.6033-2(g)(1)(iii).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> Failure to file returns when due may result in penalties.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>8►<field>fn.fnref="8"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|8|30:8"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I007ZLU"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§6652.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|8|30:8"</field>An organization claiming exemption before the establishment of its exempt status must indicate that the return is being filed in the belief that the organization is exempt but that the IRS has not yet recognized such exemption.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>9►<field>fn.fnref="9"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|8|30:8"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I000FN6"</field>26 C.F.R. &s;§1.6033-2(c).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Organization claiming exempt status before recognition of exempt status, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I002DHQ"</field>RIA Federal Tax Coordinator 2d &p;S-2803.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> If, because of a change in activity or method of operation, an organization loses its tax-exempt status, it must file a corporate income tax return showing the amount of tax due. The transition from exempt to nonexempt status has no effect on the organization's accounting period. If the day on which the organization becomes a taxable entity does not coincide with the first day of its accounting year (whether calendar year or fiscal year), the organization must file a return for a short taxable year that ends with its accounting period year.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>10►<field>fn.fnref="10"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|8|30:8"</field>►<field>cc.ref.id="I000FN4"</field>Royal Highlanders v. C. I. R., 1 T.C. 184, 1942 WL 324 (T.C. 1942), decision rev'd on other grounds, 138 F.2d 240 (C.C.A. 8th Cir. 1943).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
Practice Tip:
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|8|30:8"</field>If there is a change in activity or method of operation, the organization must also inform the state Department of Taxation and Finance of such change.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|8|30:8"</field>The organization may not prorate its income over the 12 months of its accounting year and report as taxable income only the portion applicable to the period during which it was not exempt.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>11►<field>fn.fnref="11"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|8|30:8"</field>►<field>cc.ref.id="I000FN1"</field>Economy Sav. and Loan Co. v. C. I. R., 5 T.C. 543, 1945 WL 43 (T.C. 1945), aff'd in part, 158 F.2d 472 (C.C.A. 6th Cir. 1946) and acq. withdrawn, nonacq., 1959-2 C.B. 3, 1959 WL 65592 (1959).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> After the change in status, income that is derived from contracts issued or assets held while the organization was tax exempt must be included in the taxable income.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>12►<field>fn.fnref="12"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|8|30:8"</field>►<field>cc.ref.id="I000FMZ"</field>Royal Highlanders v. C. I. R., 1 T.C. 184, 1942 WL 324 (T.C. 1942), decision rev'd on other grounds, 138 F.2d 240 (C.C.A. 8th Cir. 1943).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> A separate federal return concerning unrelated business income must be filed by an exempt organization that has gross income, included in computing unrelated business taxable income for the taxable year, of $1000 or more. The federal return is filed on ►<field>st.ref.id="I0056MT"</field>IRS Form 990-T. The filing of a return of unrelated business income does not relieve the organization of the duty to file other required returns.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>13►<field>fn.fnref="13"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|8|30:8"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I007ZRP"</field>26 C.F.R. &s;§1.6012-2(e).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Computing unrelated business income tax, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I000FLT"</field>RIA Federal Tax Coordinator 2d &pp;D-6900 et seq.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|8|30:8"</field>The Code requires an exempt organization to allow public inspection of its application for exemption and its three most recent annual information returns. The exempt organization must furnish copies of these documents on request. The copies must be provided without charge, other than for the reasonable costs of copying and mailing.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>14►<field>fn.fnref="14"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|8|30:8"</field>See ►<field>st.ref.id="I002DJ3"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§6104(d); ►<field>st.ref.id="I0056NZ"</field>26 C.F.R. &s;§301.6104(d)-1.<f_break>Research References<f_break>Application disclosure requirements, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I000FLR"</field>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &s;§10:58.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
30:9. Checklist-- Matters to be considered when completing an application for recognition of tax exemption

NFP
CHK
FCV
FTR
EBL
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|9|30:9"</field>1. Complete all parts of application form (►<field>sst.ref.id="I002DJ5"</field>IRS Form 1023 or ►<field>sst.ref.id="I000FLP"</field>IRS Form 1024) that apply to the organization.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|9|30:9"</field>2. Supply the organization's employer identification number.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|9|30:9"</field>a. If the organization has a number, write it in the space provided.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|9|30:9"</field>b. If the organization is newly formed and does not have a number, attach completed Form SS-4 if the organization has not previously applied.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|9|30:9"</field>3. Enclose complete statement of support, revenue, and expenses and the balance sheet.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|9|30:9"</field>a. Financial statements required for current year (including the period up to within 60 days of date application is filed) and each of the immediately preceding three years (or the years the organization has existed, if less than four).
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|9|30:9"</field>b. Provide a detailed breakdown of support, revenue, and expenses; do not substitute lump sums.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|9|30:9"</field>c. If organization has been in existence less than one year, proposed budgets for two years must be submitted, showing the amounts and types of receipts and expenditures anticipated.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|9|30:9"</field>4. Enclose a conformed copy of the complete organizing instrument.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|9|30:9"</field>a. An organizing instrument means:
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|9|30:9"</field>(1) the certificate of incorporation signed by the directors and accepted by an appropriate government official;
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|9|30:9"</field>(2) the constitution or articles of association (signed);
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|9|30:9"</field>(3) a trust instrument.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|9|30:9"</field>b. A conformed copy is one that agrees with the original and all amendments to the original.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|9|30:9"</field>c. If the organization is a corporation (or an unincorporated organization with bylaws), a copy of the bylaws must also be enclosed.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|9|30:9"</field>d. If filing an ►<field>sst.ref.id="I000FFZ"</field>IRS Form 1023, the organizing instrument, either expressly or by operation of state law, must limit the organization's activities to those permitted under ►<field>st.ref.id="I002DOX"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§501(c)(3) and must provide for a proper distribution of net assets upon dissolution.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|9|30:9"</field>5. Signatures by:
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|9|30:9"</field>a. An officer who is authorized to sign; or
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|9|30:9"</field>b. A person authorized by a power of attorney, in which case the power of attorney must be submitted as well.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|9|30:9"</field>6. Provide a telephone number of a person available during business hours to provide additional information, if needed by the IRS.

Research References
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I000FFW"</field>West's Key Number Digest, Internal Revenue &key;4045 et seq.

Drafter's Note 
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|17|30:17"</field>The above form<trace>, revised in 2023,</trace> <trace.deleted/>is available from the Internal Revenue Service, ►<field>url.ref.id="I000F1M"</field><url>http://www.irs.gov</url><trace>, and is provided here for illustrative purposes</trace>.
