<trace.deleted/>
II. Unincorporated Associations
A. General Considerations
1. Introduction
30:18. Definition; general background
Research References
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I000F0H"</field><trace.deleted/><trace>West’s Key Number Digest, Associations &key;101 et seq.</trace>
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I002E4F"</field><trace.deleted/>
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I00579B"</field><trace.deleted/>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|18|30:18"</field>An unincorporated association is an organization consisting of a body of persons united without a charter for the prosecution of a common enterprise. <footnote><footnote.body><f_break>1►<field>fn.fnref="1"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|18|30:18"</field>►<field>cc.ref.id="I000F0E"</field>Heifetz v. Rockaway Point Volunteer Fire Dept., 124 N.Y.S.2d 257 (Sup 1953), order aff'd, 282 A.D. 1062, 126 N.Y.S.2d 604 (2d Dep't 1953).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> An organization may be deemed to be an association as that term is used in the law, although it bears the name of a &ldquo;“society,&rdquo;” &ldquo;“league,&rdquo;” &ldquo;“board,&rdquo;” &ldquo;“union,&rdquo;” &ldquo;“foundation,&rdquo;” &ldquo;“syndicate,&rdquo;” or the like.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>2►<field>fn.fnref="2"</field><f_break>Research References<f_break>Definition of associations, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I00579E"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &s;§1.<f_break>Definition of associations, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I0080EA"</field>Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &ss;§§1 to 3.<f_break>►<field>rc.ref.id="I000EUR"</field>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &ss;§§10:53 et seq.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|18|30:18"</field>The term &ldquo;“club&rdquo;” includes bodies formed by the incorporation or association of persons for social purposes or for any common purpose other than pecuniary profit or benefit, and not of specifically educational, charitable, or religious nature. The term &ldquo;“association&rdquo;” is properly applied to an unincorporated society or body of individuals, formed for social, political, moral, religious, benevolent, protective, or mutual purposes; to promote some public, scientific, or educational objective; or to facilitate business and not for purposes of trade or direct pecuniary profit.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|18|30:18"</field>The rights and liabilities of an organization vary according to its form and substantive nature and do not depend on the title or name applied to it. Unincorporated associations include diverse types of organizations serving widely disparate purposes and goals. They may be not-for-profit organizations or business associations organized for profit, such as partnerships or joint ventures.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>3►<field>fn.fnref="3"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|18|30:18"</field>For forms relating to business partnerships, see <trace.deleted/>►<field>x.ref.id="I000EUO"</field>&ss;§§18:1 et seq.<f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|18|30:18"</field>For forms relating to joint ventures, see <trace.deleted/>►<field>x.ref.id="I002EA8"</field>&ss;§§19:1 et seq.<f_break>Research References<f_break>Nature of associations and clubs, generally, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I0057F4"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &ss;§§1 et seq.<f_break>Nature and kinds of associations and clubs, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I0080K0"</field>Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &ss;§§1, 2.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> A voluntary, unincorporated membership association as such is neither a partnership nor a corporation.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>4►<field>fn.fnref="4"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|18|30:18"</field>►<field>cc.ref.id="I000EUM"</field>Martin v. Curran, 303 N.Y. 276, 101 N.E.2d 683 (1951); ►<field>cc.ref.id="I002EAA"</field>Heifetz v. Rockaway Point Volunteer Fire Dept., 124 N.Y.S.2d 257 (Sup 1953), order aff'd, 282 A.D. 1062, 126 N.Y.S.2d 604 (2d Dep't 1953).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Characteristics of associations, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I0080K2"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &s;§3.<f_break>Associations, compared to, and distinguished from, partnerships and corporations, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I00ATOY"</field>Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &s;§1.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> However, for the express purpose of the provision of the General Association Law permitting actions against associations, any partnership or other company of persons having a <trace.deleted/>resident or treasurer is deemed to be an association.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>5►<field>fn.fnref="5"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|18|30:18"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I000EUJ"</field>Gen. Ass'ns Law &s;§13.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|18|30:18"</field>Unincorporated associations are not regarded as legal entities because they are not artificial persons and have no existence separate and apart from their members. <footnote><footnote.body><f_break>6►<field>fn.fnref="6"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|18|30:18"</field>►<field>cc.ref.id="I02MVZN"</field>Chinuch v. Congregation Lubavitch, Inc., 82 Misc. 3d 29, 204 N.Y.S.3d 380 (App. Term 2024).<f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|18|30:18"</field>►<field>cc.ref.id="I002EAD"</field>Barrett v. New York Republican State Committee, 213 A.D.2d 989, 625 N.Y.S.2d 769 (4th Dep't 1995); ►<field>cc.ref.id="I0057F9"</field>L & L Associates Holding Corp. v. Charity United Baptist Church, 34 Misc. 3d 355, 935 N.Y.S.2d 450 (Dist. Ct. 2011).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> An association is generally formed by the voluntary action of a number of individuals in associating themselves together under a common name for the accomplishment of some lawful purpose. Its organization, like corporations, does not usually depend upon compliance with any statutory provisions, although such associations may be subject to legislative control.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>7►<field>fn.fnref="7"</field><f_break>Research References<f_break>Unincorporated associations, generally, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I0080K5"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &s;§5.<f_break>Unincorporated associations, generally, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I000ETE"</field>Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &s;§1.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|18|30:18"</field>The contract of association, the constitution, or the bylaws determine the purpose for which the association is formed. There is no restriction on the power of an unincorporated association to prescribe reasonable rules in order to accomplish its purposes, as long as such rules do not violate law or public policy.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>8►<field>fn.fnref="8"</field><f_break>Research References<f_break>Constitution, bylaws, and regulations, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I002EBI"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &ss;§§<trace.deleted/><trace>4 to 8</trace>.<f_break>Constitution, bylaws, and regulations, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I000ETC"</field>Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &ss;§§5, 6.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
30:19. Legal status of unincorporated association
Research References
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I002EBK"</field><trace.deleted/><trace>West’s Key Number Digest, Associations &key;101 et seq.</trace>
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I000ET9"</field><trace.deleted/>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|19|30:19"</field>Although an unincorporated association is not a legal entity,<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>1►<field>fn.fnref="1"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|19|30:19"</field>►<field>cc.ref.id="I002EBN"</field>Martin v. Curran, 303 N.Y. 276, 101 N.E.2d 683 (1951); ►<field>cc.ref.id="I0057GJ"</field>Gillette v. Allen, 269 A.D. 441, 56 N.Y.S.2d 307 (4th Dep't 1945); ►<field>cc.ref.id="I0080LF"</field>Saxer v. Democratic County Committee of Erie County, 161 Misc. 35, 291 N.Y.S. 18 (Sup 1936); ►<field>cc.ref.id="I00ATQB"</field>Meinhart v. Contresta, 194 N.Y.S. 593 (Sup 1922).<f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|19|30:19"</field>Under the New York Uniform Commercial Code, a &ldquo;“person&rdquo;” includes an individual or an association and an &ldquo;“organization&rdquo;” means a person other than an individual. ►<field>st.ref.id="I000ENM"</field>NYUCC &ss;§§1-201<trace>(b)</trace>(25), 1-201<trace>(b)</trace>(27).<f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|19|30:19"</field>An instrument is payable to order when made payable to an unincorporated association, in which case it is payable to the association and may be indorsed or transferred by any person authorized to do so. See ►<field>st.ref.id="I0057M6"</field>NYUCC &s;§3-110(1)(g). An order otherwise unconditional is not made conditional by the fact that it is limited to payment out of the entire assets of an unincorporated association by or on behalf of which the instrument is issued. See ►<field>st.ref.id="I0080R2"</field>NYUCC &s;§3-105(1)(h).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Characteristics of associations, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I00ATVY"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &s;§3.<f_break>Associations, compared to, and distinguished from, partnerships and corporations, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I000ENJ"</field>Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &s;§1.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> an action or a special proceeding may be maintained by or against the <trace.deleted/>resident or treasurer of such an association.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>2►<field>fn.fnref="2"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|19|30:19"</field>See ►<field>st.ref.id="I002EHD"</field>Gen. Ass'ns Law &ss;§§12, 13.<f_break><trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><f_break>Research References<f_break>►<field>rc.ref.id="I0080R5"</field>Liability of hotel, motel, resort, or private membership club or association operating swimming pool, for injury or death of guest or member, 55 A.L.R.5th 463.<f_break>►<field>rc.ref.id="I00ATW1"</field>Liability of member of unincorporated association for tortious acts of association's nonmember agent or employee, 62 A.L.R.3d 1165.<f_break>►<field>rc.ref.id="I00DN0X"</field>Liability of social club for injury to or death of nonmember, 15 A.L.R.3d 1013.<f_break>►<field>rc.ref.id="I000ENH"</field>Rights and liabilities arising out of contract for lifetime membership in social or fraternal club or association, 10 A.L.R.3d 1357.<f_break>►<field>rc.ref.id="I002EHF"</field>Association of persons as proper representative of class under Rule 23 of Federal Rules of Civil Procedure governing maintenance of class actions, 63 A.L.R. Fed. 361.<f_break>►<field>rc.ref.id="I000ENE"</field>Determination of citizenship of unincorporated associations, for federal diversity of citizenship purposes, in actions by or against such associations, 14 A.L.R. Fed. 849.<f_break>Liability of association, generally, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I002EHI"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &ss;§§1<trace>4</trace>, 3<trace>1</trace> to <trace.deleted/><trace>37</trace>.<f_break>Liability of association and members, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I0057ME"</field>Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &ss;§§<trace.deleted/><trace>27 </trace>to <trace.deleted/><trace>30</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> However, in the absence of a statutory authorization, an unincorporated organization or association cannot purchase or hold either real or personal property in its own right or accept such property by devise or bequest.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>3►<field>fn.fnref="3"</field><f_break>Research References<f_break>Capacity of unincorporated association to take or hold property, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I0080RA"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &s;§<trace.deleted/><trace>9</trace>.<f_break>Power to acquire and hold property, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I000EM9"</field>Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &s;§1<trace>1</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> Property ostensibly held by an unincorporated association is deemed to belong jointly to the members.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>4►<field>fn.fnref="4"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|19|30:19"</field>►<field>cc.ref.id="I002EIN"</field>McMahon v. Rauhr, 47 N.Y. 67, 1871 WL 9874 (1871).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Interest of members in property, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I0057NJ"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &s;§2<trace>0</trace>.<f_break>Rights of members in organization's property and assets, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I000EM6"</field>Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &s;§<trace.deleted/><trace>18</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|19|30:19"</field>An unincorporated association or club is entitled to protection against the use of its name by another organization, and may resort to injunctive relief to restrain the use of its name by others, unless precluded by equitable defenses.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>5►<field>fn.fnref="5"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|19|30:19"</field>►<field>cc.ref.id="I002EIQ"</field>Democratic Organization of County of Richmond v. Democratic Organization of County of Richmond, 253 A.D. 820, 1 N.Y.S.2d 349 (2d Dep't 1938); ►<field>cc.ref.id="I0057NM"</field>Rudolph v. Southern Beneficial League, 7 N.Y.S. 135 (Sup 1889).<f_break>Research References<f_break>►<field>rc.ref.id="I0080SI"</field>Right of charitable or religious association or corporation to protection against use of same or similar name by another, 37 A.L.R.3d 277.<f_break>Right to exclusive use of name, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I000EGJ"</field>Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &s;§1<trace>2</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
2. Form Drafting Principles
30:20. Articles and bylaws
Research References
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I000EGH"</field>West's Key Number Digest, Associations &key;<trace>111 et seq .</trace>
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I002EOF"</field><trace.deleted/>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|20|30:20"</field>An unincorporated association may promote its aims and purposes and advance the best interests of its members in any legitimate way.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>1►<field>fn.fnref="1"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|20|30:20"</field>►<field>cc.ref.id="I0057TB"</field>Burt v. Oneida Community, 137 N.Y. 346, 33 N.E. 307 (1893).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> To that end, it may adopt a constitution, also called a &ldquo;“charter&rdquo;”&ldquo;“articles of association,&rdquo;” and bylaws for the regulation of its internal government, its policy, and the management of its affairs. The articles of association, bylaws, and the rules and regulations of the association constitute a contract between the organization and its members and govern members' relations among themselves and with the organization.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>2►<field>fn.fnref="2"</field><f_break>Research References<f_break>Constitution, bylaws, rules, and regulations of unincorporated association, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I0080Y7"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &ss;§§<trace.deleted/><trace>4 to 8</trace>.<f_break>Constitution, bylaws, rules, and regulations of unincorporated association, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I000EGE"</field>Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &ss;§§5, 6.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|20|30:20"</field>There is no restriction upon the power of an unincorporated association to prescribe reasonable rules, except that they must be adopted in conformity with the agreement of the members and must not be contrary to the law. An association regulation that is repugnant to the laws of the state may be declared to be void and of no effect by the courts. Moreover, to be valid and binding, the bylaws of any organization must be reasonable, and if a regulation of an association is clearly unreasonable, the courts will disregard it. Furthermore, a majority of the members cannot by vote deprive other members of their rights under the organization's constitution.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>3►<field>fn.fnref="3"</field><f_break>Research References<f_break>Constitution, bylaws, rules, and regulations of unincorporated association, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I002EOI"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &ss;§§<trace.deleted/><trace>4 to 8</trace>.<f_break>Constitution, bylaws, rules, and regulations of unincorporated association, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I0057TE"</field>Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &ss;§§5, 6.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|20|30:20"</field>Articles of an association will be read in light of the rule that limits the general words of an instrument to its specific object, and ambiguity may be explained by prior custom of the organization and interpretations by the organization itself through its officers and authorized tribunals.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>4►<field>fn.fnref="4"</field><f_break>Research References<f_break>Constitution, bylaws, rules, and regulations of unincorporated association, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I0080YA"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &ss;§§<trace.deleted/><trace>4 to 8</trace>.<f_break>Constitution, bylaws, rules, and regulations of unincorporated association, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I000EGC"</field>Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &ss;§§5, 6.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|20|30:20"</field>Although an unincorporated association is not required to have either a constitution or bylaws, such documents should be drawn up as they constitute the association's fundamental law.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|20|30:20"</field>Unlike incorporated associations or clubs, no particular provisions are required to be included in the articles of an unincorporated organization. An organization may divide its organic law as it desires among a constitution, bylaws, and a set of rules and regulations. It is recommended that the basic laws and rules be drafted contemporaneously to preclude both the inadvertent omission of desired provisions and the inclusion of inconsistent ones.
Practice Tip:
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|20|30:20"</field>While there is no requirement that articles of association and bylaws be in writing, to avoid dissension and to ensure continuity, these documents should be prepared in writing.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|20|30:20"</field>Many of the forms of the certificate of incorporation and bylaws and individual provisions for such forms appearing in the division of this chapter dealing with incorporated associations<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>5►<field>fn.fnref="5"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|20|30:20"</field>See ►<field>x.ref.id="I000EF6"</field>&ss;§§30:68 et seq.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> may, with some modification, be utilized by an unincorporated association or club.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|20|30:20"</field>As a general rule, unless forbidden by the organic law, an association, club, or society may alter, amend, or repeal its laws or enact others consistent with the purpose for which it was organized whenever the welfare of the association so requires. Where the constitution and bylaws of an unincorporated association provide for amendment, the constitution and bylaws may be amended in the mode prescribed.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>6►<field>fn.fnref="6"</field><f_break>Research References<f_break>Amendment or repeal of constitution, bylaws, rules, and regulations of unincorporated association, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I002EPQ"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &s;§<trace>7</trace>.<f_break>Amendment or repeal of constitution, bylaws, rules, and regulations of unincorporated association, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I0057UM"</field>Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &s;§<trace>8</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
30:21. Articles and bylaws-- Important matters to be covered
Research References
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I0080ZI"</field><trace.deleted/><trace>West’s Key Number Digest, Associations &key;101 et seq.</trace>
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I000EF4"</field><trace.deleted/>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|21|30:21"</field>Important matters to be treated in either the articles or the bylaws, or both, include:<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>1►<field>fn.fnref="1"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|21|30:21"</field>For checklists of matters to consider when drafting governing instruments for an association, see ►<field>x.ref.id="I002EPS"</field>&s;§30:22 (articles of association or constitution), and ►<field>x.ref.id="I0057UO"</field>&s;§30:23 (bylaws).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|21|30:21"</field>1. Purposes and powers of the association. An unincorporated association may be designed to serve any legitimate purpose<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>2►<field>fn.fnref="2"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|21|30:21"</field>►<field>cc.ref.id="I0080ZK"</field>Wicks v. Monihan, 130 N.Y. 232, 29 N.E. 139 (1891).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> and may promote its aims and purposes and advance the best interests of its members in any legitimate way.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>3►<field>fn.fnref="3"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|21|30:21"</field>►<field>cc.ref.id="I00AU4G"</field>Burt v. Oneida Community, 137 N.Y. 346, 33 N.E. 307 (1893); ►<field>cc.ref.id="I000EF1"</field>Robinson v. Dahm, 94 Misc. 729, 159 N.Y.S. 1053 (Sup 1916).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Constitution, bylaws, rules, and regulations of unincorporated association, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I002EPV"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &ss;§§<trace.deleted/><trace>4 to 8</trace>.<f_break>Constitution, bylaws, rules, and regulations of unincorporated association, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I0057UR"</field>Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &ss;§§5, 6.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|21|30:21"</field>2. Authorities and duties of officers and other bodies, such as a governing council.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|21|30:21"</field>3. Qualifications of and admission to membership. A voluntary association may prescribe the necessary qualifications for membership in the association and may limit its membership by tests of learning or skill. Membership in a voluntary association is a privilege that may be given or withheld at the association's pleasure.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>4►<field>fn.fnref="4"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|21|30:21"</field>The courts cannot compel the admission of any individual to an unincorporated association. ►<field>cc.ref.id="I000E9E"</field>McKane v. Democratic General Committee, 123 N.Y. 609, 25 N.E. 1057 (1890), holding that no rights of property, of person, or of citizenship are affected or infringed upon by the refusal of admission.<f_break>Research References<f_break>Membership and rights of members, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I002EVI"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &ss;§§1<trace>5</trace> to 2<trace.deleted/><trace>0</trace>.<f_break>Membership and rights of members, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I000E9B"</field>Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &ss;§§1<trace>3</trace> et seq.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|21|30:21"</field>4. Classification of members and rights, privileges and liabilities of each membership class. All members in good standing have a legally enforceable right to attend the meetings of the association and to participate in its deliberations and decisions.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>5►<field>fn.fnref="5"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|21|30:21"</field>►<field>cc.ref.id="I002EVL"</field>In re Bandanza, 132 Misc. 817, 230 N.Y.S. 460 (Sup 1928).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Meetings of members, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I00580H"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &s;§<trace.deleted/><trace>18</trace>.<f_break>Meetings of members, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I00815D"</field>Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &ss;§§<trace.deleted/><trace>17</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> Where the laws of the association prescribe the time and manner of giving notice, notice to members must be given as so prescribed.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>6►<field>fn.fnref="6"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|21|30:21"</field>►<field>cc.ref.id="I00AUA9"</field>In re Bandanza, 132 Misc. 817, 230 N.Y.S. 460 (Sup 1928).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Notice of meetings of members, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I000E99"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &s;§<trace.deleted/><trace>18</trace>.<f_break>Notice of meetings of members, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I002EVN"</field>Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &s;§<trace.deleted/><trace>17</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|21|30:21"</field>5. Suspension or expulsion of members. An association may suspend, expel, or terminate the membership of any member in accordance with the provisions of its governing instruments as long as such provisions are reasonable.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>7►<field>fn.fnref="7"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|21|30:21"</field>Ordinarily, the rules and bylaws of a voluntary, unincorporated association provide for the course of procedure to be followed in disciplining or expelling members, and such disciplinary action, in order to be valid, must be made in the regular manner in conformity with such rules and bylaws. ►<field>cc.ref.id="I00580J"</field>Harmon v. Matthews, 27 N.Y.S.2d 656 (Sup 1941); ►<field>cc.ref.id="I00815F"</field>Stein v. Marks, 44 Misc. 140, 89 N.Y.S. 921 (Sup 1904).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Discipline of members; expulsion or suspension, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I000E97"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &ss;§§<trace.deleted/><trace>21 to 24</trace>.<f_break>Discipline of members; expulsion or suspension, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I002EVP"</field>Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &ss;§§<trace.deleted/><trace>22 to 26</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> However, before taking such action, the association must afford the member reasonable notice and an opportunity to be heard.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>8►<field>fn.fnref="8"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|21|30:21"</field>►<field>cc.ref.id="I00580L"</field>Rodier v. Huddell, 232 A.D. 531, 250 N.Y.S. 336 (1st Dep't 1931); ►<field>cc.ref.id="I000E81"</field>Williamson v. Randolph, 48 Misc. 96, 96 N.Y.S. 644 (Sup 1905).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Disciplinary proceedings, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I002EWV"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &s;§2<trace>2</trace>.<f_break>Necessity and sufficiency of notice and hearing, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I00581R"</field>Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &s;§<trace>2</trace>4.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> If proceedings in a disciplinary hearing are had fairly, in good faith, and pursuant to the laws of the organization and if there was nothing in the proceedings in violation of the law of the land, the decision of the organization's tribunal to suspend or expel a member is conclusive.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>9►<field>fn.fnref="9"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|21|30:21"</field>►<field>cc.ref.id="I000E7Z"</field>Wilcox v. Supreme Council of Royal Arcanum, 210 N.Y. 370, 104 N.E. 624 (1914); ►<field>cc.ref.id="I002EWX"</field>Spiegelman v. Engineers Country Club, Inc., 38 A.D.2d 728, 329 N.Y.S.2d 166 (2d Dep't 1972).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Discipline of members; expulsion or suspension, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I00581T"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &ss;§§<trace.deleted/><trace>21 to 24</trace>.<f_break>Discipline of members; expulsion or suspension, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I00816P"</field>Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &ss;§§<trace.deleted/><trace>22 to 26</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 Practice Tip:
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|21|30:21"</field>It is recommended that a specific procedure for notice and hearing be set forth in the bylaws, although the governing instruments may provide for such procedure by implication.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|21|30:21"</field>6. Procedure for enforcement of sanctions.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>10►<field>fn.fnref="10"</field><f_break>Research References<f_break>Judicial review of expulsion or suspension, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I000E2B"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &s;§2<trace>3</trace>.<f_break>Judicial review of expulsion or suspension, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I002F2L"</field>Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &ss;§§<trace.deleted/><trace>25, 26</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|21|30:21"</field>7. Liability of members to third persons.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>11►<field>fn.fnref="11"</field><f_break>Research References<f_break>Liability of members for acts and debts of association, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I00587H"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &s;§<trace.deleted/>1<trace>9 27 to 30</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|21|30:21"</field>8. Amendment of articles and bylaws. The bylaws or articles of association should provide that amendments are valid and binding on all members, including those who may have voted against them. The bylaws of an unincorporated association are deemed to be a contract between the members determining their rights, powers, duties, and liabilities. As a general rule, unless forbidden by the organic law, an association, club, or society may alter, amend, or repeal its laws or enact others consistent with the purpose for which it was organized, whenever the welfare of the association so requires. Where the constitution and bylaws of an unincorporated association provide for amendment, the constitution and bylaws may be amended in the mode prescribed.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>12►<field>fn.fnref="12"</field><f_break>Research References<f_break>Amendment of constitution, bylaws, rules, and regulations, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I000E29"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &s;§<trace>7</trace>.<f_break>Amendment of constitution, bylaws, rules, and regulations, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I002F2N"</field>Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &s;§<trace>8</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|21|30:21"</field>9. Manner of dissolution and disposition of property of the association on dissolution.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>13►<field>fn.fnref="13"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|21|30:21"</field>Generally, where the operations of a voluntary association have been discontinued, its objects and purposes being abandoned by common consent, a court of equity has jurisdiction to decree a dissolution and to distribute its funds among the several contributors in proportion to the amount contributed or paid by them respectively. ►<field>cc.ref.id="I000E26"</field>Lafond v. Deems, 81 N.Y. 507, 1880 WL 12514 (1880).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Dissolution of unincorporated association, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I002F2Q"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &s;§1<trace>1</trace>.<f_break>Rights of members in organization's property and assets, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I00587M"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &s;§2<trace>0</trace>.<f_break>Rights of members in organization's property and assets, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I0081CI"</field>Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &ss;§<trace>18</trace><trace.deleted/>.<f_break>Dissolution and liquidation, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I000E24"</field>Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &ss;<trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace>§30</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
3. Checklists
30:22. Checklist-- Matters to be considered when drafting constitution or articles of association for an unincorporated association

NFP
CHK
FCV
FTR
EBL
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"</field>1. Name of association.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"</field>2. Location and complete address of association's offices.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"</field>3. Purposes for which association is formed.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"</field>a. Specific or primary purpose.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"</field>b. Other general purposes.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"</field>4. Statement that association is to be not-for-profit.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"</field>5. Powers of association.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"</field>6. Form of government.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"</field>a. Titles and numbers of members of governing body.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"</field>b. Names and addresses of the first members.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"</field>c. Meeting of governing body.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"</field>d. Quorum requirements for conducting business.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"</field>e. Appointment and duties of committees.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"</field>f. Titles, number, and duties of officers.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"</field>7. Membership.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"</field>a. Classification of members.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"</field>b. Rights, privileges, and liabilities of each class of members.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"</field>c. Qualifications of members.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"</field>d. Admission to membership.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"</field>e. Suspension or expulsion of members.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"</field>f. Termination of membership.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"</field>g. Notice and hearing of charges against member.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"</field>8. Meeting of association.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"</field>a. Regular meetings.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"</field>b. Special meeting.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"</field>c. Time and place of meeting.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"</field>d. Manner of giving notice.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"</field>e. Quorum requirements.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"</field>9. Authorization to adopt bylaws.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"</field>10. Manner of amending bylaws.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"</field>11. Manner of amending articles or constitution.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"</field>12. Amendments to articles and bylaws to be binding on all members, including those who may have voted against such amendments.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"</field>13. Manner of dissolution.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"</field>14. Distribution of assets on dissolution.

Item 1.
Drafter's Note 
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"</field>An unincorporated association is entitled to protection against the use of its name by another organization and may resort to injunctive relief to restrain the use of its name by others. ►<field>cc.ref.id="I000E0U"</field>Democratic Organization of County of Richmond v. Democratic Organization of County of Richmond, 253 A.D. 820, 1 N.Y.S.2d 349 (2d Dep't 1938); ►<field>cc.ref.id="I002F42"</field>Rudolph v. Southern Beneficial League, 7 N.Y.S. 135 (Sup 1889).
Research References
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I00588Y"</field>West's Key Number Digest, Associations &key;<trace>120 to 123</trace>
 ►<field>rc.ref.id="I00065U"</field>Right of charitable or religious association or corporation to protection against use of same or similar name by another, 37 A.L.R.3d 277
 ►<field>rc.ref.id="I002MZ2"</field>Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &s;§1<trace>2</trace>
Item 3.
Drafter's Note 
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"</field>Societies and clubs may perform all necessary governmental acts in any way consonant with their purposes and with the laws, internal and external, to which they are subject. ►<field>cc.ref.id="I005G3Y"</field>Wicks v. Monihan, 130 N.Y. 232, 29 N.E. 139 (1891).
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"</field>Purpose clauses, see ►<field>x.ref.id="I00065S"</field>&ss;§§30:74 et seq.
Item 4.
Drafter's Note 
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"</field>Qualifying for tax-exempt status, see ►<field>x.ref.id="I002MZ4"</field>&ss;§§30:2 to 30:9.
Item 5.
Drafter's Note 
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"</field>Voluntary, unincorporated associations have inherent power, somewhat akin to the police power of a state, and are under a duty to provide for the welfare of their members and to regulate their affairs so as to attain the objects and purposes for which they were constituted. ►<field>cc.ref.id="I005G40"</field>Weinstock v. Ladisky, 197 Misc. 859, 98 N.Y.S.2d 85 (Sup 1950).
Research References
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I00898W"</field>West's Key Number Digest, <trace.deleted/><trace>Association</trace>s &key;<trace>162</trace>
 ►<field>rc.ref.id="I00B2DS"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &s;§<trace.deleted/><trace>9</trace>
 ►<field>rc.ref.id="I00065P"</field>Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &ss;§§<trace.deleted/><trace>9 to 12</trace>
Item 6.
Drafter's Note 
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"</field>An association is generally formed by the voluntary action of a number of individuals in associating themselves together under a common name for the accomplishment of some lawful purpose; its organization, as in the case of corporations, does not usually depend upon compliance with any statutory provisions. ►<field>cc.ref.id="I002MZ7"</field>Weidenfeld v. Keppler, 84 A.D. 235, 82 N.Y.S. 634 (1st Dep't 1903), aff'd, 176 N.Y. 562, 68 N.E. 1125 (1903).
Research References
 <trace.deleted/>
<trace.deleted/>
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I002MZ9"</field><trace.deleted/>
 ►<field>rc.ref.id="I005G45"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &s;§5
 ►<field>rc.ref.id="I008991"</field>Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &s;§4
Item 7.
Drafter's Note 
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"</field>A voluntary association has a right to restrict its membership to those willing to sign the uniform agreement which constitutes its contractual relationship with its members. ►<field>cc.ref.id="I00064H"</field>Importers' & Exporters' Ins. Co. v. Rhoades, 209 A.D. 689, 205 N.Y.S. 628 (1st Dep't 1924), rev'd on other grounds, 239 N.Y. 420, 146 N.E. 648 (1925). In general, whether to grant or refuse membership in a voluntary association is a matter under the complete control of the organization itself, and its ruling in this respect is not subject to review by the courts. ►<field>cc.ref.id="I00064F"</field>Simons v. Berry, 210 A.D. 90, 205 N.Y.S. 442 (1st Dep't 1924); ►<field>cc.ref.id="I002N0H"</field>Barazani v. Brighton and Manhattan Beach Chamber of Commerce and Civic Ass'n, Inc., 20 Misc. 2d 844, 194 N.Y.S.2d 426 (Sup 1959).
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"</field>However, an association's authority to restrict membership is not unlimited where restriction is based on race, gender, or ethnicity. Thus, refusal of membership on such grounds can be challenged under circumstances, using antidiscrimination laws applicable to public entities. Associations, like corporations and other legislatively defined entities, are within the sphere of legislative control. ►<field>cc.ref.id="I005G5D"</field>New York State Club Ass'n, Inc. v. City of New York, 487 U.S. 1, 108 S. Ct. 2225, 101 L. Ed. 2d 1 (1988) (upholding New York City law forbidding discrimination in certain clubs with greater than 400 members in the interest of assuring equal access to business opportunities to women and minorities).
Research References
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I0089A9"</field>West's Key Number Digest, Associations &key;<trace.deleted/><trace>141 to 160</trace>
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I00B2F5"</field><trace.deleted/>
 ►<field>rc.ref.id="I00064D"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &ss;§§<trace.deleted/><trace>15 to 24</trace>
 ►<field>rc.ref.id="I002N0J"</field>Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &ss;§§<trace.deleted/><trace>13 to 26</trace>
Item 8.
Drafter's Note 
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"</field>All members in good standing of an association have a legally enforceable right to attend the meetings of the society and participate in its deliberations and decisions. ►<field>rc.ref.id="I005G5F"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &s;§<trace>18</trace><trace.deleted/>.
Research References
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I0089AB"</field>West's Key Number Digest, Associations &key;17<trace>1</trace>
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I0005YP"</field><trace.deleted/>
 ►<field>rc.ref.id="I002N67"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &s;§<trace.deleted/><trace>18</trace>
 ►<field>rc.ref.id="I005GB3"</field>Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &ss;§§<trace>17</trace>
Item 8c.
Drafter's Note 
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"</field>Notice of a meeting of a voluntary association must include the time, place, and object of the meeting. ►<field>cc.ref.id="I0089FZ"</field>Goller v. Stubenhaus, 77 Misc. 29, 134 N.Y.S. 1043 (Sup 1912).
Research References
<trace.deleted/>
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I066CF0"</field><trace.deleted/>

Item 8d.
Drafter's Note 
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"</field>Where the laws for the internal government of the association ordain the time or manner of giving notice, notice to members must be given as so prescribed. ►<field>cc.ref.id="I0005YK"</field>In re Bandanza, 132 Misc. 817, 230 N.Y.S. 460 (Sup 1928).

 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I002N6C"</field>West's Key Number Digest, Associations &key;<trace>171</trace>

Item 10.
Drafter's Note 
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"</field>As a general rule, unless forbidden by the organic law, an association, club, or society may alter, amend, or repeal its laws or enact others consistent with the purposes for which it was organized, whenever the welfare of the association so requires. ►<field>rc.ref.id="I005GBA"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &s;§<trace>7</trace>.

Item 12.
Drafter's Note 
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"</field>Where the association has the right to alter its constitution and bylaws, a member is deemed to have consented to and acquiesced in amendments duly made. ►<field>cc.ref.id="I002N7M"</field>Havens v. King, 221 A.D. 475, 224 N.Y.S. 193 (3d Dep't 1927), aff'd, 250 N.Y. 617, 166 N.E. 346 (1929).

Item 13.
Drafter's Note 
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"</field>Where the operations of a voluntary association have been discontinued, its objects and purposes being abandoned by common consent, a court of equity has jurisdiction to decree a dissolution and to distribute its funds among its several members or contributors. ►<field>rc.ref.id="I0005RK"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &s;§1<trace>1</trace>.

Item 14.
Drafter's Note 
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"</field>The dissolution of an association as a body entitles the members thereof at the time of the dissolution to a distribution, in accordance with their just interests, of its funds and other property. ►<field>rc.ref.id="I005GIA"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &s;§1<trace>1</trace>.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"</field>In the absence of an applicable statutory plan, the assets of a dissolved association should be distributed in accordance with the rules of the organization. ►<field>cc.ref.id="I0089N6"</field>In re American Dramatic Fund Ass'n, 3 N.Y.S. 793 (Sup 1889).

30:23. Checklist-- Matters to be considered when drafting bylaws for an unincorporated association
COL
NFP
CHK
FCV
FTR
EBL
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"</field>1. Location and address of organization headquarters or office<trace>.</trace>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"</field>2. Form and structure of government<trace>.</trace>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"</field>a. Designation of governing body<trace>.</trace>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"</field>b. Composition of governing body; qualifications, manner of election, and term of service of members of governing body<trace>.</trace>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"</field>c. Powers, duties, and liabilities of members of governing body<trace>.</trace>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"</field>d. Limitations on authority and powers of governing bodies and officers<trace>.</trace>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"</field>e. Composition and duties of committees<trace>.</trace>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"</field>f. Titles, number, and duties of officers<trace>.</trace>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"</field>3. Meetings of governing body<trace>.</trace>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"</field>a. Manner of giving notice of meetings<trace>.</trace>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"</field>b. Time and place of meetings<trace>.</trace>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"</field>c. Requirements of quorum<trace>.</trace>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"</field>4. Membership structure<trace>.</trace>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"</field>a. Qualifications for membership<trace>.</trace>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"</field>b. Classes of membership and rights and obligations of each class<trace>.</trace>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"</field>c. Regulations concerning the admission of members<trace>.</trace>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"</field>d. Property, voting, and other rights of members<trace>.</trace>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"</field>e. Entrance or initiation fees for new members<trace>.</trace>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"</field>f. Amount and due date of monthly, semi-annual, or annual (or as the case may be) dues<trace>.</trace>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"</field>5. Regulation of membership<trace>.</trace>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"</field>a. Sanctions, including suspension or expulsion, for nonpayment of dues or violation of rules<trace>.</trace>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"</field>b. Procedure for enforcement of sanctions<trace>.</trace>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"</field>c. Manner of withdrawal, suspension, and expulsion of members and manner of reinstatement<trace>.</trace>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"</field>d. Transfer of membership<trace>.</trace>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"</field>e. Termination of membership<trace>.</trace>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"</field>f. Notice and hearing of charges against member<trace>.</trace>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"</field>6. Meetings of members<trace>.</trace>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"</field>a. Dates for regular meetings and procedure for calling special meetings<trace>.</trace>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"</field>b. Number of members necessary to constitute quorum<trace>.</trace>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"</field>c. Order of business at meetings<trace>.</trace>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"</field>7. Method of amending bylaws<trace>.</trace>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"</field>8. Liability of members and association to third persons<trace>.</trace>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"</field>9. Dissolution of the association and distribution of assets<trace>.</trace>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"</field>10. Insignia<trace>.</trace>

Item 2.
Drafter's Note 
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"</field>An association is generally formed by the voluntary action of a number of individuals in associating themselves together under a common name for the accomplishment of some lawful purpose; its organization, as in the case of corporations, does not usually depend upon compliance with any statutory provisions. ►<field>cc.ref.id="I0005KH"</field>Weidenfeld v. Keppler, 84 A.D. 235, 82 N.Y.S. 634 (1st Dep't 1903), aff'd, 176 N.Y. 562, 68 N.E. 1125 (1903).
Research References
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I005GPB"</field>West's Key Number Digest, Associations &key;<trace>101 et seq.</trace>
<trace.deleted/>
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I00B2Z3"</field><trace.deleted/>
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I0005KF"</field><trace.deleted/>
 ►<field>rc.ref.id="I002NKH"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &s;§5
 ►<field>rc.ref.id="I005GPD"</field>Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &s;§4
Item 2b.
Drafter's Note 
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"</field>The bylaws govern the procedure and implementation of elections of officers or directors of the association.
Research References
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I0089U9"</field>West's Key Number Digest, Associations &key;<trace>221 to 22</trace>5

 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I0005KC"</field><trace.deleted/>
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I002NKK"</field><trace.deleted/>
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I005GPG"</field><trace.deleted/>
 ►<field>rc.ref.id="I0089UC"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &s;§<trace.deleted/><trace>8</trace>
Item 2c.
Drafter's Note 
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"</field>The general rule of the law of agency holds one who assumes to act as agent for a principal who has no such legal status or existence individually liable on the contract made on behalf of his or her professed principal. However, in the absence of a personal promise or covenant, one signing a contract, who therein represents himself or herself to be the agent of an association as a disclosed and known principal, or who assumes to contract for such principal only, cannot be held personally liable upon the covenants contained in such contract. ►<field>cc.ref.id="I00B2Z8"</field>Whitford v. Laidler, 94 N.Y. 145, 1883 WL 12735 (1883).
Research References
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I0005KA"</field>West's Key Number Digest, Associations &key;<trace>201 to 203</trace>
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I002NKM"</field><trace.deleted/>
 ►<field>rc.ref.id="I0005J5"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &s;§1<trace>4</trace>
 ►<field>rc.ref.id="I002NLR"</field>Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &ss;§§<trace.deleted/><trace>27 to 30</trace>
Item 4.
Drafter's Note 
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"</field>A voluntary association has a right to restrict its membership to those willing to sign the uniform agreement which constitutes its contractual relationship with its members. ►<field>cc.ref.id="I005GQN"</field>Importers' & Exporters' Ins. Co. v. Rhoades, 209 A.D. 689, 205 N.Y.S. 628 (1st Dep't 1924), rev'd on other grounds, 239 N.Y. 420, 146 N.E. 648 (1925). In general, whether to grant or refuse membership in a voluntary association is a matter under the complete control of the organization itself, and its ruling in this respect is not subject to review by the courts. ►<field>cc.ref.id="I0005J2"</field>Simons v. Berry, 210 A.D. 90, 205 N.Y.S. 442 (1st Dep't 1924); ►<field>cc.ref.id="I002NLU"</field>Barazani v. Brighton and Manhattan Beach Chamber of Commerce and Civic Ass'n, Inc., 20 Misc. 2d 844, 194 N.Y.S.2d 426 (Sup 1959).
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"</field>However, an association's authority to restrict membership is not unlimited where restriction is based on race, gender, or ethnicity. Thus, refusal of membership on such grounds can be challenged under circumstances using antidiscrimination laws applicable to public entities. Associations, like corporations and other legislatively defined entities, are within the sphere of legislative control. ►<field>cc.ref.id="I005GQQ"</field>New York State Club Ass'n, Inc. v. City of New York, 487 U.S. 1, 108 S. Ct. 2225, 101 L. Ed. 2d 1 (1988) (upholding New York City law forbidding discrimination in certain clubs with greater than 400 members in the interest of assuring equal access to business opportunities to women and minorities).
Research References
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I0089VM"</field>West's Key Number Digest, Associations &key;<trace.deleted/><trace>141 to 160</trace>
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I0005DF"</field><trace.deleted/>
 ►<field>rc.ref.id="I002NRH"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &ss;§§<trace.deleted/><trace>15 to 24</trace>
 ►<field>rc.ref.id="I005GWD"</field>Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &ss;§§<trace.deleted/><trace>13 to 26</trace>
Item 4f.
Drafter's Note 
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"</field>Provisions of the articles of association imposing upon members the payment of dues and assessments at stated times and subscribed to by them create a legal obligation upon the part of each member to pay such dues and assessments as long as the society remains a going concern and his or her membership therein continues. ►<field>rc.ref.id="I008A19"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &s;§1<trace>7</trace>.
Research References
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I00B365"</field>West's Key Number Digest, Associations &key;1<trace>73</trace>
<trace.deleted/>
 ►<field>rc.ref.id="I002NRK"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &s;§1<trace>7</trace>
 ►<field>rc.ref.id="I005GWG"</field>Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &s;§2<trace>3</trace>
Item 5a.
Drafter's Note 
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"</field>An association may expel a member for a violation of its established rules for which expulsion is provided. ►<field>cc.ref.id="I0005DA"</field>Marandino v. Westchester Country Club, Inc., 33 A.D.3d 800, 822 N.Y.S.2d 762 (2d Dep't 2006); ►<field>cc.ref.id="I002NRM"</field>Kelly v. Northport Yacht Club, Inc., 44 A.D.3d 858, 844 N.Y.S.2d 358 (2d Dep't 2007).
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"</field>Within contracts of association there inheres a term binding members to loyal support of the society in the attainment of its proper purposes and that, for a gross breach of this obligation, the power of expulsion is impliedly conferred on the association. ►<field>cc.ref.id="I005GWI"</field>Berich v. Ithaca Police Benev. Ass'n, Inc., 23 A.D.3d 904, 804 N.Y.S.2d 833 (3d Dep't 2005).
Research References
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I0005D7"</field>West's Key Number Digest, Associations &key;1<trace>50 to 152, 244</trace>
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I002NRP"</field><trace.deleted/>
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I005GWL"</field><trace.deleted/>
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I008A1H"</field><trace.deleted/>
 ►<field>rc.ref.id="I00B36D"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &s;§2<trace>1</trace>
 ►<field>rc.ref.id="I0005C2"</field>Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &s;§<trace>23</trace>
Item 5c.
Drafter's Note 
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"</field>Where the constitution and bylaws of a voluntary association reasonably set forth grounds for expulsion and provide for a hearing upon notice to the member, judicial review of such proceedings is unavailable, unless the reason for expulsion is not a violation of the constitution or bylaws or is so trivial as to suggest that the action of the association was capricious or corrupt or unless the association failed to administer its own rules fairly. ►<field>cc.ref.id="I002NSU"</field>Marandino v. Westchester Country Club, Inc., 33 A.D.3d 800, 822 N.Y.S.2d 762 (2d Dep't 2006).
Research References
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I005GXQ"</field>West's Key Number Digest, Associations &key;<trace>150 to 152, 244</trace>
<trace.deleted/>
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I00B37I"</field><trace.deleted/>
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I0005C0"</field><trace.deleted/>
 ►<field>rc.ref.id="I002NSW"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &s;§2<trace>1</trace>
 ►<field>rc.ref.id="I005GXS"</field>Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &ss;§§<trace.deleted/><trace>22 to 26</trace>
Item 5d.
Drafter's Note 
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"</field>The right of membership in a voluntary unincorporated association is a privilege that may not be transferred or sold without the consent of the association. ►<field>cc.ref.id="I008A2O"</field>Branagan v. Buckman, 67 Misc. 242, 122 N.Y.S. 610 (Sup 1910), aff'd, 145 A.D. 950, 130 N.Y.S. 1106 (3d Dep't 1911).
Research References
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I0005BX"</field>West's Key Number Digest, Associations &key;<trace>15</trace>6
<trace.deleted/>
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I002NYM"</field><trace.deleted/>
 ►<field>rc.ref.id="I005H3I"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &s;§1<trace>6</trace>
 ►<field>rc.ref.id="I008A8E"</field>Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &s;§2<trace>0</trace>
Item 5f.
Drafter's Note 
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"</field>Ordinarily, the rules and bylaws of a voluntary unincorporated association provide for the course of procedure to be followed in disciplining or expelling members, and such disciplinary action, in order to be valid, must be made in the regular manner in conformity with such rules and bylaws. ►<field>cc.ref.id="I000567"</field>Harmon v. Matthews, 27 N.Y.S.2d 656 (Sup 1941).
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"</field>Club member's right to be advised of charges against him or her to receive notice of disciplinary hearing and to be given opportunity to appear and be heard at hearing are fundamental rights that must be afforded even in absence of club bylaws. ►<field>cc.ref.id="I002NYP"</field>Anderson v. Board of Directors of Powelton Club, 183 Misc. 2d 200, 702 N.Y.S.2d 762 (Sup 1999).
Research References
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I005H3L"</field>West's Key Number Digest, Associations &key;<trace>150 to 152, 244</trace>
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I008A8H"</field><trace.deleted/>
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I00B3DD"</field><trace.deleted/>
 ►<field>rc.ref.id="I000565"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &s;§2<trace>2</trace>
 ►<field>rc.ref.id="I002NYR"</field>Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &s;§<trace>2</trace>4
Item 6.
Drafter's Note 
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"</field>All members in good standing of an association have a legally enforceable right to attend the meetings of the society and participate in its deliberations and decisions. ►<field>rc.ref.id="I005H3N"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &s;§<trace.deleted/><trace>18</trace>.
Research References
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I008A8J"</field>West's Key Number Digest, Associations &key;17<trace>1</trace>
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I000562"</field><trace.deleted/>
 ►<field>rc.ref.id="I002NYU"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &s;§<trace.deleted/><trace>18</trace>
 ►<field>rc.ref.id="I005H3Q"</field>Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &ss;§§<trace>17</trace>
Item 7.
Drafter's Note 
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"</field>As a general rule, unless forbidden by the organic law, an association, club, or society may alter, amend, or repeal its laws or enact others consistent with the purposes for which it was organized, whenever the welfare of the association so requires. ►<field>rc.ref.id="I008A8M"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &s;§<trace.deleted/><trace>7</trace>.
Research References
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I00054X"</field>West's Key Number Digest, Associations &key;<trace>128</trace>
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I002NZZ"</field><trace.deleted/>
 ►<field>rc.ref.id="I00054U"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &s;§<trace>7</trace>
 ►<field>rc.ref.id="I002O02"</field>Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &s;§<trace>8</trace>
Item 8.
Drafter's Note 
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"</field>Homeowners' association did not have duty to warn or protect motorist who was driving on street owned by association from dangerous condition created by tree that was located on neighboring property and thus was not liable for injuries allegedly sustained by motorist as result of tree falling on vehicle. ►<field>cc.ref.id="I005H4Y"</field>Crawford v. Forest Hills Gardens, 16 A.D.3d <trace.deleted/><trace>535</trace>, 792 N.Y.S.2d 135 (2d Dep't 2005).
Research References
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I008A9U"</field>West's Key Number Digest, Associations &key;<trace>2</trace>1<trace>1 to 214</trace>
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I00B3EQ"</field>West's Key Number Digest, Associations &key;<trace.deleted/><trace>201 to 203</trace>
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I000YQ5"</field><trace.deleted/>
 ►<field>rc.ref.id="I003RV1"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &ss;§§1<trace>2</trace> to 1<trace>4</trace>
 ►<field>rc.ref.id="I006KZX"</field>Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &ss;§§<trace.deleted/><trace>27 to 30</trace>
Item 9.
Drafter's Note 
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"</field>Where the operations of a voluntary association have been discontinued, its objects and purposes being abandoned by common consent, a court of equity has jurisdiction to decree a dissolution and to distribute its funds among its several members or contributors. ►<field>rc.ref.id="I009E4T"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &s;§1<trace>1</trace>.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"</field>The dissolution of an association as a body entitles the members thereof at the time of the dissolution to a distribution, in accordance with their just interests, of its funds and other property. ►<field>rc.ref.id="I00C79P"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &s;§1<trace>1</trace>.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"</field>In the absence of an applicable statutory plan, the assets of a dissolved association should be distributed in accordance with the rules of the organization. ►<field>cc.ref.id="I06431C"</field>In re American Dramatic Fund Ass'n, 3 N.Y.S. 793 (Sup 1889).
Research References
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I05ZVC0"</field>West's Key Number Digest, Associations &key;<trace.deleted/><trace>341 to 347</trace>

Item 10.
Drafter's Note 
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"</field>A society, club, or association does have the right to protection against the copying of its insignia, badges, and emblems by another organization. ►<field>rc.ref.id="I009E4Y"</field>Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &s;§1<trace>2</trace>.

<trace> </trace>B. Forms
30:24. Articles of association

►<field>form.du="0"</field><field>form.fid="Id53700901b6411e684899cfd92da4eb0"</field>ARTICLES OF ASSOCIATION 
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|24|30:24"</field>To further common purposes, the members agree to organize under these articles of association.
 
►<field>fi.lvl="1"</field>ARTICLE 1  NAME
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|24|30:24"</field>The name of this association shall be [name of association].
►<field>fi.lvl="1"</field>ARTICLE 2  PRINCIPAL OFFICE
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|24|30:24"</field>The principal office of the association shall be at [office address of association], [name of city], [name of county], State of New York. [OPTIONAL: The association may have such other offices as may, from time to time, be designated by its members or its executive committee.]
►<field>fi.lvl="1"</field>ARTICLE 3  PURPOSES
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|24|30:24"</field>The purposes for which this association is formed are:
 
►<field>fi.lvl="2"</field>A. 
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|24|30:24"</field>To own, operate, and maintain an association exclusively for the pleasure, entertainment, and recreation of its members.
►<field>fi.lvl="2"</field>B. 
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|24|30:24"</field>To do anything necessary and proper for the accomplishment of any purposes set forth in the statement of principles adopted by the founders of this association.
►<field>fi.lvl="2"</field>C. 
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|24|30:24"</field>This association is organized and operated exclusively for the above-stated purposes and for other not-for-profit purposes. No part of any net earnings shall inure to the benefit of any private member.
►<field>fi.lvl="1"</field>ARTICLE 4  POWERS
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|24|30:24"</field>In furtherance of the objectives described above, but not in limitation of such objectives, the association shall have the power, insofar as such power is conferred or is not limited, by law, to make and perform contracts for any lawful purpose; to engage in various funding and fund-raising activities; and to acquire, own, hold, operate, and maintain such property as to effectuate its purposes.
►<field>fi.lvl="1"</field>ARTICLE 5  MEMBERSHIP
 
►<field>fi.lvl="2"</field>A. 
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|24|30:24"</field>The association shall have one class of members only. All voting rights and other rights, interests, and privileges of each member shall be equal.
►<field>fi.lvl="2"</field>B. 
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|24|30:24"</field>The rights and privileges of members, their liability for dues and assessments, and the termination and transfer of membership shall be as stated in the bylaws.
►<field>fi.lvl="1"</field>ARTICLE 6  GOVERNING BODY
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|24|30:24"</field>The powers of the association shall be exercised and its property controlled by a council comprised of [number of members] members. The qualifications, the time and manner of election, the terms and duties of office, and the manner of filling vacancies shall be set forth in the bylaws.
►<field>fi.lvl="1"</field>ARTICLE 7  OFFICERS
 
►<field>fi.lvl="2"</field>A. Elective officers. 
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|24|30:24"</field>The officers of this association shall be a President, Vice President, secretary, and treasurer. Other offices and officers may be established or appointed by members of the association at the regular annual meeting. The qualifications of, the time and manner of electing, the duties of, the terms of office of, and the manner of removing officers shall be set forth in the bylaws.
►<field>fi.lvl="2"</field>B. Standing committees. 
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|24|30:24"</field>This association shall have at least two standing committees: The [name of council] shall elect annually, from among its members, an executive committee of [number of persons on executive committee] persons and a committee on admissions of [number of persons on admissions committee] persons. Other committees may be specified in the bylaws or may be appointed from time to time by the [name of council].
►<field>fi.lvl="1"</field>ARTICLE 8  AMENDMENTS TO ARTICLES
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|24|30:24"</field>These articles may be amended or repealed, in whole or in part, only by majority vote of this association's members at an organized meeting of the association.
►<field>fi.lvl="1"</field>ARTICLE 9  BYLAWS
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|24|30:24"</field>Bylaws will be hereafter adopted. Such bylaws may be amended or repealed, in whole 
or in part, in the manner they provide, and the amendments to the bylaws shall be binding on all members, including those who may have voted against them.
►<field>fi.lvl="1"</field>ARTICLE 10  DISSOLUTION
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|24|30:24"</field>This association shall be dissolved and its affairs wound up [specification of manner of voluntary dissolution].
►<field>fi.lvl="1"</field>ARTICLE 11  DISTRIBUTION OF PROPERTY ON DISSOLUTION
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|24|30:24"</field>In the event of dissolution, property of the association shall be distributed as follows: [specification of method of distribution].
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|24|30:24"</field>These articles of association are adopted on [date of adoption], at [address of adoption], [name of city], [name of county], State of New York.
►<field>fsig.pos="r"</field>►<field>fal.lo="y"</field> ______________ <br>
►<field>fvs.amt="1"</field>
►<field>fal.lo="y"</field> ______________ <br>[Names of members]
Notes to Form

Tax Notes 
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|24|30:24"</field>A club organized for pleasure, recreation, and other nonprofitable purposes will not be exempt from taxation for any taxable year if, at any time during such taxable year, the charter, bylaws, or other governing instrument of the organization or any written policy statement of the organization contains a provision that provides for discrimination against any person on the basis of race, color, or religion. ►<field>st.ref.id="I000YXA"</field>26 U.S.C.A. &s;§501(i).
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|24|30:24"</field>A not-for-profit association may or may not be tax exempt, depending on its purposes and powers. See ►<field>x.ref.id="I003S26"</field>&ss;§§30:2 et seq.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|24|30:24"</field>See ►<field>x.ref.id="I000YXD"</field>&ss;§§30:20 et seq. as to function and content of articles.
ARTICLE 1. 
Drafter's Note 
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|24|30:24"</field>An unincorporated association is entitled to protection against the use of its name by another organization and may resort to injunctive relief to restrain the use of its name by others. ►<field>cc.ref.id="I003S29"</field>Democratic Organization of County of Richmond v. Democratic Organization of County of Richmond, 253 A.D. 820, 1 N.Y.S.2d 349 (2d Dep't 1938); ►<field>cc.ref.id="I000YXF"</field>Rudolph v. Southern Beneficial League, 7 N.Y.S. 135 (Sup 1889).
Research References
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I003S2B"</field>West's Key Number Digest, Associations &key;1<trace.deleted/>2<trace>0</trace> to 1<trace>23</trace>
 <trace.deleted/>
<trace.deleted/>
<trace.deleted/>
<trace.deleted/>
 ►<field>rc.ref.id="I05ZUXG"</field>Right of charitable or religious association or corporation to protection against use of same or similar name by another, 37 A.L.R.3d 277
 ►<field>rc.ref.id="I006L79"</field>Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &s;§1<trace>2</trace>
ARTICLE 3. 
Drafter's Note 
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|24|30:24"</field>Societies and clubs may perform all necessary governmental acts in any way consonant with their purposes and with the laws, internal and external, to which they are subject. ►<field>cc.ref.id="I009EC5"</field>Wicks v. Monihan, 130 N.Y. 232, 29 N.E. 139 (1891).
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|24|30:24"</field>Purpose clauses, see ►<field>x.ref.id="I00C7H1"</field>&ss;§§30:74 et seq.
ARTICLE 4. 
Drafter's Note 
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|24|30:24"</field>Voluntary, unincorporated associations have inherent power, somewhat akin to the police power of a state, and are under a duty to provide for the welfare of their members and to regulate their affairs so as to attain the objects and purposes for which they were constituted. ►<field>cc.ref.id="I000YYN"</field>Weinstock v. Ladisky, 197 Misc. 859, 98 N.Y.S.2d 85 (Sup 1950).
Research References
 ►<field>rc.ref.id="I003S3J"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &s;§<trace.deleted/><trace>9</trace>
 ►<field>rc.ref.id="I006L8F"</field>Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &ss;§§<trace.deleted/><trace>9 to 12</trace>
ARTICLE 5. 
Drafter's Note 
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|24|30:24"</field>A voluntary association has a right to restrict its membership to those willing to sign the uniform agreement which constitutes its contractual relationship with its members. ►<field>cc.ref.id="I0642KC"</field>Importers' & Exporters' Ins. Co. v. Rhoades, 209 A.D. 689, 205 N.Y.S. 628 (1st Dep't 1924), rev'd on other grounds, 239 N.Y. 420, 146 N.E. 648 (1925). In general, whether to grant or refuse membership in a voluntary association is a matter under the complete control of the organization itself, and its ruling in this respect is not subject to review by the courts. ►<field>cc.ref.id="I05VN5O"</field>Simons v. Berry, 210 A.D. 90, 205 N.Y.S. 442 (1st Dep't 1924); ►<field>cc.ref.id="I000Z4D"</field>Barazani v. Brighton and Manhattan Beach Chamber of Commerce and Civic Ass'n, Inc., 20 Misc. 2d 844, 194 N.Y.S.2d 426 (Sup 1959).
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|24|30:24"</field>However, an association's authority to restrict membership is not unlimited where restriction is based on race, gender, or ethnicity. Thus, refusal of membership on such grounds can be challenged under circumstances, using antidiscrimination laws applicable to public entities. Associations, like corporations and other legislatively defined entities, are within the sphere of legislative control. ►<field>cc.ref.id="I003S99"</field>New York State Club Ass'n, Inc. v. City of New York, 487 U.S. 1, 108 S. Ct. 2225, 101 L. Ed. 2d 1 (1988) (upholding New York City law forbidding discrimination in certain clubs with greater than 400 members in the interest of assuring equal access to business opportunities to women and minorities).
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|24|30:24"</field>The right of membership in a voluntary unincorporated association is a privilege that may not be transferred or sold without the consent of the association. ►<field>cc.ref.id="I006LE5"</field>Branagan v. Buckman, 67 Misc. 242, 122 N.Y.S. 610 (Sup 1910), aff'd, 145 A.D. 950, 130 N.Y.S. 1106 (3d Dep't 1911).
Research References
 ►<field>rc.ref.id="I06428W"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &ss;§§<trace.deleted/><trace>15 to 24</trace>
 ►<field>rc.ref.id="I003S9B"</field>Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &ss;§§<trace.deleted/><trace>13 to 26</trace>
ARTICLE 7. 
Drafter's Note 
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|24|30:24"</field>The bylaws govern the procedure and implementation of elections of officers or directors of the association. ►<field>rc.ref.id="I006LE7"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &s;§<trace.deleted/><trace>8</trace>.
Research References
 ►<field>rc.ref.id="I009EJ3"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &s;§<trace.deleted/><trace>8</trace>
ARTICLE 8. 
Drafter's Note 
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|24|30:24"</field>As a general rule, unless forbidden by the organic law, an association, club, or society may alter, amend, or repeal its laws or enact others consistent with the purposes for which it was organized, whenever the welfare of the association so requires. ►<field>rc.ref.id="I000Z4I"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &s;§<trace.deleted/><trace>7</trace>.
Research References
 ►<field>rc.ref.id="I003S9E"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &s;§<trace>7</trace>
 ►<field>rc.ref.id="I006LEA"</field>Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &s;§<trace>8</trace>
ARTICLE 9. 
Drafter's Note 
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|24|30:24"</field>The contract between a new member and the association includes the constitution and bylaws of that association to which the new member is deemed to have consented. Furthermore, the bylaws and articles of association constitute a contract among the members of that association which the courts will enforce.
Research References
 ►<field>rc.ref.id="I000Z4K"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &ss;§<trace.deleted/><trace>6</trace>
 ►<field>rc.ref.id="I000Z5Q"</field>Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &s;§5
ARTICLE 10. 
Drafter's Note 
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|24|30:24"</field>Where the operations of a voluntary association have been discontinued, its objects and purposes being abandoned by common consent, a court of equity has jurisdiction to decree a dissolution and to distribute its funds among its several members or contributors. ►<field>rc.ref.id="I003SAM"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &s;§1<trace>1</trace>.
Research References
 ►<field>rc.ref.id="I006LFI"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &s;§1<trace>1</trace>
 ►<field>rc.ref.id="I009EKE"</field>Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &ss;§§<trace.deleted/><trace>38</trace>
ARTICLE 11. 
Drafter's Note 
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|24|30:24"</field>The dissolution of an association as a body entitles the members thereof at the time of the dissolution to a distribution, in accordance with their just interests, of its funds and other property. ►<field>rc.ref.id="I000Z5S"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &s;§1<trace.deleted/><trace>1</trace>.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|24|30:24"</field>In the absence of an applicable statutory plan, the assets of a dissolved association should be distributed in accordance with the rules of the organization. ►<field>cc.ref.id="I003SAO"</field>In re American Dramatic Fund Ass'n, 3 N.Y.S. 793 (Sup 1889).
Research References
 ►<field>rc.ref.id="I006LFK"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &s;§<trace.deleted/><trace>11</trace>

30:25. Bylaws of association governed by council
