 ►<field>rc.ref.id="I0041XV"</field>Wrongful Expulsion from Voluntary Social Organization, 44 Am. Jur. Proof of Facts 2d 455
III. Incorporated Associations
A. General Considerations
30:33. Introduction
Research References
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I006V2R"</field>West's Key Number Digest, Corporations and Business Organizations &key;3350 to 3499
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|37|30:33"</field>In New York, not-for-profit corporations are governed by the N.Y. Not-for-Profit Corporation Law (&ldquo;“Law&rdquo;”).<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>1►<field>fn.fnref="1"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|37|30:33"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I009O7N"</field>N-PCL &ss;§§101 et seq.<f_break>Research References<f_break>N.Y. Not-for-Profit Corp. Law, generally, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I063IVO"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &ss;§§9 to 13.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>&ldquo;“not-for-profit corporation&rdquo;” is defined as a corporation: (1) formed under the N.Y. Not-for-Profit Corp. Law<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>2►<field>fn.fnref="2"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|37|30:33"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I0041XX"</field>N-PCL &s;§102(a)(5).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> or existing on its effective date (September 1, 1970) and previously formed under any other general statute or by any special act of the State of New York, exclusively for a purpose or purposes, not for pecuniary profit or financial gain, for which a corporation may be formed under the chapter; and (2) no part of the assets, income, or profit of which is distributable to, or enures to the benefit of, its members, directors, or officers except to the extent permitted under the statute.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>3►<field>fn.fnref="3"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|37|30:33"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I006V2T"</field>N-PCL &s;§102(a)(5).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Not-for-profit corporations, generally, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I009O7P"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &s;§2<trace>8</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> With respect to corporations formed prior to the effective date of the statute, by or pursuant to a special act of the New York legislature, which corporation has as its principal purpose a religious, education, or charitable purpose, and is operated, supervised, or controlled by or in connection with a religious organization, to the extent that the former Membership Corporations Law or the General Corporation Law applied to it as of the effective date of the statute, the corresponding provisions of the N.Y. Not-for-Profit Corporation Law will apply. However, any such corporation may at any time after the effective date of the statute file a restated certificate of incorporation including a statement that it elects to have the statute apply in all respects to it. The restated certificate of incorporation must conform with the requirements of ►<field>st.ref.id="I0018U7"</field>N-PCL &s;§ for new corporations. Upon the filing of such certificate by the Department of State, the Not-for-Profit Corporation Law will apply in all respects to such corporation.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>4►<field>fn.fnref="4"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|37|30:33"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I0041Z3"</field>N-PCL &s;§103(a).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Application of N.Y. Not-for-Profit Corporation Law to corporations formed prior to effective date of statute, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I0018U9"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &s;§11.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> It does not apply to any corporation to which the Education Law, Religious Corporation Law, or Benevolent Orders Law is applicable or to certain corporations formed under special acts.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>5►<field>fn.fnref="5"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|37|30:33"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I0041Z5"</field>N-PCL &s;§103(a).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Application of N.Y. Not-for-Profit Corp. Law to special not-for-profit corporations, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I006V41"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &ss;§§10, 12.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> The application of the Law is exclusive in that, if it applies to a corporation, the Business Corporation Law does not apply.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>6►<field>fn.fnref="6"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|37|30:33"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I009O8X"</field>N-PCL &s;§103(b).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|37|30:33"</field>A foreign corporation, before it conducts any activities in New York, must file an application for authority to do so from the Department of State.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>7►<field>fn.fnref="7"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|37|30:33"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I00CHDT"</field>N-PCL &s;§1304.<f_break>Research References<f_break>Application of foreign corporations to conduct activities, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I0018ZX"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &s;<trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace>§216</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> The procedures for applying for the certificate of authority are set out in the Act.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>8►<field>fn.fnref="8"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|37|30:33"</field>See ►<field>st.ref.id="I00424T"</field>N-PCL &s;§1304, specifying what must be set forth in the application and attached to it.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>&ldquo;“foreign corporation&rdquo;” is defined as a corporation formed under laws other than the statutes of the State of New York, which, if formed under the statutes of this state, would be within the term &ldquo;“not-for-profit corporation.&rdquo;”<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>9►<field>fn.fnref="9"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|37|30:33"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I006V9P"</field>N-PCL &s;§102(a)(7).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|37|30:33"</field>The N.Y. Not-for-Profit Corporation Law is administered by the Department of State.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>10►<field>fn.fnref="10"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|37|30:33"</field>See ►<field>st.ref.id="I009OEL"</field>N-PCL &s;§104.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
30:34. Execution and filing of documents with Department of State; other formal requirements; corrections
Research References
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I0018ZZ"</field>West's Key Number Digest, Corporations and Business Organizations &key;3370 et seq.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|38|30:34"</field>Every certificate or other instrument relating to a domestic or foreign not-for-profit corporation delivered to the New York Department of State for filing under the N.Y. Not-for-Profit Corp. Law must be in the English language, except that the corporate name need not be in the English language if written in English letters or characters.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>1►<field>fn.fnref="1"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|38|30:34"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I00424V"</field>N-PCL &s;§104(a).<f_break>Research References<f_break>General requirements of certificate of incorporation, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I006V9R"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &s;<trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace>§68</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> The instrument becomes effective upon the filing thereof by the Department of State.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>2►<field>fn.fnref="2"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|38|30:34"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I001901"</field>N-PCL &s;§104(f).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Effective date of certificate; effect of filing, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I00424X"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &ss;§§<trace.deleted/><trace>81, 82</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|38|30:34"</field>The Department of State will make, certify, and transmit electronically a copy of each such instrument to the clerk of the county in which the office of the domestic or foreign corporation is and is to be located. The county clerk must file and index such copy.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>3►<field>fn.fnref="3"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|38|30:34"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I001904"</field>N-PCL &s;§104(g).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|38|30:34"</field>Every certificate required to be signed and delivered to the Department of State must, except as otherwise specified in ►<field>st.ref.id="I004250"</field>&s;§ providing for such certificate, be signed by either an officer, director, attorney-in-fact, or duly authorized person and must include the name and the capacity in which such person signs such certificate.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>4►<field>fn.fnref="4"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|38|30:34"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I006V9W"</field>N-PCL &s;§104(d).<f_break>Research References<f_break>General requirements of certificate of incorporation, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I009OES"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &s;<trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace>§68</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|38|30:34"</field>If an instrument delivered to the Department of State for filing complies as to form with the requirements of law and there has been attached to it the consent or approval of the Supreme Court justice, governmental body or officer, or other person or body, if any, whose consent to or approval of such instrument or the filing thereof is required by any statute of the State of New York and the appropriate filing fee and tax, if any, required by law have been paid, the instrument will be filed and indexed by the Department of State.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>5►<field>fn.fnref="5"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|38|30:34"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I00CHJO"</field>N-PCL &s;§104(e).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> No certificate of authentication or conformity or other proof will be required with respect to any verification, oath, or acknowledgment of any instrument delivered to the Department of State under the Law, if such verification, oath, or acknowledgment purports to have been made before a notary public, or person performing the equivalent function, of one of the states, or any subdivision thereof, of the United States or the District of Columbia.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>6►<field>fn.fnref="6"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|38|30:34"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I063IHE"</field>N-PCL &s;§104(e).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> Without limiting the effect of a certificate of incorporation, filing and indexing by the Department of State will not be deemed a finding that a certificate conforms to law, nor will it be deemed to constitute an approval by the Department of State of the corporation's name or the contents of the certificate, nor will it be deemed to prevent any person with appropriate standing from contesting the legality in an appropriate forum.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>7►<field>fn.fnref="7"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|38|30:34"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I05ZAS2"</field>N-PCL &s;§104(e).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|38|30:34"</field>If the instrument is required to set forth the date of incorporation or the date when a certificate of incorporation was filed, the original certificate of incorporation is meant.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>8►<field>fn.fnref="8"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|38|30:34"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I006V9Y"</field>N-PCL &s;§104(c).<f_break>Research References<f_break>General requirements of certificate of incorporation, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I009OEU"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &s;<trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace>§68</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|38|30:34"</field>Any certificate or other instrument relating to a domestic or foreign corporation filed by the Department of State under the Law may be corrected with respect to any typographical or similar nonmaterial error apparent on the face or defect in its execution, including the deletion of any matter not permitted to be stated in the document, by the filing of a certificate of correction.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>9►<field>fn.fnref="9"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|38|30:34"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I00191C"</field>N-PCL &s;§105(b).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Correcting or curing defective incorporation, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I004268"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &s;§<trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace>134.</trace><f_break></footnote.body></footnote> The certificate, entitled &ldquo;“Certificate of Correction of (Correct Title of Certificate and Name of Corporation),&rdquo;” must be signed and delivered to the Department of State.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>10►<field>fn.fnref="10"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|38|30:34"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I00191E"</field>N-PCL &s;§105(b).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Correcting or curing defective incorporation, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I00426A"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &s;§<trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace>134.</trace><f_break></footnote.body></footnote> The certificate of correction must state the name of the corporation; the date the certificate to be corrected was filed by the Department of State; the provision in the certificate as corrected or eliminated; and, if the execution was defective, the proper execution.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>11►<field>fn.fnref="11"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|38|30:34"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I006VB6"</field>N-PCL &s;§105(b).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Correcting or curing defective incorporation, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I009OG2"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &s;§<trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace>134.</trace><f_break></footnote.body></footnote> The filing of the certificate by the Department of State does not alter the effective time of the instrument being corrected, which will remain as its original effective time, and will not affect any right or liability accrued or incurred before such filing.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>12►<field>fn.fnref="12"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|38|30:34"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I00CHKY"</field>N-PCL &s;§105(b).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Correcting or curing defective incorporation, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I001972"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &s;§<trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace>134.</trace><f_break></footnote.body></footnote> A corporate name may not be changed or corrected under this section other than to correct any typographical or similar nonmaterial error.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>13►<field>fn.fnref="13"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|38|30:34"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I0042BY"</field>N-PCL &s;§105.<f_break>Research References<f_break>Correcting or curing defective incorporation, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I006VGU"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &s;§<trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace>134.</trace><f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
30:35. Types of not-for-profit corporations; purposes and powers, generally
Research References
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I009OLQ"</field>West's Key Number Digest, Corporations and Business Organizations &key;3350 to 3499
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|39|30:35"</field>Prior to its amendment, ►<field>st.ref.id="I00CHQM"</field>N-PCL &s;§ provided for four types of not-for-profit corporations: Types A, B, C, and D. These four types of not-for-profit corporations have been replaced with two types: charitable and noncharitable. A corporation formed under the N.Y. Not-for-Profit Corporation Law on or after July 1, 2014 will either be a charitable corporation or a noncharitable corporation. Any corporation formed for both charitable purposes and noncharitable purposes will be deemed a charitable corporation for purposes of the Not-For-Profit Corporation Law. A type A not-for-profit corporation formed prior to July 1, 2014 will be deemed a noncharitable corporation. Any submission or filing by such corporation to any person or entity will be deemed to have been submitted or filed by a noncharitable corporation, and any reference in any such filing or submission referring to the status of such corporation as a type A corporation will be deemed to refer to a noncharitable corporation.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>1►<field>fn.fnref="1"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|39|30:35"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I001974"</field>N-PCL &s;§201(b).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|39|30:35"</field>A type B or C not-for-profit corporation formed prior to July 1, 2014 will be deemed a charitable corporation for all purposes under the Not-For-Profit Corporation Law. Any submission or filing by such corporation to any person or entity will be deemed to have been submitted or filed by a charitable corporation, and any reference in any such filing or submission referring to the status of such corporation as a type B or type C corporation will be deemed to refer to a charitable corporation.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>2►<field>fn.fnref="2"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|39|30:35"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I001977"</field>N-PCL &s;§201(c).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|39|30:35"</field>A type D not-for-profit corporation formed prior to July 1, 2014 for charitable purposes will be deemed a charitable corporation. Any submission or filing by such corporation to any person or entity will be deemed to have been submitted or filed by a charitable corporation, and any reference in any such filing or submission referring to the status of such corporation as a type D corporation will be deemed to refer to a charitable corporation. Any other type D not-for-profit corporations formed prior to July 1, 2014 will be deemed a noncharitable corporation. Any submission or filing by such corporation to any person or entity will be deemed to have been submitted or filed by a noncharitable corporation, and any reference in any such filing or submission referring to the status of such corporation as a type D corporation will be deemed to refer to a noncharitable corporation.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>3►<field>fn.fnref="3"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|39|30:35"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I0042C3"</field>N-PCL &s;§201(d).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|39|30:35"</field>The general powers of a not-for-profit corporation are enumerated by statute and are subject to limitation by the corporation's certificate of incorporation, by the N.Y. Not-for-Profit Corporation Law, and by any other statute of the State of New York.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>4►<field>fn.fnref="4"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|39|30:35"</field>See ►<field>st.ref.id="I006VGZ"</field>N-PCL &s;§202(a).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Powers of corporations, generally, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I009OLV"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &ss;§§42<trace.deleted/><trace>1</trace> et seq.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|39|30:35"</field>A corporation organized under the N.Y. Not-for-Profit Corporation Law may not have stock or shares or certificates for stock or for shares, but may issue nontransferable membership certificates or cards to evidence membership, whether or not connected with any financial contribution to the corporation.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>5►<field>fn.fnref="5"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|39|30:35"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I00CHQR"</field>N-PCL &s;§501.<f_break>Research References<f_break>Existence and evidence of membership, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I001979"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &s;<trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace>§826</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> The fact that the corporation is a not-for-profit corporation and that the membership certificate or card is nontransferable must be noted conspicuously on the face or back of each such certificate or card.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>6►<field>fn.fnref="6"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|39|30:35"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I0042C5"</field>N-PCL &s;§501.<f_break>Research References<f_break>Existence and evidence of membership, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I006VH1"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &s;<trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace>§826</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
30:36. Relative advantage of incorporation
Research References
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I009OLX"</field>West's Key Number Digest, Corporations and Business Organizations &key;3350 to 3499
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|40|30:36"</field>Although detailed discussion of the relative advantages and disadvantages of incorporating a club or association is beyond the scope of this chapter,<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>1►<field>fn.fnref="1"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|40|30:36"</field>See discussion in Corporations ►<field>x.ref.id="I063I0Y"</field>&ss;§§17:1 et seq.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> the major factors to be taken into account may be mentioned briefly. The principal advantages of incorporating an association or club are that the corporate form provides a recognized legal entity for all purposes, including the conduct of its business activities and centralization of management, enables the club to have perpetual duration (unless a limited period is stated in the certificate of incorporation)<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>2►<field>fn.fnref="2"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|40|30:36"</field>See ►<field>st.ref.id="I05ZABM"</field>N-PCL &ss;§§202(a)(1), 402(a)(5).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Duration, generally, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I00198H"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &s;§11<trace>0</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> and affords to directors and members limited liability for debts, liabilities, and obligations of the corporation.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>3►<field>fn.fnref="3"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|40|30:36"</field>See ►<field>st.ref.id="I0042DD"</field>N-PCL &ss;§§517(a), 719.<f_break>Research References<f_break>Duties and liabilities of directors, generally, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I009ON5"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &ss;§<trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace>§683</trace> et seq.<f_break>Liabilities of members, generally, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I00198J"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &s;§97<trace.deleted/><trace>3</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|40|30:36"</field>Corporate status permits the club or association to sue and be sued in all courts and to participate in actions and proceedings, whether judicial, administrative, arbitrative, or otherwise, in like cases as natural persons;<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>4►<field>fn.fnref="4"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|40|30:36"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I0042DF"</field>N-PCL &s;§202(a)(2).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> to purchase, receive, take by grant, gift, devise, bequest or otherwise, lease or otherwise acquire, own, hold, improve, employ, use, and otherwise deal in and with, real or personal property, or any interest therein;<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>5►<field>fn.fnref="5"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|40|30:36"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I006VIB"</field>N-PCL &s;§202(a)(4).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> borrow money<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>6►<field>fn.fnref="6"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|40|30:36"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I009ON7"</field>N-PCL &s;§202(a)(9).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> or lend it;<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>7►<field>fn.fnref="7"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|40|30:36"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I00CHS3"</field>N-PCL &s;§202(a)(10).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> make contracts and give guarantees;<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>8►<field>fn.fnref="8"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|40|30:36"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I0019E7"</field>N-PCL &s;§202(a)(9).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> to be a member, associate, or manager of other nonprofit activities or to the extent permitted in any other jurisdiction to be an incorporator of other corporations;<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>9►<field>fn.fnref="9"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|40|30:36"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I0042J3"</field>N-PCL &s;§202(a)(15).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> and to exercise any corporate powers necessary or convenient to effect any of the purposes for which the corporation is formed.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>10►<field>fn.fnref="10"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|40|30:36"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I006VNZ"</field>N-PCL &s;§202(a)(16).<f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|40|30:36"</field>For a list of the general and special powers of a not-for-profit corporation, see ►<field>st.ref.id="I009OSV"</field>N-PCL &s;§202.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> Unincorporated associations may exercise some, but not all, of these powers.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>11►<field>fn.fnref="11"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|40|30:36"</field>See ►<field>x.ref.id="I00CHXR"</field>&s;§30:19.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>

 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|40|30:36"</field>A corporation whose lawful activities involve, among other things, the charging of fees or prices for its services or products has the right to receive such income and, in so doing, may make an incidental profit.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>12►<field>fn.fnref="12"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|40|30:36"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I0019E9"</field>N-PCL &s;§508.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> All such incidental profits must be applied to the maintenance, expansion, or operation of the lawful activities of the corporation and in no case may be divided or distributed in any manner whatsoever among the members, directors, or officers of the corporation.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>13►<field>fn.fnref="13"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|40|30:36"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I0019EC"</field>N-PCL &s;§508.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|40|30:36"</field>Although a not-for-profit corporation may not pay dividends or distribute any part of its income or profit to its members, directors, or officers, it may pay compensation in a reasonable amount to members, directors, or officers for services rendered,<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>14►<field>fn.fnref="14"</field><f_break>Research References<f_break>►<field>rc.ref.id="I0042J8"</field>Payment of premiums by corporation on corporate officer's life insurance policy as affecting right to policy, 56 A.L.R.3d 1086 (secs. 3(a), 3(b) superseded in part by Construction and Application of "Key Man" Life Insurance, 12 A.L.R.7th Art. 6)..<f_break>►<field>rc.ref.id="I006VO4"</field>Test in stockholders' actions as to reasonableness of compensation of corporate officers who as directors determine own compensation, 53 A.L.R.3d 358.<f_break>Compensation of directors and officers, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I009OT0"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &ss;§§7<trace>8</trace>9<trace.deleted/>, 79<trace.deleted/><trace>1</trace>.<f_break>►<field>rc.ref.id="I00CHXW"</field>Reasonableness of Corporate Officer's Compensation, 4 Am. Jur. Proof of Facts 2d 425.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> and may make distributions of cash or property to members upon dissolution or final liquidation as permitted by the N.Y. Not-for-Profit Corporation Law.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>15►<field>fn.fnref="15"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|40|30:36"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I0019EE"</field>N-PCL &s;§515.<f_break>Research References<f_break>Distribution of assets on dissolution to members, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I0042JA"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &s;§14<trace>31</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> Additionally, the corporation may confer benefits on members or nonmembers in conformity with its purposes, may redeem its capital certificates or subvention certificates, and may make other distributions in cash or property to its members or former members, directors, or officers prior to dissolution or final liquidation as permitted by the N.Y. Not-for-Profit Corp. Law.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>16►<field>fn.fnref="16"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|40|30:36"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I006VO6"</field>N-PCL &s;§515.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|40|30:36"</field>The principal disadvantage of incorporation, aside from its trouble and expense, is that the activities of an incorporated association are subject to greater regulation than those of an unincorporated association.
Practice Tip:
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|40|30:36"</field>As the foregoing discussion demonstrates, numerous factors must be taken into consideration in determining whether it is advisable to incorporate an association or club, and the practitioner is strongly advised to review all factors carefully with the client before a final decision on the form of operation (unincorporated or incorporated not-for-profit) is made.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|40|30:36"</field>If it is determined that the association or club should not be incorporated under the N.Y. Not-for-Profit Corporation Law,<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>17►<field>fn.fnref="17"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|40|30:36"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I009OT2"</field>N-PCL &ss;§§101 et seq.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> many of the forms of certificates of incorporation and bylaws and individual provisions for such forms, appearing in this division of the chapter may, with some modification, be utilized by an unincorporated association or club.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|40|30:36"</field>The discussion of incorporation in this division of the chapter is limited to incorporating under the N.Y. Not-for-Profit Corporation Law. In the event the association or club determines to incorporate pursuant to the provisions of the New York Business Corporation Law,<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>18►<field>fn.fnref="18"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|40|30:36"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I063HMO"</field>BCL &ss;§§101 et seq.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> which provides that a corporation for profit may be organized under that Law for any lawful purpose or purposes,<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>19►<field>fn.fnref="19"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|40|30:36"</field>See ►<field>st.ref.id="I0042KF"</field>BCL &s;§201.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> recourse must be had to another chapter of this work.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>20►<field>fn.fnref="20"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|40|30:36"</field>See Corporations ►<field>x.ref.id="I0019FM"</field>&ss;§§17:1 et seq.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
B. Form Drafting Principles
1. In General
30:37. Incorporation of existing association
Research References
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I0042KI"</field>West's Key Number Digest, Corporations and Business Organizations &key;3370 to 3379
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|41|30:37"</field>An unincorporated association or group may incorporate under the N.Y. Not-for-Profit Corporation Law. Where the certificate of incorporation is for the incorporation of an unincorporated association or group, the members of such association or group will automatically be members of the corporation so created, and all property owned by or held for the unincorporated association or group will automatically belong to and vest in the corporation, subject to all existing incumbrances and claims as if incorporation had not taken place.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>1►<field>fn.fnref="1"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|41|30:37"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I006VPE"</field>N-PCL &s;§403.<f_break>Research References<f_break>Specific requirements of N.Y. Not-for-Profit Corp. Law, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I0619WK"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &s;§7<trace>1</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|41|30:37"</field>A foreign corporation cannot conduct activities in New York until it has been authorized to do so as provided in the N.Y. Not-for-Profit Corporation Law.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>2►<field>fn.fnref="2"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|41|30:37"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I0056FH"</field>N-PCL &s;§1301(a).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Application of foreign corporations to conduct activities, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I007ZKD"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &s;<trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace>§216</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> Such a corporation may apply for authority to do so by filing an application signed and delivered to the Department of State.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>3►<field>fn.fnref="3"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|41|30:37"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I00ASP9"</field>N-PCL &s;§1304(a).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Application of foreign corporations to conduct activities, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I00DLU5"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &s;<trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace>§216</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|41|30:37"</field>An existing unincorporated association should duly authorize its incorporation. Because the association is an aggregation of individuals who have contracted among themselves with regard to the manner of making decisions,<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>4►<field>fn.fnref="4"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|41|30:37"</field>For definition and general background of associations, see ►<field>x.ref.id="I00GEZ1"</field>&s;§30:18.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> a vote of the membership to incorporate is suggested as a preliminary step. If the unincorporated association has a constitution or articles of association, authorization for its incorporation should be effected in the same manner as is provided in the constitution or articles for adopting amendments.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|41|30:37"</field>As part of the incorporation process, a committee of the members of the unincorporated association or group should be appointed or elected or otherwise constituted and specifically authorized to incorporate the association or group. The reason for this is that when the certificate of incorporation is filed with the Department of State, it must have attached to it an affidavit of the subscribers of the certificate stating that they constitute a majority of the members of a committee duly authorized to incorporate the association or group.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>5►<field>fn.fnref="5"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|41|30:37"</field>See ►<field>st.ref.id="I002DAO"</field>N-PCL &s;§402(b).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Specific requirements of N.Y. Not-for-Profit Corporation Law, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I0619WA"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &s;§7<trace>1</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|41|30:37"</field>All members of an unincorporated association may not favor incorporation. In this event and if they do not wish to become members of the corporation being formed, dissenting members should file their dissent in writing with the secretary of the newly formed corporation or simply resign.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>6►<field>fn.fnref="6"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|41|30:37"</field>Where the certificate of incorporation is for the incorporation of an unincorporated association or group, the members of such association or group shall be members of the corporation so created. ►<field>st.ref.id="I05X26Y"</field>N-PCL &s;§403.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|41|30:37"</field>If the association owns property or has rights under existing contracts, it is desirable that conveyances to the new corporation be executed to avoid questions as to title to such property or rights.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>7►<field>fn.fnref="7"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|41|30:37"</field>Where the certificate of incorporation is for the incorporation of an unincorporated association or group, all property owned by or held for the unincorporated association or group shall belong to and vest in the corporation, subject to all existing incumbrances and claims as if incorporation had not taken place. ►<field>st.ref.id="I007ZKI"</field>N-PCL &s;§403.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|41|30:37"</field>Furthermore, a corporation organized to take over the business of an unincorporated association or club may assume the liabilities of the association or club and thereupon become liable to the creditors of the association or club. The assumption may be either express or implied from the circumstances.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>8►<field>fn.fnref="8"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|41|30:37"</field>Where the certificate of incorporation is for the incorporation of an unincorporated association or group, all property owned by or held for the unincorporated association or group shall belong to and vest in the corporation, subject to all existing incumbrances and claims as if incorporation had not taken place. ►<field>st.ref.id="I00ASPE"</field>N-PCL &s;§403.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|41|30:37"</field>If the association has debts, accounts payable, and the like, the new corporation should formally assume them as one of the first acts of its existence.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|41|30:37"</field>Under the N.Y. Not-for-Profit Corporation Law,<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>9►<field>fn.fnref="9"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|41|30:37"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I002DAT"</field>N-PCL &ss;§§101 et seq.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> one or more incorporators may organize a not-for-profit corporation. An incorporator must be a natural person at least 18 years of age.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>10►<field>fn.fnref="10"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|41|30:37"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I0056FP"</field>N-PCL &s;§401.<f_break>Research References<f_break>Incorporators, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I007ZKL"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &s;§6<trace>7</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> The Law imposes no citizenship or residence requirements for incorporators.
30:38. Incorporation of existing association-- Formal requirements for certificate of incorporation
Research References
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I00ASPH"</field>West's Key Number Digest, Corporations and Business Organizations &key;3370 to 3379
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|42|30:38"</field>The certificate of incorporation should be drafted as nearly as possible in the form and with the content indicated in the N.Y. Not-for-Profit Corporation Law.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>1►<field>fn.fnref="1"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|42|30:38"</field>See ►<field>st.ref.id="I00DLUD"</field>N-PCL &s;§402.<f_break>Research References<f_break>Specific requirements of N.Y. Not-for-Profit Corporation Law, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I002DBY"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &s;§7<trace>1</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|42|30:38"</field>In accordance with general provisions of the Law, the certificate must be in the English language, except that the corporate name need not be in the English language if written in English letters or characters.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>2►<field>fn.fnref="2"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|42|30:38"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I002DC1"</field>N-PCL &s;§104(a).<f_break>Research References<f_break>General requirements of certificate of incorporation, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I0056GX"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &s;<trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace>§68</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|42|30:38"</field>The certificate must be entitled &ldquo;“Certificate of Incorporation of (Name of Corporation), Under ►<field>st.ref.id="I007ZLT"</field>Section 402 of the Not-for-Profit Corp. Law&rdquo;” and must be signed by each incorporator with his or her name and address included in the certificate.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>3►<field>fn.fnref="3"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|42|30:38"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I00ASQP"</field>N-PCL &s;§402(a).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Specific requirements of N.Y. Not-for-Profit Corporation Law, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I00DLVL"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &s;§7<trace>1</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> The certificate must be delivered to the Department of State.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>4►<field>fn.fnref="4"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|42|30:38"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I002DC3"</field>N-PCL &s;§402(a).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Specific requirements of N.Y. Not-for-Profit Corporation Law, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I0056GZ"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &s;§7<trace>1</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|42|30:38"</field>The certificate of incorporation becomes effective upon the filing thereof by the Department of State.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>5►<field>fn.fnref="5"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|42|30:38"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I007ZLV"</field>N-PCL &s;§104(f).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Effective date of certificate; effect of filing, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I00ASQR"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &ss;§§<trace.deleted/><trace>81, 82</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
30:39. Incorporation of existing association-- Contents
Research References
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I00DLVN"</field>West's Key Number Digest, Corporations and Business Organizations &key;3370 to 3379
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|43|30:39"</field>The N.Y. Not-for-Profit Corporation Law prescribes the minimum specific elements of a certificate of incorporation for a not-for-profit corporation.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>1►<field>fn.fnref="1"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|43|30:39"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I0619IA"</field>N-PCL &s;§402.<f_break>Research References<f_break>Specific requirements of the N.Y. Not-for-Profit Corporation Law, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I0056MM"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &s;§7<trace>1</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> These required elements are:
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|43|30:39"</field>1. The name of the corporation,<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>2►<field>fn.fnref="2"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|43|30:39"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I007ZRI"</field>N-PCL &ss;§§104(a), 402(a)(1).<f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|43|30:39"</field>For discussion of requisites of a name for a not-for-profit corporation, see ►<field>x.ref.id="I00DM1A"</field>&s;§30:46.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> which need not be in the English language, provided it is written in English letters or characters;<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>3►<field>fn.fnref="3"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|43|30:39"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I002DHT"</field>N-PCL &s;§104(a).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Limitations and conditions governing choice of name, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I0619I0"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &ss;§§1<trace>64</trace> to <trace.deleted/><trace>179</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|43|30:39"</field>2. A statement that the corporation is a corporation as defined in ►<field>st.ref.id="I05X1SO"</field>Section 102(a)(5) of the Not-for-Profit Corporation Law;<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>4►<field>fn.fnref="4"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|43|30:39"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I007ZRN"</field>N-PCL &s;§402(a)(2).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|43|30:39"</field>3. The purpose or purposes for which the corporation is formed, it being sufficient to state that the purpose of the corporation is any purpose for which corporations may be organized under the Not-for-Profit Corporation Law as a charitable or noncharitable corporation, and whether it is a charitable corporation or a noncharitable corporation under ►<field>st.ref.id="I00ASWJ"</field>N-PCL &s;§;<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>5►<field>fn.fnref="5"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|43|30:39"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I00DM1F"</field>N-PCL &s;§402(a)(2-a). Any corporation may also set forth any activities that it intends to carry out in furtherance of such purpose or purposes; provided that this will not be interpreted to require that the certificate of incorporation set forth such activities or otherwise state how the corporation's purposes will be achieved.<f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|43|30:39"</field>The purposes for which not-for-profit corporations may be organized under the Law are set forth in ►<field>st.ref.id="I00GF6B"</field>N-PCL &s;§201.<f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|43|30:39"</field>See the discussion of purposes and powers, generally, in ►<field>x.ref.id="I002DHY"</field>&s;§30:35, and the discussion concerning statement of purposes in the certificate of incorporation in ►<field>x.ref.id="I0056MU"</field>&s;§30:40.<f_break>Research References<f_break>Purposes of not-for-profit corporations, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I007ZRQ"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &ss;§§5<trace>7</trace>, <trace.deleted/><trace>58</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|43|30:39"</field>4. If it is not formed to engage in any activity or for any purpose requiring consent or approval of any state official, department, board, agency or other body, a statement that no such consent or approval is required; <footnote><footnote.body><f_break>6►<field>fn.fnref="6"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|43|30:39"</field>Such statement will be deemed conclusive for purposes of filing by the Department of State. If subsequent to submitting the certificate of incorporation for filing, the corporation plans to engage in any activity requiring consent or approval pursuant to ►<field>st.ref.id="I00ASWM"</field>N-PCL &s;§404, the corporation must obtain such consent or approval and accordingly amend its certificate of incorporation pursuant to the Not-for-Profit Corporation Law. ►<field>st.ref.id="I00DM1I"</field>N-PCL &s;§402(a)(2-b).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|43|30:39"</field>5. The county within the state in which the office of the corporation is to be located and, if desired, the post office address of an office outside the state, at which, pursuant to ►<field>st.ref.id="I0619FK"</field>N-PCL &s;§, the books and records of account of the corporation will be kept;<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>7►<field>fn.fnref="7"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|43|30:39"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I05X1Q8"</field>N-PCL &s;§402(a)(3).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Location of books and records under N.Y. Not-for-Profit Corp. Law, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I007ZSV"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &s;§3<trace.deleted/><trace>69</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|43|30:39"</field>6. The names and addresses of the initial directors;<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>8►<field>fn.fnref="8"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|43|30:39"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I002DJ6"</field>N-PCL &s;§402(a)(4).<f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|43|30:39"</field>The number of directors constituting the entire board must not be less than three. ►<field>st.ref.id="I0056O2"</field>N-PCL &s;§702(a).<f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|43|30:39"</field>Except as otherwise provided in the certificate of incorporation, the corporation must be managed by its board of directors, and each director must be at least 18 years of age, except in the case of certain specified youth groups. ►<field>st.ref.id="I007ZSY"</field>N-PCL &s;§701(a).<f_break>Research References<f_break>►<field>rc.ref.id="I002DOT"</field>Construction and effect of corporate bylaws or articles relating to change in number of directors, 3 A.L.R.3d 623.<f_break>Specific requirements of the N.Y. Not-for-Profit Corporation Law, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I0056TP"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &s;§7<trace>1</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|43|30:39"</field>7. The specific duration of the corporation unless it is intended that the duration be perpetual, in which case the certificate may remain silent on the point;<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>9►<field>fn.fnref="9"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|43|30:39"</field>See ►<field>st.ref.id="I007ZYL"</field>N-PCL &s;§402(a)(5).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Duration of corporation, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I00AT3H"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &ss;§§11<trace>0</trace>, 11<trace.deleted/><trace>1</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|43|30:39"</field>8. A designation of the Secretary of State as agent of the corporation upon whom process against it may be served and the post office address within or outside the state to which the Secretary of State can mail a copy of any process against the corporation served on the Secretary of State;<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>10►<field>fn.fnref="10"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|43|30:39"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I002DOW"</field>N-PCL &s;§402(a)(6).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Specific requirements of the N.Y. Not-for-Profit Corporation Law, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I0056TS"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &s;§7<trace>1</trace>.<f_break>Designation of agent for service of process; Secretary of State, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I007ZYO"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &ss;§§<trace.deleted/><trace>1062, 1063</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|43|30:39"</field>9. If the corporation is to have a registered agent, the agent's name and address within the state and a statement that the registered agent is to be the agent of the corporation upon whom process against the corporation may be served; and<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>11►<field>fn.fnref="11"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|43|30:39"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I00AT3K"</field>N-PCL &s;§402(a)(7).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Specific requirements of the N.Y. Not-for-Profit Corporation Law, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I00DM8G"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &s;§7<trace>1</trace>.<f_break>Designation of agent for service of process; Secretary of State, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I00GFDC"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &ss;§§<trace.deleted/><trace>1062, 1063</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|43|30:39"</field>10. Statements, if any, required in connection with special not-for-profit corporations.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>12►<field>fn.fnref="12"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|43|30:39"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I002DOY"</field>N-PCL &s;§402(a)(8).<f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|43|30:39"</field>Special not-for-profit corporations are provided for in ►<field>st.ref.id="I0056TU"</field>Article 14 of the Not-for-Profit Corp. Law (►<field>st.ref.id="I002DP0"</field>N-PCL &ss;§§1401 et seq.), which special corporations include, inter alia, cemetery corporations, medical societies, alumni corporations, historical societies, boards of trade and chambers of commerce, and local development corporations.<f_break>Research References<f_break>Specific requirements for special not-for-profit corporations, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I0056TW"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &s;§7<trace>1</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|43|30:39"</field>If the certificate is for the incorporation of an existing unincorporated association or group, it must have attached to it an affidavit of the subscribers of the certificate stating that they constitute a majority of the members of the committee duly authorized to incorporate the association or group.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>13►<field>fn.fnref="13"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|43|30:39"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I007ZYS"</field>N-PCL &s;§402(b).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Specific requirements of the N.Y. Not-for-Profit Corporation Law, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I00AT3O"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &s;§7<trace>1</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|43|30:39"</field>In addition, the certificate may include any provision, not inconsistent with law, that the incorporator(s) may choose to insert: (1) for the regulation of the internal affairs of the corporation, including types or classes of membership and the distribution of assets on dissolution or final liquidation; or (2) as required by any governmental body or officer or other person or body as a condition for giving the consent or approval required for the filing of the certificate of incorporation.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>14►<field>fn.fnref="14"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|43|30:39"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I002DQ6"</field>N-PCL &s;§402(c).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Specific requirements of the N.Y. Not-for-Profit Corporation Law, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I0056V2"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &s;§7<trace>1</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|43|30:39"</field>Furthermore, a provision may be included in the certificate specifying greater requirements as to quorum and votes of members on general matters of business or any specified item(s) of business at membership meetings.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>15►<field>fn.fnref="15"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|43|30:39"</field>See ►<field>st.ref.id="I007ZZY"</field>N-PCL &s;§615(a).<f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|43|30:39"</field>Greater requirement for quorum at meetings of members, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I00AT4U"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &s;§91<trace.deleted/><trace>4 § 1 8, 919</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> If the certificate contains such a provision, the existence of the provision must be noted conspicuously on the face or back of every membership certificate or card or capital certificate issued by the corporation.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>16►<field>fn.fnref="16"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|43|30:39"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I002DQ8"</field>N-PCL &s;§615(c).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|43|30:39"</field>There is no requirement that the certificate must set forth any of the corporate powers enumerated in the N.Y. Not-for-Profit Corporation Law.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>17►<field>fn.fnref="17"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|43|30:39"</field>General and special powers of not-for-profit corporations are set forth in ►<field>st.ref.id="I0056V4"</field>N-PCL &s;§202.<f_break>Research References<f_break>Powers and functions of corporations, generally, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I008000"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &s;§42<trace>1</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
30:40. Incorporation of existing association-- Statement of purposes
Research References
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I00AT4W"</field>West's Key Number Digest, Corporations and Business Organizations &key;3370 to 3379
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|44|30:40"</field>A corporation may be formed for various purposes under the N.Y. Not-for-Profit Corporation Law.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>1►<field>fn.fnref="1"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|44|30:40"</field>See ►<field>x.ref.id="I002DQB"</field>&s;§30:35 for a discussion of purposes for which a not-for-profit corporation may be formed.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|44|30:40"</field>The purpose or purposes for which a not-for-profit corporation may be formed may not include pecuniary profit or financial gain, and no part of the assets, income, or profits of the corporation may be distributable to or enure to the benefit of its members, directors, or officers, except to the extent permitted under the N.Y. Not-for-Profit Corporation Law.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>2►<field>fn.fnref="2"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|44|30:40"</field>See ►<field>st.ref.id="I0056V7"</field>N-PCL &ss;§§102(a)(5), 201(a).<f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|44|30:40"</field>Although a not-for-profit corporation may not pay dividends or distribute any part of its income or profits to its members, directors, or officers, it may pay compensation in a reasonable amount to members, directors, or officers for services rendered and may make distributions of cash or property to members upon dissolution or final liquidation as permitted by the N.Y. Not-for-Profit Corporation Law. ►<field>st.ref.id="I002DVY"</field>N-PCL &s;§515.<f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|44|30:40"</field>A corporation whose lawful activities involve, among other things, the charging of fees or prices for its services or products has the right to receive such income and, in so doing, may make an incidental profit. All such incidental profits must be applied to the maintenance, expansion, or operation of the lawful activities of the corporation and in no case may be divided or distributed in any manner whatsoever among the members, directors, or officers of the corporation. ►<field>st.ref.id="I00570U"</field>N-PCL &s;§508.<f_break>Research References<f_break>Purposes of not-for-profit corporations, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I00805Q"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &ss;§§5<trace>7</trace>, <trace.deleted/><trace>58</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|44|30:40"</field>The certificate of incorporation of the not-for-profit corporation must set forth the specific purpose or purposes for which the corporation is formed.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>3►<field>fn.fnref="3"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|44|30:40"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I00ATAM"</field>N-PCL &s;§402(a)(2).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Specific requirements of the N.Y. Not-for-Profit Corporation Law, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I00DMFI"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &s;§7<trace>1</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> A corporation formed under the Not-for-Profit Corporation Law on or after July 1, 2014 will either be a charitable corporation or a noncharitable corporation. Any corporation formed for both charitable purposes and noncharitable purposes will be deemed a charitable corporation for purposes of the law.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>4►<field>fn.fnref="4"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|44|30:40"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I00GFKE"</field>N-PCL &s;§201(b). Under the Not-for-Profit Corporation Law, a type A not-for-profit corporation formed prior to July 1, 2014 will be deemed a noncharitable corporation. ►<field>st.ref.id="I002DW1"</field>N-PCL &s;§201(b). A type B or C not-for-profit corporation formed prior to July 1, 2014 will be deemed a charitable corporation for all purposes under this chapter. ►<field>st.ref.id="I00570X"</field>N-PCL &s;§201(c). A type D not-for-profit corporation formed prior to July 1, 2014 for charitable purposes will be deemed a charitable corporation. Any other type D not-for-profit corporations formed prior to July 1, 2014 will be deemed a noncharitable corporation. ►<field>st.ref.id="I00805T"</field>N-PCL &s;§201(d).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Purposes of not-for-profit corporations, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I00ATAP"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &ss;§§5<trace>7</trace>, <trace.deleted/><trace>58</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>

 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|45|30:41"</field>The filing fee, which is subject to change, for a certificate of incorporation is $75.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>3►<field>fn.fnref="3"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|45|30:41"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I005712"</field>N-PCL &s;§104-A(e).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>

 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|45|30:41"</field>Corporate existence begins upon the filing of the certificate of incorporation by the Department of State.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>6►<field>fn.fnref="6"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|45|30:41"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I005727"</field>N-PCL &s;§403.<f_break>Research References<f_break>Commencement of existence, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I008073"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &s;§<trace.deleted/><trace>109</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> The certificate will be conclusive evidence that all conditions precedent have been fulfilled and that the corporation has been formed under the N.Y. Not-for-Profit Corporation Law, except in an action or special proceeding brought by the Attorney General.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>7►<field>fn.fnref="7"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|45|30:41"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I00ATBZ"</field>N-PCL &s;§403.<f_break>Research References<f_break>Evidentiary effect of certificate, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I00DMGV"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &s;§85.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> Where the certificate is for the incorporation of an unincorporated association or group, the members of such association or group shall be members of the corporation so created, and all property owned by or held for it shall belong to and vest in the corporation, subject to all existing encumbrances and claims as if the incorporation had not taken place.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>8►<field>fn.fnref="8"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|45|30:41"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I002DXD"</field>N-PCL &s;§403.<f_break>Research References<f_break>Effect on incorporation of unincorporated group, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I005729"</field>N.Y.  ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|45|30:41"</field>The Department of State will make, certify, and transmit electronically a copy of the certificate of incorporation to the clerk of the county in which the office of the corporation is or is to be located.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>9►<field>fn.fnref="9"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|45|30:41"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I002E31"</field>N-PCL &s;§104(g).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> The county clerk will file and index such copy.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>10►<field>fn.fnref="10"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|45|30:41"</field>See ►<field>st.ref.id="I00577X"</field>N-PCL &s;§104(g).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
30:42. Incorporation of existing association-- Amendment; restated certificate of incorporation
Research References
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I0080CT"</field>West's Key Number Digest, Corporations and Business Organizations &key;3370 to 3379
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|46|30:42"</field>A not-for-profit corporation may amend its certificate of incorporation in any and as many respects as may be desired, as long as the amendment contains only such provisions as might lawfully be contained in the original certificate of incorporation at the time of amendment.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>1►<field>fn.fnref="1"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|46|30:42"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I00ATHP"</field>N-PCL &s;§801(a).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Amendment of certificate of incorporation, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I0618BK"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &ss;§§<trace.deleted/><trace>143 to 157</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|46|30:42"</field>The procedure to amend the certificate of incorporation is set forth in the N.Y. Not-for-Profit Corporation Law. If there are members entitled to vote thereon, an amendment may be adopted by a majority vote of such members at a meeting of members.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>2►<field>fn.fnref="2"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|46|30:42"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I00577Z"</field>N-PCL &s;§802(a)(1).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Procedure for effecting amendment or change of certificate of incorporation, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I0080CV"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &ss;§§<trace.deleted/><trace>147 to 153</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> If there are no members entitled to vote thereon, an amendment may be adopted by a majority of the entire board.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>3►<field>fn.fnref="3"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|46|30:42"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I00ATHR"</field>N-PCL &s;§802(a)(2).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Procedure for effecting amendment or change of certificate of incorporation, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I00DMMN"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &ss;§§<trace.deleted/><trace>147 to 153</trace>.<f_break>Authorization of amendment or change of certificate of incorporation by board of directors, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I002E36"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &s;<trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace>§150</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|46|30:42"</field>Any one or more of the following changes may be authorized by or pursuant to authorization of the board:
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|46|30:42"</field>1. To specify or change the location of the office of the corporation;
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|46|30:42"</field>2. To specify or change the post office address to which the Secretary of State can mail a copy of any notice required by law; and
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|46|30:42"</field>3. To make, revoke, or change the designation of a registered agent or to specify or change the address of its registered agent.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>4►<field>fn.fnref="4"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|46|30:42"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I002E38"</field>N-PCL &s;§802(c).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Authorization of amendment or change of certificate of incorporation by board of directors, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I005784"</field>N.Y.  ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|46|30:42"</field>To accomplish any amendment, a certificate of amendment entitled &ldquo;“Certificate of Amendment of the Certificate of Incorporation of (Name of Corporation) Under ►<field>st.ref.id="I0080D0"</field>Section 803 of the Not-for-Profit Corporation Law&rdquo;” must be signed and delivered to the Department of State.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>5►<field>fn.fnref="5"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|46|30:42"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I00ATHW"</field>N-PCL &s;§803(a).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Procedure for effecting amendment or change of certificate of incorporation, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I00DMMS"</field>N.Y.
