 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|46|30:42"</field>The Department of State will make, certify, and transmit electronically a copy of the certificate of amendment to the county in which the office of the corporation is located.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>7►<field>fn.fnref="7"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|46|30:42"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I00ATJ2"</field>N-PCL &s;§104(g).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|46|30:42"</field>A corporation, when authorized by the board, may restate in a single certificate the text of its certificate of incorporation without making any amendment or change thereby, except that it may include any one or more of the amendments or changes that may be authorized by the board without a vote of members.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>8►<field>fn.fnref="8"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|46|30:42"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I00DMNY"</field>N-PCL &s;§805(a).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Restated certificate of incorporation, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I00GFSU"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &ss;§§<trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace>156, 157</trace><f_break></footnote.body></footnote> Alternatively, a corporation may restate in a single certificate the text of its certificate of incorporation as amended thereby to effect any one or more of the amendments or changes authorized by the N.Y. Not-for-Profit Corporation Law, when authorized by a vote of a membership class.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>9►<field>fn.fnref="9"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|46|30:42"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I002E4G"</field>N-PCL &s;§805(a).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Restated certificate of incorporation, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I00579C"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &ss;§§<trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace>156, 157</trace><f_break></footnote.body></footnote> Upon filing by the Department of State, the original certificate of incorporation will be superseded and the restated certificate of incorporation, including any amendments and changes made thereby, will be the corporation's certificate of incorporation.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>10►<field>fn.fnref="10"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|46|30:42"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I0080E8"</field>N-PCL &s;§805(f).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Restated certificate of incorporation, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I00ATJ4"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &ss;§§<trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace>156, 157</trace><f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|46|30:42"</field>To accomplish such restatement, a restated certificate of incorporation entitled &ldquo;“Restated Certificate of Incorporation of (Name of Corporation) Under ►<field>st.ref.id="I06188Q"</field>Section 805 of the Not-for-Profit Corporation Law&rdquo;” must be signed and delivered to the Department of State. The contents of the certificate are enumerated in the statute.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>11►<field>fn.fnref="11"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|46|30:42"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I05X0JE"</field>N-PCL &s;§805(b).<f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|46|30:42"</field>For execution requirements, see ►<field>x.ref.id="I05SSU2"</field>&s;§30:34.<f_break>Research References<f_break>Contents of restated certificate of incorporation, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I002EA6"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &ss;§§<trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace>156, 157</trace><f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|46|30:42"</field>The Department of State will make, certify, and transmit electronically a copy of the restated certificate of incorporation to the county in which the office of the corporation is located.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>12►<field>fn.fnref="12"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|46|30:42"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I0057F2"</field>N-PCL &s;§104(g).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|46|30:42"</field>If the restated certificate merely restates the text of the certificate of incorporation without making any amendment or change, then the certificate should include a statement that the text of the certificate of incorporation, as amended, is thereby restated without further amendment or change to read as therein set forth in full.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>13►<field>fn.fnref="13"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|46|30:42"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I0080JY"</field>N-PCL &s;§805(b)(3).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Restated certificate of incorporation, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I00ATOU"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &ss;§§<trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace>156, 157</trace><f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|46|30:42"</field>If the restated certificate restates the text of the certificate of incorporation as amended or changed thereby, then the restated certificate should include a statement that the certificate of incorporation is amended or changed to effect one or more of the amendments or changes authorized by the N.Y. Not-for-Profit Corporation Law, specifying each such amendment or change and that the text of the certificate of incorporation is thereby restated as amended or changed to read as therein set forth in full.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>14►<field>fn.fnref="14"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|46|30:42"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I00DMTQ"</field>N-PCL &s;§805(b)(4).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Restated certificate of incorporation, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I0617XA"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &ss;§§<trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace>156, 157</trace><f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|46|30:42"</field>A restated certificate of incorporation need not include statements as to the incorporator(s) or as to the first directors.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>15►<field>fn.fnref="15"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|46|30:42"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I05X07Y"</field>N-PCL &s;§805(c).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Restated certificate of incorporation, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I05SSIM"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &ss;§§<trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace>156, 157</trace><f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
30:43. Bylaws
Research References
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I00ATOW"</field>West's Key Number Digest, Corporations and Business Organizations &key;3384
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|47|30:43"</field>The term &ldquo;“bylaws&rdquo;” for a not-for-profit corporation means the code of rules adopted for the regulation or management of the affairs of the corporation, irrespective of the name by which such rules are designated.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>1►<field>fn.fnref="1"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|47|30:43"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I002EAB"</field>N-PCL &s;§102(a)(2).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> They serve the same purpose as do bylaws of a corporation for profit. They set forth the details of internal government with respect to the membership structure and details concerning regulation of the corporation's trustees and officers. Any provision that might properly be included in the bylaws may be incorporated in the certificate of incorporation. The day-to-day regulation of corporate affairs is, however, generally specified in the bylaws, allowing the certificate to be kept as simple as possible.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>2►<field>fn.fnref="2"</field><f_break>Research References<f_break>Bylaws of not-for-profit corporations, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I0057F7"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &s;<trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace>§118</trace>.<f_break>Bylaws, generally, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I0617X0"</field>Am. Jur. 2d, Corporations &ss;§§252 to 271.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
Practice Tip:
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|47|30:43"</field>Bylaws should be distinguished from corporate resolutions. Although a bylaw may be adopted by resolution, once adopted, the bylaw becomes a continuing and permanent rule. Conversely, a resolution is usually confined to a single corporate act.
30:44. Bylaws-- Contents
Research References
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I05X07O"</field>West's Key Number Digest, Corporations and Business Organizations &key;3384
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|48|30:44"</field>The bylaws may contain any provision relating to the business of the corporation, the conduct of its affairs, its rights or powers, or the rights or powers of its members, directors, or officers, not inconsistent with law or the certificate of incorporation.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>1►<field>fn.fnref="1"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|48|30:44"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I05SSIC"</field>N-PCL &s;§602(f).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> The certificate of incorporation may set forth any provision, not inconsistent with the N.Y. Not-for-Profit Corporation Law or any other statute of the State of New York, which provision is for the regulation of the internal affairs of the corporation, including types or classes of membership and the distribution of assets on dissolution or final liquidation, or required by any governmental body or officer or other person or body as a condition for giving the consent or approval required for the filing of the certificate of incorporation.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>2►<field>fn.fnref="2"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|48|30:44"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I00ATP1"</field>N-PCL &s;§402(c).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
Practice Tip:
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|48|30:44"</field>It should be noted as a practical consideration that whether particular matters should be treated in the certificate of incorporation or in the bylaws depends to some extent on such factors as the size of the corporation and the desired amount of membership regulation. Generally, the more routine matters involved in governing a corporation should be placed in the bylaws. Where there is a choice between putting provisions in the bylaws or the certificate, the bylaws will sometimes be chosen because they are not a matter of public record. In this connection, it should be noted that amendment of the certificate is considerably more difficult than amendment of the bylaws.
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|48|30:44"</field>In order to be valid and binding, a bylaw must not disturb vested rights or impair the obligation of a contract, take away or abridge substantial rights of a member, affect rights of property, or create an obligation unknown to the law. Furthermore, a bylaw must be a general regulation affecting all the members alike; it cannot be directed against a single member. Any bylaw must have a rational nexus to the organization's purpose, be nondiscriminatory in its application, and refrain from depriving members of any right expressly granted in the basic agreement and not made expressly subject to revision of a so-called vested right. Nevertheless, it is not true that a bylaw must never modify or vary rights of individuals; if such were the case, no valid bylaw whatever could be made.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>3►<field>fn.fnref="3"</field><f_break>Research References<f_break>General requisites and validity of bylaws, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I002EBJ"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &ss;§§12<trace>0</trace> to 12<trace.deleted/><trace>3</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
30:45. Bylaws-- Adoption, amendment, and repeal
Research References
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I0057GF"</field>West's Key Number Digest, Corporations and Business Organizations &key;3384
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|49|30:45"</field>The initial bylaws of a corporation may be adopted by its incorporators at its organization meeting and, if not so adopted by its incorporators, by its board of directors.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>1►<field>fn.fnref="1"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|49|30:45"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I002EBL"</field>N-PCL &s;§602(a).<f_break><trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><f_break><trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|49|30:45"</field>The N.Y. Not-for-Profit Corporation Law provides different methods for the adoption of new bylaws. Bylaws may be adopted by the members of the not-for-profit corporation entitled to vote at that time in the election of directors and, unless otherwise provided in the certificate of incorporation or the bylaws adopted by the members, by the board of directors.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>2►<field>fn.fnref="2"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|49|30:45"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I002EH9"</field>N-PCL &s;§602(b).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> If so provided in some other law of the state, any governmental body or officer authorized by such law to supervise a not-for-profit corporation created under such law may adopt bylaws.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>3►<field>fn.fnref="3"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|49|30:45"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I0057M5"</field>N-PCL &s;§602(d).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|49|30:45"</field>Any bylaw adopted by the board may be amended or repealed by the members and, unless otherwise provided in the certificate of incorporation or the bylaws adopted by the members, any bylaw adopted by the members may be amended or repealed by the board.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>4►<field>fn.fnref="4"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|49|30:45"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I0080R1"</field>N-PCL &s;§602(c).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Amendment or repeal of bylaws, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I00ATVX"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &s;§129.<f_break>Amendment or repeal of bylaws, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I00DN0T"</field>Am. Jur. 2d, Corporations &ss;§§266 to 269.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|49|30:45"</field>If any bylaws regulating an impending election of directors is adopted, amended, or repealed by the board, there must be set forth in the notice of the next meeting of members for the election of directors the bylaw so adopted, amended, or repealed, together with a concise statement of the changes made.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>5►<field>fn.fnref="5"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|49|30:45"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I002EHB"</field>N-PCL &s;§602(e).<f_break><f_break><trace>6 N-PCL &s; § 602(g) .</trace><f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
<trace>In the case of residential not-for-profit corporations, changes including the adoption, amendment or repeal of the bylaws by the board of directors must be provided to the members, stockholders, and delegates of such corporation in writing, by physical or electronic means, within ten days of such adoption.</trace>
Practice Tip:
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|49|30:45"</field>The original, or a copy, of the bylaws as amended or otherwise altered, certified by the secretary of the corporation, should be kept at the principal office of the corporation.
30:46. Corporate name; reservation; change
Research References
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I0057M7"</field>West's Key Number Digest, Corporations and Business Organizations &key;3382
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|50|30:46"</field>The selection of a distinctive corporate name will be one of the first tasks of the incorporators, and it should be noted that certain statutory requirements and limitations<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>1►<field>fn.fnref="1"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|50|30:46"</field>See ►<field>st.ref.id="I0080R3"</field>N-PCL &s;§301.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> must be taken into account in making the selection. The corporate name need not be in the English language as long as it is written in English letters or characters.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>2►<field>fn.fnref="2"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|50|30:46"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I00ATVZ"</field>N-PCL &s;§104(a).<f_break>Research References<f_break>►<field>rc.ref.id="I0617J0"</field>Use of &ldquo;“family name&rdquo;” by corporation as unfair competition, 72 A.L.R.3d 8.<f_break>►<field>rc.ref.id="I05WZTO"</field>Incorporation of company under particular name as creating exclusive right to such name, 68 A.L.R.3d 1168.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|50|30:46"</field>According to statute, the corporate name must:
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|50|30:46"</field>(a) Contain the word &ldquo;“corporation,&rdquo;” &ldquo;“incorporated,&rdquo;”&ldquo;“limited&rdquo;” or an abbreviation of one of such words, unless the corporation is formed for charitable or religious purposes or for purposes requiring special approval or is a bar association;<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>3►<field>fn.fnref="3"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|50|30:46"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I002EHG"</field>N-PCL &s;§301(a)(1).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|50|30:46"</field>(b) Be such as to distinguish it from the names of corporations of any kind, or a fictitious name of an authorized foreign corporation, as such names appear on the Department of State's index of names of existing domestic and authorized foreign corporations of any kind, including fictitious names of authorized foreign corporations;<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>4►<field>fn.fnref="4"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|50|30:46"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I0057MC"</field>N-PCL &s;§301(a)(2).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|50|30:46"</field>(c) Not contain any word or phrase or any abbreviation or derivative of a word or phrase, the use of which is prohibited or restricted by statute;<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>5►<field>fn.fnref="5"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|50|30:46"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I0080R8"</field>N-PCL &s;§301(a)(3).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|50|30:46"</field>(d) Not contain any word or phrase, or any abbreviation or derivative of a word or phrase, in a context that indicates or implies that the corporation is formed or authorized for any purpose or is possessed in the state of any power other than a purpose for which, or a power with which, the domestic corporation may be and is formed or the foreign corporation is authorized;<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>6►<field>fn.fnref="6"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|50|30:46"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I00ATW4"</field>N-PCL &s;§301(a)(4).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|50|30:46"</field>(e) Not, with certain exceptions, contain any of the proscribed words or phrases, or any abbreviation or derivative of such words or phrases, to include &ldquo;“bank,&rdquo;” &ldquo;“casualty,&rdquo;” &ldquo;“doctor,&rdquo;” &ldquo;“endowment,&rdquo;” &ldquo;“insurance,&rdquo;” &ldquo;“lawyer,&rdquo;”&ldquo;“underwriter&rdquo;”;<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>7►<field>fn.fnref="7"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|50|30:46"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I00DN10"</field>N-PCL &s;§301(a)(5).<f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|50|30:46"</field>The use of the words listed is permitted if certain requirements are met. See ►<field>st.ref.id="I0617IQ"</field>N-PCL &s;§301(a)(5)(B).<f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|50|30:46"</field>The word &ldquo;“doctor&rdquo;” has special ramifications governing its use. See ►<field>st.ref.id="I05WZTE"</field>N-PCL &s;§301(a)(5)(B), (9).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|50|30:46"</field>(f) Not contain any word or phrase, or any abbreviation or derivative of a word or phrase, in a context that will tend to mislead the public into believing that the corporation is an agency or instrumentality of the United States or the State of New York, or a subdivision of such entities, or is a public corporation;<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>8►<field>fn.fnref="8"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|50|30:46"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I002EIO"</field>N-PCL &s;§301(a)(6).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|50|30:46"</field>(g) Not contain the word &ldquo;“cooperative&rdquo;” or an abbreviation, contraction, or derivative of such word.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>9►<field>fn.fnref="9"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|50|30:46"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I0057NK"</field>N-PCL &s;§301(a)(7).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|50|30:46"</field>(h) Not contain any word or phrase, or any abbreviation or derivation of a word or phrase, that, separately or in context, is indecent or obscene or ridicules or degrades any person, group, belief, business, or agency of government or indicates or implies any unlawful activity;<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>10►<field>fn.fnref="10"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|50|30:46"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I0080SG"</field>N-PCL &s;§301(a)(8).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|50|30:46"</field>After having determined that a given name is available for use, counsel should arrange to reserve it. A corporate name may be reserved by: (1) any person intending to form a domestic corporation; (2) any domestic corporation intending to change its name; (3) any foreign corporation intending to apply for authority to conduct activities in New York; (4) any authorized foreign corporation intending to change its name; (5) any person intending to incorporate a foreign corporation and to have it apply for authority to conduct activities in New York; (6) any domestic corporation intending to file the consent of the Attorney General to reinstate such corporation pursuant to the Not-for-Profit Corporation Law.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>11►<field>fn.fnref="11"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|50|30:46"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I0617GA"</field>N-PCL &s;§303(a).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|50|30:46"</field>A fictitious name for use as an authorized foreign corporation may be reserved by: (1) any foreign corporation intending to apply for authority to do business in the State of New York; (2) any authorized foreign corporation intending to change its fictitious name under which it conducts activities in this state; and (3) any authorized foreign corporation which has changed its corporate name in its jurisdiction, which new corporate name is not available in this state.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>12►<field>fn.fnref="12"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|50|30:46"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I05WZQY"</field>N-PCL &s;§303(b).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|50|30:46"</field>An application to reserve a corporate name must be delivered to the Department of State. The application must set forth the applicant's name and address, the name to be reserved, and a statement of the basis under ►<field>st.ref.id="I05SS1M"</field>Section 303 of the Law for the application,<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>13►<field>fn.fnref="13"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|50|30:46"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I00ATXE"</field>N-PCL &s;§303(c).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> for example, that the basis for the application is that the applicant is a person intending to form a domestic corporation. The Secretary of State may require the applicant to set forth in the application the nature of the activities to be conducted by the corporation.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>14►<field>fn.fnref="14"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|50|30:46"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I00DN2A"</field>N-PCL &s;§303(c).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> The application must be signed by the applicant or the applicant's attorney or agent.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>15►<field>fn.fnref="15"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|50|30:46"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I00GG76"</field>N-PCL &s;§303(f).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> The fee for filing an application for reservation of a corporate name, which is subject to change, is $10.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>16►<field>fn.fnref="16"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|50|30:46"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I002EOE"</field>N-PCL &s;§104-A(b).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|50|30:46"</field>If the name is available for corporate use, the Department of State will reserve the name for the applicant's use for a period of 60 days and issue a certificate of reservation.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>17►<field>fn.fnref="17"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|50|30:46"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I0057TA"</field>N-PCL &s;§303(c).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> The certificate of reservation (or in lieu thereof an affidavit by the applicant or by the applicant's agent or attorney that the certificate of reservation has been lost or destroyed) must accompany the certificate of incorporation or the application for authority when it is delivered to the Department of State.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>18►<field>fn.fnref="18"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|50|30:46"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I002EOG"</field>N-PCL &s;§303(c).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|50|30:46"</field>The Secretary of State may extend the reservation for additional periods of not more than 60 days each, upon the written request of the applicant, or the applicant's attorney or agent, delivered to the Department of State, to be filed before the expiration of the reservation period then in effect.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>19►<field>fn.fnref="19"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|50|30:46"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I0057TC"</field>N-PCL &s;§303(d).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> The request must have attached to it the certificate of reservation of name.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>20►<field>fn.fnref="20"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|50|30:46"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I0080Y8"</field>N-PCL &s;§303(d).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> No more than two such extensions will be granted.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>21►<field>fn.fnref="21"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|50|30:46"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I00AU34"</field>N-PCL &s;§303(d).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|50|30:46"</field>Upon the applicant's request, delivered to the Department of State before the expiration of the reserved period, together with the certificate of reservation, the Department will cancel the reservation.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>22►<field>fn.fnref="22"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|50|30:46"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I00DN80"</field>N-PCL &s;§303(e).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|50|30:46"</field>A corporation may change its name by amending its certificate of incorporation.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>23►<field>fn.fnref="23"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|50|30:46"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I002EOJ"</field>N-PCL &s;§801(b)(1).<f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|50|30:46"</field>For discussion concerning amendment of certificate of incorporation, see ►<field>x.ref.id="I0057TF"</field>&s;§30:42.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
30:47. Secretary of State as designated agent for service of process; registered agent
Research References
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I0080YB"</field>West's Key Number Digest, Corporations and Business Organizations &key;3459
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I00AU37"</field>West's Key Number Digest, Corporations and Business Organizations &key;3494
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|51|30:47"</field>The Secretary of State is the agent of every domestic corporation formed under the N.Y. Not-for-Profit Corporation Law and every authorized foreign corporation upon whom process against the corporation may be served.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>1►<field>fn.fnref="1"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|51|30:47"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I00DN83"</field>N-PCL &s;§304(a).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Specific requirements of the N.Y. Practice Tip:
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|51|30:47"</field>The certificate of incorporation must contain a provision designating the Secretary of State as agent of the corporation upon whom process against it may be served and a post office address within or outside the state to which the Secretary of State can mail a copy of any process against the corporation served on the Secretary of State.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>2►<field>fn.fnref="2"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|51|30:47"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I06172A"</field>N-PCL &s;§402(a)(6).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Specific requirements of the N.Y. Not-for-Profit Corporation Law, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I05WZCY"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &s;§7<trace>1</trace>.<f_break>Designation of agent for service of process; Secretary of State, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I05SRNM"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &ss;§§<trace.deleted/><trace>1062, 1063</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|51|30:47"</field>Additionally, a domestic corporation organized under the N.Y. Not-for-Profit Corp. Law and a foreign corporation authorized to conduct activities in New York may designate a registered agent in the State of New York upon whom process against the corporation may be served.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>3►<field>fn.fnref="3"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|51|30:47"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I00AU4E"</field>N-PCL &s;§305(a).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Designation of agent for service of process, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I00DN9A"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &ss;§§<trace.deleted/><trace>1062, 1063</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> The agent must be a natural person who is a resident of or has a business address in the State of New York or a domestic corporation or a foreign corporation of any type or kind formed or authorized to do business in the state under the N.Y. Not-for-Profit Corporation Law or under any other statute of the State of New York.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>4►<field>fn.fnref="4"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|51|30:47"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I00GGE6"</field>N-PCL &s;§305(a).<f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|51|30:47"</field>As to statutory provisions concerning service of process on a registered agent, see ►<field>st.ref.id="I002EPT"</field>N-PCL &s;§306.<f_break>Research References<f_break>Designation of agent for service of process, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I0057UP"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &ss;§§<trace.deleted/><trace>1062, 1063</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> The designation of a registered agent, with the agent's name and address and a statement that the registered agent is to be the agent of the corporation upon whom process against it may be served, is made in the certificate of incorporation.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>5►<field>fn.fnref="5"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|51|30:47"</field>See ►<field>st.ref.id="I0080ZL"</field>N-PCL &ss;§§305(b), 402(a)(7).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Specific requirements of the N.Y. Not-for-Profit Corporation Law, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I00DN9D"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &s;§7<trace>1</trace>.<f_break>Designation of agent for service of process; Secretary of State, see ►<field>rc.ref.id="I00GGE9"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &ss;§§<trace.deleted/><trace>1062, 1063</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> The designation of a registered agent may be made, revoked, or changed, or the address of the registered agent may be specified or changed by amendment of the corporation's certificate of incorporation.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>6►<field>fn.fnref="6"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|51|30:47"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I061720"</field>N-PCL &ss;§§305(b), 801(b)(8).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Amendment of certificate of incorporation, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I0080ZN"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &ss;§§<trace.deleted/><trace>143 to 157</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|51|30:47"</field>A change in the certificate of incorporation making, revoking, or changing the designation of a registered agent or specifying or changing the address of a registered agent may be authorized by or pursuant to authorization of the board of directors.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>7►<field>fn.fnref="7"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|51|30:47"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I00AU4J"</field>N-PCL &s;§802(c)(3).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Authorization of amendment or change of certificate of incorporation by board of directors, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I002EVJ"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &s;<trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace>§150</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> Such a change may be accomplished by filing a certificate of change, entitled &ldquo;“Certificate of Change of (Name of Corporation) Under ►<field>st.ref.id="I00580F"</field>Section 803-A of the Not-for-Profit Corporation Law.&rdquo;”<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>8►<field>fn.fnref="8"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|51|30:47"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I00815B"</field>N-PCL &s;§803-A.<f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|51|30:47"</field>The fee for filing a certificate of change, which is subject to change, is $20. ►<field>st.ref.id="I00AUA7"</field>N-PCL &s;§104-A(g).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Certificate of amendment or change; requisites and filing, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I0616QK"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &ss;§§<trace.deleted/><trace>154, 155</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> The certificate of change must set forth the corporation's name and if it has been changed the name under which it was formed, the date its certificate of incorporation was filed by the Department of State, each change effected thereby, and the manner in which the change was authorized.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>9►<field>fn.fnref="9"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|51|30:47"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I05WZ18"</field>N-PCL &s;§803-A(a).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Contents of certificate of change, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I05SRBW"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &s;§15<trace>4</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> A certificate of change which changes only the post office address to which the Secretary of State shall mail a copy of any process against the corporation served upon him or her or the registered agent's address, provided the address being changed is the address of a person, partnership, or other corporation whose address, as agent, is the address to be changed or who has been designated as registered agent for such corporation, may be signed and delivered to the Department of State by such agent.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>10►<field>fn.fnref="10"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|51|30:47"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I05OJMK"</field>N-PCL &s;§803-A(b).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Contents of certificate of change, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I00DNF5"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &s;§15<trace>4</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> In addition to the above requirements for the certificate of change, the certificate must include statements that notice of the proposed change was mailed to the corporation by the party signing the certificate not less than 30 days prior to the date of delivery to the Department and that the corporation has not objected thereto and that the party signing the certificate is the agent of the corporation to whose address the Secretary of State is required to mail copies of any process against the corporation served upon him or her or the registered agent, if such be the case.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>11►<field>fn.fnref="11"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|51|30:47"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I00GGK1"</field>N-PCL &s;§803-A(b).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Contents of certificate of change, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I002EVO"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &s;§15<trace>4</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> Such a certificate signed and delivered will not be deemed to effect a change of location of the office of the corporation in whose behalf the certificate is filed.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>12►<field>fn.fnref="12"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|51|30:47"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I00580K"</field>N-PCL &s;§803-A(b).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Contents of certificate of change, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I00815G"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &s;§15<trace>4</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|51|30:47"</field>A registered agent may resign as such agent by delivering to the Department of State a certificate, entitled &ldquo;“Certificate of Resignation of Registered Agent of (Name of Designating Corporation) Under ►<field>st.ref.id="I00AUAC"</field>Section 305 of the Not-for-Profit Corporation Law.&rdquo;”<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>13►<field>fn.fnref="13"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|51|30:47"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I002EVQ"</field>N-PCL &s;§305(c).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> The certificate must be signed by the registered agent and must contain the following provisions:
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|51|30:47"</field>(a) that he or she resigns as registered agent for the designating corporation;
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|51|30:47"</field>(b) the date the certificate of incorporation or the application for authority of the designating corporation was filed by the Department of State; and
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|51|30:47"</field>(c) that the agent has sent a copy of the certificate of resignation by registered mail to the designating corporation at the post office address on file in the Department of State specified for the mailing of process or, if such address is the address of the registered agent, then to the office of the designating corporation in the jurisdiction of its formation or incorporation.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>14►<field>fn.fnref="14"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|51|30:47"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I00580M"</field>N-PCL &s;§305(c).<f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|51|30:47"</field>The fee for filing a certificate of resignation, which is subject to change, is $30. ►<field>st.ref.id="I00815I"</field>N-PCL &s;§104-A(c).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|51|30:47"</field>The designation of a registered agent will terminate 30 days after the filing by the Department of State of a certificate of resignation or a certificate containing a revocation or change of the designation, whichever is filed earlier.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>15►<field>fn.fnref="15"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|51|30:47"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I002EWW"</field>N-PCL &s;§305(d).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> A certificate designating a new registered agent may be delivered to the Department of State by the corporation within such 30-day period or thereafter.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>16►<field>fn.fnref="16"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|51|30:47"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I00581S"</field>N-PCL &s;§305(d).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
30:48. Corporate management
Research References
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I00816O"</field>West's Key Number Digest, Corporations and Business Organizations &key;3420 to 3439
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|52|30:48"</field>The activities of a not-for-profit corporation must be managed by a board of directors, except as otherwise provided in the N.Y. Not-for-Profit Corporation Law or in the corporation's certificate of incorporation.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>1►<field>fn.fnref="1"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|52|30:48"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I00AUBK"</field>N-PCL &s;§701.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> The directors must be at least 18 years of age, except in the case of certain specified youth groups.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>2►<field>fn.fnref="2"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|52|30:48"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I00DNGG"</field>N-PCL &s;§701.<f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|52|30:48"</field>Unless otherwise provided in the certificate of incorporation or bylaws, the board of directors has the authority to establish reasonable compensation of the corporation's members, directors, and officers for services rendered. See ►<field>st.ref.id="I002EWY"</field>N-PCL &s;§515(b).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Specific requirements of the N.Y. Not-for-Profit Corporation Law, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I00581U"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &s;§7<trace>1</trace>.<f_break>Rights, duties, and liabilities of directors, officers, and agents, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I00816Q"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &ss;§<trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace>§683</trace> et seq.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|52|30:48"</field>Although the certificate or bylaws may prescribe qualifications for directors,<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>3►<field>fn.fnref="3"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|52|30:48"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I00AUBM"</field>N-PCL &s;§701(a).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Qualifications of directors of not-for-profit corporations, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I0616CK"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &s;§<trace.deleted/><trace>535</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> the number of directors must be at least three.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>4►<field>fn.fnref="4"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|52|30:48"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I05WYN8"</field>N-PCL &s;§702(a).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Number of directors for not-for-profit corporations, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I05SQXW"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &s;§<trace.deleted/><trace>537</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> The bylaws or the certificate of incorporation may, however, provide for committees composed of directors.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>5►<field>fn.fnref="5"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|52|30:48"</field>See ►<field>st.ref.id="I002F2O"</field>N-PCL &s;§712(a).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Delegation of authority to executive and other committees, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I00587K"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &ss;§§<trace.deleted/><trace>592 to 594</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|52|30:48"</field>Newly created directorships resulting from an increase in the number of directors elected or appointed at large and vacancies among such directors for any reason may be filled by vote of a majority of the directors then in office, regardless of their number, unless the certificate of incorporation or the bylaws provide that such newly created directorships or vacancies must be filled by vote of the members.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>6►<field>fn.fnref="6"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|52|30:48"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I0081CG"</field>N-PCL &s;§705(a).<f_break>Research References<f_break>►<field>rc.ref.id="I00AUHC"</field>Construction and effect of corporate bylaws or articles relating to change in number of directors, 3 A.L.R.3d 623.<f_break>Filling board of director vacancies, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I00DNM8"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &s;§55<trace>0</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> A director elected or appointed, as the case may be, will hold office until the next annual meeting at which the election of directors is in the regular order of business and until a successor is elected or appointed and qualified.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>7►<field>fn.fnref="7"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|52|30:48"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I00GGR4"</field>N-PCL &s;§705(c).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Term of directors, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I0616CA"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &s;§5<trace>46</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
30:49. Whistleblower policy
Research References
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I05WYMY"</field>West's Key Number Digest, Corporations and Business Organizations &key;3350 to 3499
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|53|30:49"</field>With certain exceptions, every corporation that has 20 or more employees and in the prior fiscal year had annual revenue in excess of $1 million must adopt<trace>, and oversee the implementation of, and compliance with, </trace>a whistleblower policy to protect from retaliation persons who report suspected improper conduct. Such policy must provide that no director, officer,<trace>key person ,</trace> employee<trace>,</trace> or volunteer of a corporation who in good faith reports any action or suspected action taken by or within the corporation that is illegal, fraudulent or in violation of any adopted policy of the corporation will suffer intimidation, harassment, discrimination or other retaliation or, in the case of employees, adverse employment consequence. <footnote><footnote.body><f_break>1►<field>fn.fnref="1"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|53|30:49"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I05SQXM"</field>N-PCL &s;§715-b(a).<f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|53|30:49"</field>►<field>cc.ref.id="I02N4VP"</field>Rosen v. Zionist Organization of America, 225 A.D.3d 575, 206 N.Y.S.3d 595 (1st Dep't 2024) finding that a former employee, who had been terminated, sufficiently alleged a cause of action against the employer, president, and chair of the board under the statute that required certain nonprofit organizations to adopt and implement whistleblower policies to protect individuals who reported suspected improper conduct from retaliatory conduct; the former employee alleged he was an employee, rather than an officer, of the employer, and the employer did not refute such allegation. ►<field>cc.ref.id="I02N4WU"</field>Rosen v. Zionist Organization of America, 225 A.D.3d 575, 206 N.Y.S.3d 595 (1st Dep't 2024).<f_break><trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|53|30:49"</field>►<field>cc.ref.id="I00587P"</field>Ferris v. Lustgarten Foundation, 189 A.D.3d 1002, 138 N.Y.S.3d 517 (2d Dep't 2020) stating that the statute governing whistleblower policy of not-for-profit corporations created private right of action for employees who were retaliated against or subject to adverse employment consequences as a result of whistleblowing activities, where the statute was intended to protect employees who reported suspect actions of corporations in good faith, the legislative purpose was promoted by holding corporations accountable for retaliation against whistleblowers, and there was no regulatory agency to enforce a not-for-profit corporation's compliance with the statute.<f_break><trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|53|30:49"</field>The whistleblower policy must include the following provisions:
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|53|30:49"</field>(1) Procedures for the reporting of violations or suspected violations of laws or corporate policies, including procedures for preserving the confidentiality of reported information;
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|53|30:49"</field>(2) A requirement that an employee, officer or director of the corporation be designated to administer the whistleblower policy and to report to the audit committee or other committee of independent directors or, if there are no such committees, to the board; and
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|53|30:49"</field>(3) A requirement that a copy of the policy be distributed to all directors, officers, employees and to volunteers who provide substantial services to the corporation. Posting the policy on the corporation's website or at the corporation's offices in a conspicuous location accessible to employees and volunteers are among the methods a corporation may use to satisfy the distribution requirement. <footnote><footnote.body><f_break>2►<field>fn.fnref="2"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|53|30:49"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I00588U"</field>N-PCL &s;§715-b(b).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
30:50. Conflict of interest policy
Research References
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I0081DQ"</field>West's Key Number Digest, Corporations and Business Organizations &key;3350 to 3499
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|54|30:50"</field>With certain exceptions, <trace.deleted/> <trace.deleted/><trace>board </trace>must adopt<trace>, and oversee the implementation of, and compliance with,</trace> a conflict of interest policy to ensure that its directors, officers and key <trace.deleted/><trace>persons </trace>act in the corporation's best interest and comply with applicable legal requirements. <footnote><footnote.body><f_break>1►<field>fn.fnref="1"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|54|30:50"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I00AUIM"</field>N-PCL &s;§715-a(a).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|54|30:50"</field>The conflict of interest policy must include, at a minimum, the following provisions:
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|54|30:50"</field>(1) a definition of the circumstances that constitute a conflict of interest;
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|54|30:50"</field>(2) procedures for disclosing a conflict of interest <trace>or possible conflict of interest to the board or to a committee of the board, and procedures for the board or committee to determine whether a conflict exists</trace>;
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|54|30:50"</field>(3) a requirement that the person with the conflict of interest not be present at or participate in board or committee deliberation or vote on the matter giving rise to such conflict, provided that nothing will prohibit the board or a committee from requesting that the person with the conflict of interest present information as background or answer questions at a committee or board meeting prior to the commencement of deliberations or voting relating thereto;
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|54|30:50"</field>(4) a prohibition against any attempt by the person with the conflict to influence improperly the deliberation or voting on the matter giving rise to such conflict;
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|54|30:50"</field>(5) a requirement that the existence and resolution of the conflict be documented in the corporation's records, including in the minutes of any meeting at which the conflict was discussed or voted upon; and
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|54|30:50"</field>(6) procedures for disclosing, addressing, and documenting related party transactions in accordance with ►<field>st.ref.id="I002F41"</field>N-PCL &s;§. <footnote><footnote.body><f_break>2►<field>fn.fnref="2"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|54|30:50"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I002F43"</field>N-PCL &s;§715-a(b).<f_break><trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><f_break><trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|54|30:50"</field>The conflict of interest policy must require that prior to the initial election of any director, and annually thereafter, such director must complete, sign and submit to the secretary of the corporation or a designated compliance officer a written statement identifying, to the best of the director's knowledge, any entity of which such director is an officer, director, trustee, member, owner (either as a sole proprietor or a partner), or employee and with which the corporation has a relationship, and any transaction in which the corporation is a participant and in which the director might have a conflicting interest. The policy must require that each director annually resubmit such written statement. The secretary of the corporation or the designated compliance officer must provide a copy of all completed statements to the chair of the audit committee or, if there is no audit committee, to the chair of the board. <footnote><footnote.body><f_break>3►<field>fn.fnref="3"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|54|30:50"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I00AUIR"</field>N-PCL &s;§715-a(c).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
30:51. Membership
Research References
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I00DNNN"</field>West's Key Number Digest, Corporations and Business Organizations &key;3400 to 3419
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|55|30:51"</field>A not-for-profit corporation may have one or more classes of members or, in the case of a charitable corporation, may have no members.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>1►<field>fn.fnref="1"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|55|30:51"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I002MZ3"</field>N-PCL &s;§601(a).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> Provision is usually made in the bylaws for classes of members, election of members, their voting rights, termination of membership, resignation, reinstatement, and transfer of membership.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>2►<field>fn.fnref="2"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|55|30:51"</field>See ►<field>x.ref.id="I002MZ5"</field>&ss;§§30:97 et seq.<f_break>Research References<f_break>Who may be members of not-for-profit corporation, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I005G41"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &s;<trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace>§823</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|55|30:51"</field>The bylaws of a not-for-profit corporation may provide for the time, place, and manner of calling and conducting annual and special meetings of members<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>3►<field>fn.fnref="3"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|55|30:51"</field>See ►<field>st.ref.id="I00898X"</field>N-PCL &s;§603.<f_break>Research References<f_break>Calling of meetings of members, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I00B2DT"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &s;<trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace>§897</trace>.<f_break>Notice of meetings of members, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I00DVIP"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &ss;§§<trace.deleted/><trace>901 to 907</trace>.<f_break>Time and place of meetings of members, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I00GONL"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &ss;§§9<trace.deleted/>0<trace>8</trace> to 91<trace.deleted/><trace>0</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> and for the requirements of a quorum of members.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>4►<field>fn.fnref="4"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|55|30:51"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I060QJC"</field>N-PCL &s;§608.<f_break>Research References<f_break>Quorum requirements for not-for-profit corporations, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I05WIU0"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &s;<trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace>§912</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> Special meetings of the members may be called by the board or by such person or persons as may be authorized by the certificate of incorporation or the bylaws. In the absence of a provision in the certificate of incorporation or the bylaws for the convening of special meetings of the membership, such meetings may be convened by the members entitled to cast 10&percnt;% of the total number of votes entitled to be cast at such meeting.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>5►<field>fn.fnref="5"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|55|30:51"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I05SB4O"</field>N-PCL &s;§603(c).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Calling of meetings of members, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I00B2DV"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &s;<trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace>§897</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|55|30:51"</field>Fees, dues, and assessments may be imposed on and collected from the members of the corporation in accordance with the provisions of the certificate of incorporation or the bylaws.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>6►<field>fn.fnref="6"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|55|30:51"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I00DVIR"</field>N-PCL &s;§507(a).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Fees, dues, and assessments, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I00GONN"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &ss;§§<trace.deleted/><trace>828, 829</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> Initiation fees, dues, or assessments may be levied on all classes of members or in different amounts or proportions for different classes of members, as the certificate of incorporation or the bylaws may provide but, in all cases, the fees, dues, and assessments payable by members of one class must be determined on the same basis.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>7►<field>fn.fnref="7"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|55|30:51"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I002MZA"</field>N-PCL &s;§507(b).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Fees, dues, and assessments, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I005G46"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &ss;§§<trace.deleted/><trace>828, 829</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> Additionally, the certificate of incorporation or, more commonly, the bylaws, may contain such provisions as are deemed necessary to enforce the collection of fees, dues, assessments, fines, or other penalties, including provisions for the termination of membership, on reasonable notice, for nonpayment of such fees, dues, assessments, fines, or other penalties and provisions for reinstatement of membership.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>8►<field>fn.fnref="8"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|55|30:51"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I008992"</field>N-PCL &s;§507(c).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Delinquencies and collection of fees, dues, and assessments, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I060QGW"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &s;§<trace.deleted/><trace>829</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|55|30:51"</field>The N.Y. Not-for-Profit Corp. Law sets forth provisions regarding members and members' rights, including meetings of members,<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>9►<field>fn.fnref="9"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|55|30:51"</field>See ►<field>st.ref.id="I005G5B"</field>N-PCL &ss;§§603 et seq.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> voting rights,<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>10►<field>fn.fnref="10"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|55|30:51"</field>See ►<field>st.ref.id="I0089A7"</field>N-PCL &ss;§§611 et seq.<f_break>Research References<f_break>Right of members to vote, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I00B2F3"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &s;§91<trace>6</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> informal action by members entitled to vote,<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>11►<field>fn.fnref="11"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|55|30:51"</field>See ►<field>st.ref.id="I002N0I"</field>N-PCL &s;§614.<f_break>Research References<f_break>Action by members without meeting, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I005G5E"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &s;§89<trace.deleted/><trace>4</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> and voting agreements.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>12►<field>fn.fnref="12"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|55|30:51"</field>See ►<field>st.ref.id="I0089AA"</field>N-PCL &s;§619.<f_break>Research References<f_break>Validity of voting agreements, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I00B2F6"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &s;§95<trace>4</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|55|30:51"</field>In accordance with the general rule regarding immunity of shareholders for the debts of a corporation, members are not personally liable for the debts, liabilities, or obligations of a not-for-profit corporation.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>13►<field>fn.fnref="13"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|55|30:51"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I00DVK2"</field>N-PCL &s;§517(a).<f_break>Research References<f_break>Nonliability of members of not-for-profit corporations, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I00GOOY"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &s;§97<trace.deleted/><trace>3</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|55|30:51"</field>As noted above, the certificate of incorporation or, more commonly, the bylaws, may contain such provisions as are deemed necessary to enforce the collection of fees, dues, assessments, fines, or other penalties, including provisions for the termination of membership, on reasonable notice, for nonpayment of such fees, dues, assessments, fines, or other penalties and provisions for reinstatement of membership.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>14►<field>fn.fnref="14"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|55|30:51"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I00JHTU"</field>N-PCL &s;§507(c).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> In the absence of a bylaw to the contrary, failure to pay dues does not automatically terminate membership.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>15►<field>fn.fnref="15"</field><f_break>Research References<f_break>Delinquencies and collection of dues, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I002N65"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &s;§<trace.deleted/><trace>829</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> Additionally, membership in a not-for-profit corporation is terminated by death, resignation, expulsion, expiration of a term of membership, or dissolution, judicial or nonjudicial, unless otherwise provided by the N.Y. Not-for-Profit Corporation Law, the certificate of incorporation, or the bylaws.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>16►<field>fn.fnref="16"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|55|30:51"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I005GB1"</field>N-PCL &s;§601(e).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
Practice Tip:
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|55|30:51"</field>Inasmuch as property rights may be involved in connection with the expulsion of a member, the grounds and procedure (including fair trial, fair notice of the proceedings and charges or accusations, and an opportunity to be heard or to meet the accusations) provisions in the bylaws should be carefully drafted.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>17►<field>fn.fnref="17"</field><f_break>Research References<f_break>Discipline of members; suspension and expulsion, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I002N68"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &ss;§§<trace.deleted/><trace>831 to 834</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|55|30:51"</field>In the absence of a bylaw to the contrary, membership in a not-for-profit corporation terminates on tender or receipt of a resignation. In such case, formal acceptance by the corporation is not necessary to make the resignation effective. However, the bylaws may provide that no resignation shall be effective until accepted or until the member has discharged his or her indebtedness to the organization.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>18►<field>fn.fnref="18"</field><f_break>Research References<f_break>Termination or forfeiture of membership; resignation, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I005GB4"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &ss;§§83<trace>5</trace>, 8<trace.deleted/><trace>38</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
30:52. Dissolution of corporation
Research References
 ►<field>tk.ref.id="I0089G0"</field>West's Key Number Digest, Corporations and Business Organizations &key;3480 to 3489
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|56|30:52"</field>A not-for-profit corporation has the power to cease its corporate activities and terminate its existence by voluntary dissolution.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>1►<field>fn.fnref="1"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|56|30:52"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I00B2KW"</field>N-PCL &ss;§§1001 et seq.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> On dissolution, a not-for-profit corporation may make distributions to its members as permitted by the N.Y. Not-for-Profit Corporation Law.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>2►<field>fn.fnref="2"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|56|30:52"</field>See ►<field>st.ref.id="I002N6A"</field>N-PCL &s;§515(b).<f_break>Research References<f_break>►<field>rc.ref.id="I005GB6"</field>Right to assets of voluntarily dissolved lodge or club, 70 A.L.R.4th 897.<f_break>►<field>rc.ref.id="I0089G2"</field>Distribution of funds by nonprofit corporation absent dissolution, 51 A.L.R.3d 1318.<f_break>Nonjudicial dissolution of not-for-profit corporations, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I00B2KY"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &ss;§§<trace.deleted/><trace>1328 to 1336</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> The Law also provides for the dissolution of a not-for-profit corporation by an action for dissolution brought by the Attorney General based on one or more specified, statutory grounds.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>3►<field>fn.fnref="3"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|56|30:52"</field>See ►<field>st.ref.id="I00DVPU"</field>N-PCL &ss;§§1101 et seq.<f_break><trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><trace.deleted/><f_break></footnote.body></footnote> A foreign corporation authorized to conduct affairs in New York may surrender its authority by filing a certificate of surrender of authority with the Department of State.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>4►<field>fn.fnref="4"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|56|30:52"</field>The fee for filing a certificate of surrender of authority, which is subject to change, is $30. ►<field>st.ref.id="I00GOUQ"</field>N-PCL &s;§104-A(q).<f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|56|30:52"</field>See ►<field>st.ref.id="I060Q52"</field>N-PCL &s;§1311.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> The certificate must set forth the foreign corporation's name as it appears on the index of names of existing and authorized foreign corporations of any type or kind in the Department of State and the fictitious name the corporation has agreed to use in this state pursuant to ►<field>st.ref.id="I05WIFQ"</field>Section 1301 of the Not-for-Profit Corporation Law.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>5►<field>fn.fnref="5"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|56|30:52"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I0089G4"</field>N-PCL &s;§1311(a)(1).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> A foreign corporation's authority to conduct activities in the State of New York terminates on the filing by the Department of State of the certificate of surrender of authority.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>6►<field>fn.fnref="6"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|56|30:52"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I002N7I"</field>N-PCL &s;§1311(c).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|56|30:52"</field>The procedures for the voluntary, nonjudicial dissolution and the application and distribution of assets of a not-for-profit corporation are set forth in the N.Y. Not-for-Profit Corporation Law.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>7►<field>fn.fnref="7"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|56|30:52"</field>See ►<field>st.ref.id="I005GCE"</field>N-PCL &ss;§§1001 et seq.<f_break>Research References<f_break>►<field>rc.ref.id="I0089HA"</field>Right to assets of voluntarily dissolved lodge or club, 70 A.L.R.4th 897.<f_break>Nonjudicial dissolution of not-for-profit corporation, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I00B2M6"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &ss;§§<trace.deleted/><trace>1328 to 1336</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> The Law also sets forth what must be contained in the certificate of dissolution, which must be signed and delivered to the Department of State.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>8►<field>fn.fnref="8"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|56|30:52"</field>See ►<field>st.ref.id="I060Q2M"</field>N-PCL &s;§1003.<f_break>Research References<f_break>Certificate of dissolution of not-for-profit corporation, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I05WIDA"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &s;§13<trace.deleted/><trace>32</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|56|30:52"</field>Basically, a nonjudicial dissolution of a not-for-profit corporation must be initiated by the adoption by the corporation's board of directors of a plan for its dissolution and the distribution of its assets.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>9►<field>fn.fnref="9"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|56|30:52"</field>See ►<field>st.ref.id="I05SANY"</field>N-PCL &s;§1001.<f_break>Research References<f_break>►<field>rc.ref.id="I05O2YM"</field>Right to assets of voluntarily dissolved lodge or club, 70 A.L.R.4th 897.<f_break>Nonjudicial dissolution of not-for-profit corporation, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I00DVR4"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &ss;§§<trace.deleted/><trace>1328 to 1336</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> This plan must implement any provision in the certificate of incorporation prescribing the distributive rights of its members.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>10►<field>fn.fnref="10"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|56|30:52"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I00GOW0"</field>N-PCL &s;§1001(a).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
Practice Tip:
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|56|30:52"</field>If the corporation is a charitable corporation and has no assets to distribute and no liabilities at the time of dissolution, the plan must include a statement to that effect. <footnote><footnote.body><f_break>11►<field>fn.fnref="11"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|56|30:52"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I002N7N"</field>N-PCL &s;§1001(b).<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> If the corporation has no assets to distribute, other than a reserve not to exceed $25,000 for the purpose of paying ordinary and necessary expenses of winding up its affairs including attorney and accountant fees, and liabilities not in excess of $10,000 at the time of adoption of the plan of dissolution, the plan of dissolution must include a statement to that effect.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>12►<field>fn.fnref="12"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|56|30:52"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I005GCJ"</field>N-PCL &s;§1001(c).<f_break>Research References<f_break>►<field>rc.ref.id="I0089HF"</field>Right to assets of voluntarily dissolved lodge or club, 70 A.L.R.4th 897.<f_break>Nonjudicial dissolution of not-for-profit corporation, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I00B2MB"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &ss;§§<trace.deleted/><trace>1328 to 1336</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|56|30:52"</field>The board must then submit its plan to the members of the corporation for approval.<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>13►<field>fn.fnref="13"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|56|30:52"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I060PR6"</field>N-PCL &s;§1002(a).<f_break>Research References<f_break>►<field>rc.ref.id="I005GI6"</field>Right to assets of voluntarily dissolved lodge or club, 70 A.L.R.4th 897.<f_break>Nonjudicial dissolution of not-for-profit corporation, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I0089N2"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &ss;§§<trace.deleted/><trace>1328 to 1336</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote> The dissolution is deemed authorized when the plan is approved by the statutory two-thirds vote of the members, provided, however, that if the corporation is a charitable corporation, other than a corporation incorporated pursuant to the article governing public cemetery corporations, the vote required by the corporation's board of directors for adoption of the plan of dissolution of such a corporation or by the corporation's members for the authorization thereof will be:
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|56|30:52"</field>(1) In the case of a vote by the board of directors: (i) the number of directors required under the certificate of incorporation, bylaws, the Not-for-Profit Corporation Law and any other applicable law;<trace> (ii) two-thirds of the directors present at the time of the vote, if a quorum is present at that time; </trace>or (ii) if the number of directors actually holding office as such at the time of the vote to adopt the plan is less than the number required to constitute a quorum of directors under the certificate of incorporation, the bylaws, the Not-for-Profit Corporation Law or any other applicable law, the remaining directors unanimously;
 ►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|56|30:52"</field>(2) In the case of a vote by the members, (i) the number of members required under the certificate of incorporation, bylaws, the Not-for-Profit Corporation Law and any other applicable law; or (ii) by the vote of members authorized by an order of the Supreme Court pursuant to ►<field>st.ref.id="I002NDD"</field>N-PCL &s;§608 permitting the corporation to dispense with the applicable quorum requirement.1<footnote><footnote.body><f_break>14►<field>fn.fnref="14"</field><f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|56|30:52"</field>►<field>st.ref.id="I005GI9"</field>N-PCL &s;§1002(a).<f_break>►<field>p.ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|56|30:52"</field>Notice of a special or regular meeting of the board of directors or of the members entitled to vote on adoption and authorization or approval of the plan of dissolution must be sent to all the directors and members of record entitled to vote. Unless otherwise directed by order of the Supreme Court pursuant to ►<field>st.ref.id="I0089N5"</field>N-PCL &s;§608, the notice must be sent by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the last-known address of record of each director and member not fewer than 30, and not more than 60 days before the date of each meeting provided, however, that if the last-known address of record of any director or member is not within the United States, the notice to such director will be sent by any other reasonable means.<f_break>Research References<f_break>►<field>rc.ref.id="I00B2S1"</field>Right to assets of voluntarily dissolved lodge or club, 70 A.L.R.4th 897.<f_break>Nonjudicial dissolution of not-for-profit corporation, ►<field>rc.ref.id="I00DVWX"</field>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &ss;§§<trace.deleted/><trace>1328 to 1336</trace>.<f_break></footnote.body></footnote>
